div3.head: TC TO DAVID LAING

docBody.p: About four weeks ago, not sooner, the fine new Book Memoirs of the Master of SinclairJohn, master of Sinclair, Memoirs of the Insurrection in Scotland in 1715 (Edinburgh, 1858). John Sinclair (ca. 1683–1750), Jacobite army officer; deprived of his title because of his involvement in the 1715 Jacobite Rebellion, he lived in exile until pardoned in 1726. whh Mr MacknightJames Macknight (1810–78; see 17:260TC to DL, 10 Feb. 1844) edited Memoirs, which the Abbotsford Club (of which he was treasurer) pbd. Although his name is not on the title page, David Laing is named as “joint superintendent” of the publication in the minutes of the Abbotsford Club’s meeting, 9 Dec. 1856 (printed at the start of Memoirs); they also note that it was to be printed, “accompanied with Sir Walter Scott’s Annotations, from the Manuscript at Abbotsford” (iii). Sir Walter Scott (1771–1832), Scottish novelist and poet; Abbotsford was his country seat, nr. Melrose; it contains his extensive library. had been so kind as announce a good while before, was safely handed in to me; and I read it straight way, with a great deal of pleasure and thankfulness,—meaning to express the same to you with the least possible delay. That surely was the minimum of what could be expected of me, in the case! I am very blameable to have delayed so long: but if you saw how I am held to the grindstone here, by the ugliest job man ever had, and by a great many botherations over and above, I think you could hardly have the heart to condemn me without speedy absolution after!—

I found the Master a most excellent fellow to keep company with in print; and truly it is many a day since I have read a Book with so much entertainment,—or been able to read so ill-written a Book at all. Nothing can excel the tortuous verbosity, iteration, perversity, of the Master’s way of describing that matter and the people acting in it: but it is notable with what a degree of glowing distinctness he lodges it, every feature of it, in our mind at last,—having had it so in his own, and being a man of real force and talent. I found great pleasure in him;—and wish much you, or somebody competent, would annotate him judiciously: give dates especially (day by day, that is terribly wanted), explain who and what (in outline) these bankrupt LordsClan leaders and gentry who took part in the rebellion and then fled, whose lands and wealth were therefore forfeit. &c &c are. I find the thing to be not only a Picture, but a Bit of Sculpture (so vivid is it), were the dark places cleared up. Potentially a “bit of Sculpture”; potentially, that is all: to make it really such wd be a harder job!—

There are several errors of the press, as you doubtless know: the worst I noticed was in p. 45, “placed armes,“—instead of “place d’armes.”The passage reads: “I was positive nobodie ever pretended to make war without haveing some placed armes to retreat to in case of a misfortune, and where we might keep our stores and magazines” (Memoirs 45).
Accept my kind thanks and regards, sincere tho’ late; and please, to Mr Macknight too, with the fit apologies from me! I am always
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady C [LCH], 6 Feb. MS: Shakespeare Birthplace Trust, Stratford-upon-Avon. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY CHATTERTON

docBody.p: I very well remember your goodness to me; I have to thank you again for a pretty Book,Lady Chatterton had presumably sent Extracts from the Works of Jean Paul F. Richter, selected and trans. Georgiana, Lady Chatterton (1859); its publication was announced in the Examiner, 22 Jan. TC wrote to Lady Chatterton, 23 Aug. 1845, in answer to her queries about translating Richter: “If I might venture to advise, your profitablest plan would be to learn German, and read Richter and others for yourself. Which were a far easier attainment than perhaps you apprehend” (MS: Shakespeare Birthplace Trust; hitherto unpbd.). TC sent the letter to JWC, 23 Aug. 1845, referring to Lady Chatterton as “a young writing lady, does Irish Tales I think, or some such rubbish”; see 19:168TC to JWC, 23 Aug. 1845.—which I believe will do good to all that read in it: a thing one cannot say of many Books now going. My vote is you have made a clearly superior use of your leisure hours in doing such a work, and you have done it well, whh was not quite easy either.

closer.salute: I beg to return you many thanks and respects and good wishes; and am sincerely

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [7 Feb.?]. MS: NLS 7864. Hitherto unpbd. Conjecturally dated by being the third letter in the sequence about eggs; see JWC to MCA, [3 or 10 Jan.?].
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p:
Oh my poor dear little Woman! I declare I could put my arms round your neck, and cry over you!—about those eggs!— If only, crying might mend
broken eggs—or broken anything!—which it won’t!— The next thing I am tempted to do is to tell you a good round lie, smack-out! to describe the eggs as having arrived all whole this time; not so much as one cracked one among them. But what then? You would go on believing in this principle of egg-packing! and practising it, on occasion, with such waste of the largest freshest beautifulest eggs in Creation, as is lamentable to think of!— Besides, that I have a certain objection to telling lies, when one isn’t absolutely driven to it!! so here goes for the truth; little as it pleases me to tell it, or will please you to hear it! My Dear! that box arrived all right outwardly; not a nail loosened in it—no egg dripping out! and I took off the lid “with my own hands”Coterie speech; see 4:336TC to JAC, 7 March 1828.—and chisel. The first lair of hay being tenderly lifted off disclosed——“immortal smash”!!Coterie speech; see 14:210TC to TSS, 26 June 1842. certainly two thirds of that first lair of eggs had to be lifted with a spoon! some, clean spilt in the hay, “could not be gathered!” And so it went on to the bottom; in spite of your clever expedient of nailing the “chuka”Chicken. to the box; so that it had exercised no fatal influence on the rest of the contents. The result was not so desperate this time as last time however; tho’ as large a proportion of eggs were broken there were not so many lost—not above eight or ten quite spilt—all the rest, with more or less in them, were put in a dish by themselves. and I am eating them poached or fried and Mr C is having them in puddings. Now, tho’ I have told you the fact of the case dear Mary I wont have you vexing your kind heart about it. Your part had been done with all the zeal and pains and generosity conceivable—even to prepaying the carriage—which I declare to be a piece of handsomeness perfectly unusual in this world! and which certainly nobody ever dreams of doing for us except your magnanimous self! Besides there are a great many whole eggs to the fore! quite as many as will serve him for breakfast as long as they will be fresh— Bless you it is not above a week since he had the last of the former escaped two dozen!!— And there will be plenty to be had here, fresh enough, by the time these are done. It is only in the middle of summer and in the middle of winter that the supply breaks down.

I will write you a letter of greater length and not smeared over with egg, some day soon. Just now I am obliged to break off—to prepare for a drive in “a neat Fly” which Mr C has forced on me twice a week—and the expense of which seems to me to greatly outride the project!

Bless you I can get a good jumble, 12 or fourteen miles long, for one shilling, in a clean, roomy, Omnibus!— The gentility is all the advantage on the ‘Fly’ side of the question! and really having been used to set gentility at defiance when my years and my looks and my habits made such proceedings
riskish for myself, and questionable in the eyes of others, I dont see why the deuce I should be told by Mr C, now, when nobody is at the trouble to think about or remark upon me, and when I myself am completely habituated to self dependence—that “really my dear it is quite improper for you to be going in Omnibuses!! one should conform to the customs of the people one lives among!!” Lord! Lord! It was a very different story that was impressed on my youthful mind, when I had to go to somebody (Murry’s) marriage, with Mr C a few weeks after my own marriageTC and JWC were m. 17 Oct. 1826; TC’s longtime friend Rev. Thomas Murray (1792–1872; see 1:3TC to TM, 24 June 1813) m. Janet, b. Murray, late Dec. 1826; see 4:169TC to TM, 14 Dec. 1826, and 178–79TC to AC, 1 Jan. 1827. in a wet night—in my thin white dress—with an umbrella and a pair of Pattens!! To be “above the prejudices of the people one lived among” was then required of me every day and every hour— Men are curious creatures after all! and so are women for that matter! Love to your belongings and your good little self
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GMC, [8 Feb.]. Addr: Holywood / Belfast / Ireland. PM: Charing Cross, 11 Feb. 1859; Belfast, 12 Feb. 1859. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO GEORGIANA MARION CRAIK

docBody.p: The only thing I have to say for myself is, that it is better to be thanking you for your book thus late,Lost and Won (1859) was reviewed by Geraldine Jewsbury: “An improvement on Miss Craik’s first work … [the] story bespeaks a young writer, who has not much knowledge of life and nature to go upon, but making good use of all she has” (Athenaeum, 12 March, 354). For JWC’s delays in acknowledging Georgiana Craik’s first novel, Riverton, 3 vols. (1857), see 33:113JWC to DD, 5 Nov. 1857. but after having read it; than to have adopted Talleyrand’sCharles Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord (1754–1838), French statesman and diplomat. or Sir Walter Scott’s dodge (I have heard it imputed to both) of returning thanks on the instant; while merely “hoping to read the book with the same pleasure with which I had received it.”

From what your FatherGeorge Lillie Craik. told me, when he was here, about this second book, and from my own conviction about you; that you are not one of what I call the tea-pot-authoresses, who having infused all the tea they had, or ever would have, pour one off a tolerable cup at the first pouring, and go on ever after adding new water to the same leaves, till it ends in sheer dishwashings!— Confident that you would turn out to have a full tea-canister as well as
a boiling kettle; I did not see any imprudence in deferring my acknowledgement of the book, till there was full time to have read it, and until I had read it. But I might have read thro’, and should have been delighted to have read thro’ a dozen such volumes in the time that has elapsed since I said to George Cook;JWC’s friend, John George Cooke, who was a frequent visitor at the time; see 34:257JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1858. “do you ever hear from Mrs HooperProbably Jane Margaret Hooper, b. Winnard (b. 1818), author of The House of Raby, or Our Lady of Darkness (1854), m. to George Hooper (1824–90), journalist. They were friends of the Craiks; see 31:125–26JWC to MC, [19 July 1856]. if Georgina Craik’s Book is out yet. I don’t know its name—I shall be so vexed if it is published and she hasn’t sent it to me!“—and as if in answer to the words—not ten minutes after—Lost and Won was brought up stairs!! But tho’ I had been so impatient to have it; I did not get it read for more than a week. I looked into it here and there, and felt sure that if I began at the beginning I should not stop till I reached the end—and there were just then several things absolutely oughting to be done—amongst the rest, I recollect, there was a letter to be written to my clever, good young cousin, he who is in the Kew Observatory;John Welsh, the meteorologist. but now at Falmouth for change of climate, being far gone in ConsumptionJohn Welsh had gone to Falmouth with his mother in 1858; see 34:222—23JWC to JWEL, 21 Oct. 1858. He d. 12 May.—and there was another letter to be written to my dear old Ladies at Haddington,Jean and Jess Donaldson. to whom I was going when I accompanied you in that never to be forgotten dog-box!The very uncomfortable train journey to Scotland with the Craiks, July 1857; see 32:173–74JWC to TC, 8 July 1857. And the one of these two oldest friends I have on Earth, has been for weeks past dying slowly, slowly, a painful death of restlessness and sleeplessness, tho’ eighty nine years old! Not a symptom of age and decay in her mind and heart but all vividly alive there, to feel the more acutely the loss of sight and hearing and the weary struggle with death.Jean Donaldson, JWC’s godmother, d. 30 March 1860. and the other sister eighty five; a confirmed Invalid since before I was born! hanging on the failing breath of the one who has been her strength thro life—about to be left solitaryJess Donaldson, JWC’s main correspondent, d. 1 June 1860.—for the large family of nephews and nieces (of which Dr Donaldson the Classical ManJohn William Donaldson; there were two other nephews and six nieces. is one) aren’t a bit of comfort to the Aunts, whom their heartlessness and worldliness distress at every turn— That sort of letters are hard to write, dear, I trust you havn’t had much opportunity to know how hard! Just the more one’s heart is full of sympathy the more one hasn’t a word to say!— Not to be tempted aside to a real pleasure instead, I sent Lost & Won to Countess
Pepoli, who was confined to her room with a cold, begging to have it back in three days—and—she kept it ten!— Now however I have read it and well read it—and I like it better than any novel that I have read for years—with one exception (to be perfectly truthful) Scenes from Clerical Life. and that is by a man.George Eliot, Scenes of Clerical Life (1858); JWC had been sent a copy and wrote to the author assuming she was a man; see 33:164–65JWC to GEL, 21 Jan. 1858. The last two novels I had read were Framley Hall and an old debt by Snow Wedgwood,Frances Julia Wedgwood, Framleigh Hall (1858); reviewed by Jewsbury in the Athenaeum, 21 Aug. 1858, 231–32. An Old Debt (1858) was pbd. under her pseud., Florence Dawson. “Snow” was her family nickname; the Carlyles had known the Wedgwood family since the 1830s; see 9:107TC to HWE, 11 Dec. 1836. whom like yourself I have known from a Child but, not like yourself, been fond of from a Child—a morbid, self conscious, self centered young Lady who has there put into print for us all the spewings of her (moral) stomach, and given them the name of “Self-Sacrifice”!— The Critics have praised her as a wonderfully clever and metaphysical young Lady— I find her only a wonderfully indelicate young Lady—“coming out for to“—spew before Company! You may call it the criticism of a Dressmaker; but I should say this last book of yours is intensely womanly and “Ladylike“—and in the time we live in I take that to be very high praise! It is so seldom one meets with an Authoress now, who is either a woman or a Lady; and as they certainly are not men (for all the dodge of putting mens names on their Title pages!)—one wants to know what the devil they are at all! and—until they can satisfy one, as to “who made them,” to give them a wide berth!

But “womanly and Ladylike” is not all the praise I have to give your Book—it is poetical too—That gleaming haired UndineJWC was probably thinking of Craik’s character Hildred Kane, an outsider, rather than the narrator, Hope Graham. Undine was a water nymph in medieval legend and the subject of Baron Friedrich Heinrich Karl de la Motte Fouqué’s Undine (Berlin, 1811); see 25:162TC to JWC, 19 Aug. 1850. of a girl is like “a time of music” (as Mr Carlyle would say)Cf. 9:52TC to JOST, 11 Sept. 1836, when TC calls a conversation “a pleasant time of music or Sonata.”— Decidedly your tea does not fall off—“quite the contrary[“]Coterie speech; see 26:232JWC to JAC, [15 Nov. 1851].— The first was rather too much drawn— In this only the delicate flavour is traceable, “with cream and sugar softened well” (as Dr Johnson himself liked it)“I therefore pray thee, Renny dear, / That thou wilt give to me, / With cream and sugar soften’d well, / Another dish of tea”; from an untitled poem by Samuel Johnson; see The Poems of Samuel Johnson, ed. David Nichol Smith and Edward L. McAdam (Oxford, 1941) 158.
My Dear—excuse my freedom of criticism, in consideration of no superior sense I pretend to, but of my decided superiority in years!
My kindest regards to your Father— A kiss to that dear good quiet little MaryGeorgiana’s elder sister.— Again thanking you heartily for the pleasure you have given me
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [8 Feb.]. Addr: 3. St John’s Villas / Highbury Vale. PM: London, 8 Feb. 1859. MS: Huntington Lib. Pbd: Larkin, BQR 68.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Sir,—Could you call tomorrow at the Londn Library, and bring me Oeuvres de Voltaire vol. 39The London Lib. had Voltaire, Oeuvres Complètes (Paris, 17–20); see also 29:247TC to HG, 8 Feb. 1855. (there are marks in whh I wish to see):—I will then give you some (abstruse enough) copying to do.Larkin noted that “in addition to map-making, my labours had gradually come to include the deciphering and copying-out of the more intricate and least intelligible bits of Carlyle’s sometimes singularly intricate manuscript, as the following note will sufficiently testify” (BQR 68).——In haste of hastes
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p:
Chelsea, Tuesday
(try this paper—no other to be had)

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [ca. 8 Feb.]. MS: NLS 606.520. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:201–4 inc. Conjecturally dated by JWC to GMC, [8 Feb.], when she also wrote about John Welsh’s illness and the Donaldson sisters’ failing health.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
If I dont take care I shall be falling into the self-same evil course I warned you against in my last. “Let him that standeth on the house-top take heed &c &c.”Cf. 1 Cor. 10:12. I don’t think my brain is so active when I sleep (as I still continue to do with that whisky!) as it used to be when I spent greater part of my nights in reading in my bed, to stave off insane thoughts! The fact is, anyhow, that my stupidity in these weeks approaches the sublime! and yet I dont get fat upon it; so I doubt if it be good, genuine, healthy stupidity, and not rather some physical torpor! Perhaps the explanation isJWC wrote “is” and “were”; it is unclear which is the original and which the correction. comprised in the few frank words
which Dr JeffsonProbably Dr. Henry Jephson (1798–1878) of Leamington Spa, who was consulted by many, including John Ruskin and members of nobility; he was famous for speaking bluntly, and stories and rhymes about him were widely circulated. addressed to the would-be-young Dandy who consulted him; “You are old—yes damned old! that’s all!“—

Did you ever see such a winter? I suppose it is good for weak lungs, but the Drs here say, there never was more sickness—only, the Drs say that, every winter, whether it be mild or severe! My poor Cousin at Falmouth fancies the climate there equal to that of Maidera, I question if it be Falmouth that makes the difference.The Carlyles had offered money to John Welsh for a trip to Madeira, hoping that the change in climate would relieve his worsening consumption, but he had chosen to go to Falmouth; see 34:222—23JWC to JWEL, 21 Oct. 1858. Of course he is no better. His MotherMargaret Welsh. writes such flourishing letters about the comforts he has, and the attentions he receives at Falmouth,Anna Maria and Caroline Fox in particular were kind to him; see 34:222—23JWC to JWEL, 21 Oct. 1858. that it is difficult to not let oneself be distracted from the fact of the case,—that her only son is dying!— Bence JonesHenry Bence Jones; see 33:254JWC to TC, [27 June 1858]. forwarded to me a letter from the Falmouth Doctor,Probably Frederick Charles Bullmore (1809–96), 1 Stratton Pl., Falmouth.—to destroy every hope, had I still entertained any. I have never seen so unintelligible a woman as Mrs George Welsh.

I have another sorrow in the constant expectation of hearing from Haddington that the eldestJean Donaldson. of my two dear old ladies is dead— She has continued to live, and keep all her intellects and feelings as alive as ever, nobody knows how, for weeks back—for she has lost the faculty of taking nourishment by which alone she was kept in life the DrDr. Thomas Howden (1812–1900). said. The otherJess Donaldson. can’t survive her long; and then Haddington will be turned all into a church-yard for me! What a strange reflection it must be for Miss Douglas,Miss Clark Douglas (1759–1859) of Holmhill, nr. Thornhill, a neighbor of Mary Russell; see 34:210JWC to MR, [1 Oct. 1858]. The 1851 Census records that she was the head of a household that had two female servants in the house and one on the farm, and two male farm laborers. Clark was her first name; b. in Penicuik, Midlothian, she perhaps knew the Donaldsons because she had lived in Haddington at some point. She d. 10 Aug. The Russells were to move to Holmhill in the autumn. (if she ever reflects,) that she has outlived all she began life beside! even a distant approximation to that state of being left behind all ones contemporaries, makes one so wae and dreary, at times! But also it makes the early friends we still possess doubly dear—every year they become more precious— Think of that—you—
when you are tempted to fall into faithless speculations about any Mrs PringleJWC’s cousin, Janet Pringle, of Lann Hall, where JWC had visited her, Aug. 1858, before going to stay with Mary Russell at Thornhill; see 34:107JWC to MR, 8 Aug. [1858]. I may take up with!

I heard, curiously enough, of Mrs DunbarA Mrs. Dunbar lived at 16 Brompton Row, London, but this is more probably a Mrs. Dunbar from Dumfriesshire or Haddington known to JWC and Mary Russell. the other day. She was visiting a Mrs BorthwickPossibly Mrs. Borthwick of 11 Walton Villas, Chelsea. (I dont know the Lady), a friend of the Artist who did that picture of our Interior.Robert Tait and A Chelsea Interior; see 33:175TC to JAC, 28 Jan. 1858, and 33:196–97JWC to MR, 29 March 1858; for several details reproduced from the painting, see vol. 33. Mrs Borthwick was showing her some Italian views and among them was a photograph of the picture which the artist had given this Mrs Borthwick— Mrs Dunbar went into raptures over its distinctness and suddenly, not knowing what Interior it was, exclaimed “good gracious! there is Mrs Carlyle sitting in it!” Tait was enchanted when Mrs Borthwick repeated to him this tribute to his talent!—
How are your maids going on? and the Bread? Have you put “sand in the oven” as Mrs BlacklockProbably Mary Blacklock; see 34:210JWC to MR, [1 Oct. 1858]. advised?!
My little Charlotte continues to behave like the good girl of a Fairy Tale!—The only drawback to my satisfaction with her is, that it seems too great to last—in a world of imperfection!

Do you still wake up your patient HusbandJames Russell. two or three times a night to talk to you? You should have seen Mr Carlyles stare of astonishment and horror, when I told him you had that practice!

Who is Miss Murray?Unidentified. A Miss Murray whom that Eternal Tait met with Mr Comb,George Combe (1778–1858; ODNB), phrenologist, whom Tait had shown round the 1858 Royal Academy exhibition; see 33:254–56JWC to TC, [27 June 1858]. said she had been staying with you just after I had been there.

My kindest regards to the Doctor. Did I tell you I had put RippThe photograph of Ripp, the Russells’ dog, sent in 1858 after JWC’s visit; see 34:246JWC to MR, [ca. 25 Nov. 1858]. in a little frame and hung him in my dressing room?— When Mr C first noticed it he said “May I ask, my Dear, who is the interesting quadruped you have been at the pains to frame there?”
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [10 or 17 Feb.?]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd. Conjecturally dated soon after JWC to MCA, [7 Feb.?], when JWC had announced the second batch of broken eggs.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: Oh thank you! thank you, Dear! Never was a petition more swiftly complied with.As JWC to MCA, [7 Feb.?], was written on a Mon., JWC would indeed have been impressed at Mary Austin’s managing to get the eggs sent to arrive by Wed. evening, 9 Feb., although if she had sent the eggs the same day the letter arrived, it would have been just possible. Otherwise, we should infer that this letter was written the following Thurs., 17 Feb. The eggs actually arrived last night! A complete success this time! for there was not a si[n]gle egg broken, or so much as cracked!

I paid only eight pence for the box—is it possible it could have come all that wayFrom Dumfries. for eight pence, or was that only the carriage from the StationPresumably Euston, about 4 mi. from Cheyne Row; eight pence was the porterage fee for 1–1½ mi. here! and you pre-paying the carriage to London in spite of my prohibition—? Tell me!—that I may understand for future times. You cannot understand—yes you perhaps can—the serious nature of the worry this Box of eggs has rescued me out of! and will deliver me from for a fortnight to come.
By then, there will perhaps be fresh eggs procurable here—or at all events I may get some more from you.

This isn’t the letter yet that I am to write you— But I am obliged to go early to town on that horrible business of servant-huntingCharlotte Southam was at Cheyne Row until Aug. 1860, but JWC occasionally went servant hunting for friends.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF [JFO], 11 Feb. Addr: (Marischal College) / Kingsland House / Aberdeen. PM: 12 Feb. 1859. MS: facsimile, Cassell’s Weekly, 17 Oct. 1923, 125. Pbd: Times, 25 Feb. 1859; Rectorial Addresses Delivered in the Universities of Aberdeen, 1835–1900 362, ed. Peter John Anderson (Aberdeen, 1902); Glasgow Herald, 6 Oct. 1923. John Forbes (1838–1904), b. Aberdeen; educ. Marischal Coll., Aberdeen, he entered Lincoln’s Inn 1860 and was called to the English Bar 1862; he worked on the Northern and the North-East Circuits (both of England); Q. C. 1881; attorney general 1887–1901; royal commissioner of assize 1896 and 1902. He m., 1866, Maria Elizabeth, b. Thomas, youngest da. of Henry Thomas, Esq., of Sheffield.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORBES

docBody.p: I am much obliged to you & to your young friends in Marischal CollegeMarischal Coll. was founded in 1593 as a Protestant university alongside the pre-Reformation King’s Coll., founded 1495. The two colleges were combined to form the University of Aberdeen, Sept. 1860. but there are two reasons why, as appears to me, you ought not to proceed with your Nomination. The first is, That you have no good likelihood, so far as I can guess, of carrying your election.TC had also been proposed for rector of Marischal Coll. in 1850, but John Thomson Gordon (1818–65) was elected; see 25:31TC to TAH, 22 Feb. 1850, and 38TC to JAC, 5 March 1850. This is a very important preliminary reason!—The second is, That, being extremely busy in these months, and otherwise averse to travel, and in truth an enemy rather than a friend to Public Haranguing, as at present practiced,—I do not think it likely I could get to Aberdeen on such an errand, even if you were unexpectedly successful.

Pray desist, therefore. To me the honour is without importance at this stage of my lifeIn 1866 he consented to stand for rector of Edinburgh Univ. and defeated Benjamin Disraeli by 657 votes to 310.—and in fact has no value at all, except as testifying your regard to me, of which I can now otherwise hold myself assured. And to you have not I already ‘spoken,’—to such of you as cared to listen,—and, with a great deal of deliberation, given you the truest advice I had!—

Accept many thanks from me; and believe, all of you, voters for and voters against, that nobody, elected or eligible,David Graham Drummond, 7th earl of Airlie, husband of JWC’s friend Blanche, became rector of Marischal Coll., 1859. can wish you more truly than I do, continual increase of intelligence and of all the nobleness that should go along with it. And so, with sincere regards and thanks, I remain / Yours faithfully, / T Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 11 Feb. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 11 Feb. 1859. MS: NLS 552.185. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
There is a patch of Memorandum which I enclose you, for another Letter to Magnus.Eduard Magnus; see TC to JN, 7 Jan. It will be safer if he send us a Specimen of his man’s way of working, when he has settled on a man.Neuberg had sent, 7 Feb., an abstract of a letter from Magnus, reporting that Albert Teichel (b. 1822) would be willing to do the engravings for Frederick, £30 an engraving. He had also spoken to Johann August Eduard Mandel (1810–82), “an engraver of some celebrity,” who was willing to supervise a pupil but who would be twice as expensive as Teichel. Magnus was continuing his inquiries.— The Portrait Prints (Borck, Finck Puttkammer, Saldern, Seidlitz, Wobersnow, Schmettau, Wedel, Gessler &c &c)Field Marshal Adrian Heinrich Graf von Borcke (1715–88). Gen. Friedrich August Finck (1718–66). Lt. Gen. Georg Ludwig von Puttkamer (1715–59). Gen. Adj. Friedrich Christoph von Saldern (1719–86). Gen. Friedrich Wilhelm von Seydlitz (1721–73). Maj. Gen. Moritz Franz Kasimir von Wobersnow (1708–59). Probably Lt. Gen. Karl Christoph Graf von Schmettau (1696–1775), “Schmettau junior,” or possibly his brother, “Schmettau senior,” Field Marshal Samuel Graf von Schmettau (1684–1751), of whom a portrait is listed in Carlyle’s House 108. (“Schmettau junior” is wrongly identified as their nephew, Friedrich Wilhelm Karl, Count von Schmettau [1742–1806], at 28:28.) Either Lt. Gen. Karl Heinrich von Wedell (1712–82), war minister, or his brother Lt. Col. Georg von Wedell (1710–45). Maj. Gen. Friedrich Leopold Graf von Gessler (1688–1762). For further discussion of the portraits, see TC to JN, 25 April.—almost any Prints, provided they were genuine Likenesses*;Neuberg replied, 28 Feb., that Magnus was looking for portraits of generals and enclosed a list of works by Adolf von Menzel (1815–1905), whose work Magnus recommended. for I really know almost nobody but Ziethen,Hans Joachim von Zieten (1699–1786), Prussian cavalry general.—wd do me marked service perhaps, if I once had them! Chodowiecki’s two Prints (old Frh reviewing on horseback, and Frh setting a chair for Ziethen),Daniel Nikolaus Chodowiecki (1726–1801), German artist. Chodowiecki’s print from his painting of Frederick reviewing the troops is listed with TC’s comment “Friedrich on Parade; very good” in Carlyle’s House 107; see 32above. The portrait of Ziethen sitting in front of the king is also listed in Carlyle’s House 104. these and the absurd Pauli (Leben Grosser &c)Karl Friedrich Pauli, Leben grosser Helden des gegenwärtigen Krieges, 3 vols. (Halle, 1759–64), which contained portraits. TC’s copy: HCC. are literally my whole stock at present. Press that, so far as polite.
D. N. Chodowiecki, “Friedrich on Parade”
Courtesy of The National Trust

And the Gotto Paper;Parkins & Gotto, stationers, 24–25 Oxford St.—alas, alas, neither of those Specimens will in the least do! The white is sound strong paper, but it is shy of the ink,—a quite intolerable quality. Do do the blue, tho’ in a less degree: neither of these must
we venture on. I beg you to make a farther hunt therefore. I will send Larkin too,—and surely we shall turn up something. It is on you I depend chiefly

closer.salute: Adieu; come on Sunday Evg & report progress

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: *worse than nothing almost, if not so? No, not worse

div3.sourceNote: JWC-DD, 14 Feb. Pbd: Davidson, Memories 313–16; A. Carlyle, NLM 2:204–6 inc. Quot: Wilson 5:333; Hansons, NE 462.
div3.head: JWC TO DAVID DAVIDSON

docBody.p:
My dear Friend,—It is not to you that I should write this evening, if I were animated by a due sense of “the duty nearest hand!”Coterie speech; see 6:122TC to JAC, 16 Feb. 1832, and Carlyle, Sartor 145. Putting aside all questions about a cap to be “done up” (alas that England should expectCoterie speech; see 33:13TC to JWC, 7 Aug. 1858. of one to wear caps at “a certain age” for all that one’s hair don’t turn grey!) and all questions about three pair of socks in my workbasket in immediate need of
darning; then Katie Macready in breathless expectation of a letter from me to tell her “what I think” of a bulky MS.,Probably the MS of Catherine Macready’s poems, which were published as Leaves from the Olive Mount (1860). She called JWC’s (untraced) letter “so delightful, and wise, and indulgent and tender,” adding: “You are very good to be interested in anything that I have done, or may do. … I wish I could think I should soon become a ‘model housekeeper,’—a ‘model anything’ as you so kindly wish I may be but—it does not look much like it at present” ([20 Feb.]). Her father, W. C. Macready, also wrote to JWC, 20 Feb., finally acknowledging a letter she had apparently written him in Nov. 1858. He had written inviting her to visit Sherborne, his home in Dorset, after her stay at Bay House, but she had gone to Scotland instead; see 34:107JWC to MR, 8 Aug. [1858]. His sister Letitia d. 8 Nov. 1858, the night after JWC’s letter arrived: “Your last account—and what a delightfully amusing one!—of your wanderings.” He had “just seen [her] second letter to Katie … its words of affectionate wisdom.” on which after the fashion of young ladies of the present day, she has been employing her leisure, instead of on a sampler; and there is Miss Anderton (a young actress and a good girl as can be) expecting “a few lines” about a sensible little “article” of hers, entitled “Thoughts on Actresses,”Sarah Anderton, “A Few Words about Actresses and the Profession of the Stage,” English Woman’s Journal 2.12 (1 Feb.): 385–98; dismissing the stereotypes of actresses as immoral and hedonistic, she wrote that many actresses were “irreproachable women and patient workers. … [W]e desire others … to strip away from their idea of the actress … both the soiled drapings of vice and the glittering but worthless stage tinsel that may very possibly hang about it” (387). Actresses must be “unceasingly industrious”; they also have a “larger experience of life,” from grappling “with real, hard facts,” than those women “absorbed by the petty vanities and trifles and anxieties of a woman’s ordinary life” (396–97). in the Englishwomen’s Journal,English Woman’s Journal, a Victorian feminist periodical, pbd. March 1858–Aug. 1864 by the Langham Place circle (a group of women activists) and printed by Emily Faithfull (1835–95; ODNB) and the Victoria Press. The journal included articles on women’s legal rights, employment, education, and personal development, as well as reviews of women’s writing. By November 1859 it had a regular circulation of 700 copies. which she sent me yesterday. (What a mercy you were married a good many years ago! You could hardly have succeeded in finding a wife now who had not published a Book or contributed to a Journal, or at least had a manuscript in progress!) And there is an unknown Entity, who is pleased to pass by the name of George Eliot, to whom I have owed acknowledgment a week back for the present of herWhen JWC acknowledged Scenes of Clerical Life (1858), she assumed George Eliot was a man; see 33:164JWC to GEL, 21 Jan. 1858. It is possible that JWC knew that Eliot was a woman by now, as the Carlyles were friendly with George Henry Lewes. Here JWC mentions Eliot in the context of women writers, yet, in JWC to GEGEL, 20 Feb., she addresses Eliot throughout as a man, although this could have been out of politeness or playfulness. Davidson may have substituted “her” for “him” when he pbd. the letter in 1890. Both Alexander Carlyle (NLM 2:205) and William Allingham (1824–89; ODNB) wrote that TC had come to the conclusion that Adam Bede was written by a woman from the description of the making of a paneled door in the first two pages: “she supposed that in making a door, you last of all put in the panels” (Allingham, [1880]; MS: NLS 3823.143). new
novel Adam Bede,Adam Bede (1859), although clearly available earlier, was advertised as “this day published,” 19 Feb., in the Athenaeum, which also reviewed it enthusiastically, 26 Feb. a really charming book, which novel tho’ it be I advise you to read—and engage that you will not think the time misspent—under penalty of reading the dreariest book of sermons you like to impose on me if you do! All that I don’t feel equal to breaking ground on to-night. My pen positively would not begin with anything to-night but “My dear Friend.” Besides I don’t want you to be thinking me quite a Brute! insensible to your kindness in writing me such nice long letters—deaf to the echoes of dear long ago, that sound through them. That little picture of your visit to Grant’s Braes!Grant’s Braes, nr. Haddington (see 3:364–66TC to JJ, [4 Aug. 1825]), home of Gilbert Burns (1760–1827), Robert Burns’s younger brother, and Jean Burns, b. Breckenridge (1764–1841), old friends of the Welshes, JWC’s parents; see 3:73TC to JJ, [29 May 1824]. how pretty, how dream-like! awaking so many recollections of my own young visiting there—the dinners of rice and milk with currants—a very few currants—kind, thrifty Mrs. Gilbert Burns used to give me, with such a welcome! of play-fellows, boys and girls—all I fancy dead now—who made my Saturdays at Grant’s Braes white days for me! I went to see the dear old house, when I was last at Sunny Bank,The old name, which JWC persisted in using, for Tenterfield, the Donaldson sisters’ home in Haddington; see 33:89JWC to WDO, [19? Sept. 1857]. and found the new prosaic farm house in its stead, and it was as if my heart had knocked up against it! a sort of (moral) blow in the breast is what I feel always at these sudden revelations of the new strange uncared for thing usurping the place of the thing one knew as well as oneself, and had all sorts of associations with, and had hung the fondest memories on! When I first saw Mrs. Somerville (of mathematical celebrity)Mary Somerville (1780–1872;ODNB), scientific writer; JWC had met her in 1824; see 7:252JWC to EA, [ca. Aug. 1834], and 334TC to MAC, 20 Nov. 1834. I was much struck with her exact likeness to Mrs. G. Burns—minus the geniality—and plus the feathers in her head! and I remember remarking to my husband, that after all Mrs. Burns was far the cleverer woman of the two, in as much as to bring up twelve children,Jean Burns had 11 children of her own: William (b. 1792), James (b. 1794), Thomas (b. 1796), Robert (b. 1797), Janet (b. 1799), Agnes (b. 1800), John (b. 1802), Gilbert (b. 1804), Ann (b. 1805), Jean (b. 1807), and Isabella (b. 1809). Elizabeth Burns (1785–1815), Robert Burns’s illegitimate da. by Elizabeth Paton, also lived with them; she was his “dear-bought Bess” (Burns, “The Inventory” 54). as these young Burns were brought up, and keep up such a comfortable house as Grant’s Braes, all on eighty pounds a year, was a much more intricate problem than the Reconcilement of the Physical Sciences! and Mr. C. cordially agreed with me. I am glad, however, the Centenary is over! for Mr. C. was pestered out of his wits with letters from “all the braying Jackasses in in Creation”
about it.The Robert Burns centenary celebrations were on 25 Jan. For TC’s invitations to join the celebrations, see TC to Lord ALOA, 30 Jan., and vol. 34. If he had cut himself up into square inches he could not have been present at all the “occasions” where he was summoned. He (Mr. C.) is as busy as ever tearing away at his new volumes. Meanwhile I am spending my life with the two Royal Children (of his title page)Antoine Pesne (1683–1757), The Little Drummer; frontispiece of vol. 1 of the first edn. of Frederick, engraved by Francis Holl “from a copy in Lord Ashburton’s possession”; see Works 12:370 and CL 34:75–76TC to LOA, 27 [26] July 1858. as large as life! Lord Ashburton having made me a present of the Picture from which the engraving was made.For Lord Ashburton’s gift of his copy, see 34:240TC to JCA, 13 Nov. 1858. It quite makes the fortune of my drawing-room. For one thing, it serves the end our pretty little ShandyJWC’s family dog; see 2:272JBW to TC, [18 Jan. 1823]. Davidson recalled: “I happen to possess the only portrait, as far as I know, of the dog ‘Shandy’ mentioned in this letter.” The dog had been included in a portrait of his two younger brothers, and “as it was the only good bit in the production, I cut it out, and preserved it for Jeanie’s sake” (Davidson, Memories 316). used to serve at Haddington, and is something for the stupid callers to chatter about. A very interesting letter came to-day to Mr. C. from Captain Pelly,Lewis Pelly (1825–92; ODNB), officer in the Indian Army, whom the Carlyles had known for several years; see 33:191–92TC to LP, 20 [19] March 1858. His letter was dated 26 Dec. 1858 (MS: NLS 1767.196). the intimate friend of Colonel Jacob,Brig. Gen. John Jacob (1812–58; ODNB), officer in the Indian Army; commander of the cavalry division of the Indian Army in the Persian War, 1857–58, he had returned to India in Oct. 1857 to resume his position as political superintendent and commandant of the frontier of Upper Scinde (Sind). He had written controversial books and pamphlets on military organization, equipment, and training in India and had also designed a new kind of rifle and explosive bullet. Pelly had written to TC from the NW Frontier, [1?] Jan. 1858, saying he was sending him a copy of The Views and Opinions of Brigadier-General John Jacob, C.B., collected and ed. Captain Lewis Pelly (Bombay, 1858) (see 33:191, where it is wrongly identified as the 2d edn.). He asked TC to read it and whether he agreed that “a man has been silently, effectually, and amid unusual opposition working out principles which you regard as eternal and alone worthy of the notice of good men”; he ended, “it would afford me gratification to receive from you a word to such effect” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). Pelly used a quotation by TC, presumably taken from his reply, as one of two epigraphs in the 2d edn. (1858): “Here is an earnest, truth-speaking; no theorizer, sentimentalizer, but a practical man of work and endeavour, man of sufferance and endurance. The thing that he speaks is not a hearsay, but a thing that he has himself known, and by experience become assured of. * * * [asterisks in printed text] His grand excellency is this, that he is genuine. As his primary faculty, the foundation of all others, is Intellect, depth and force of Vision; so his primary virtue is Justice, the Courage to be just. * * * [asterisks in printed text] He lives, as he counsels and commands, not commodiously in the Reputable, the Plausible, the Half, but resolutely in the Whole, the Good, the True” (TC to LP, [early 1858]; pbd.: The Views and Opinions of Brigadier-General John Jacob, C.B. [1858] [iii]). who got back to India just in time to be with him at his death. He himself, Jacob, called his illness “complete loss of vital power,
with inability to sleep.” For seven nights he had never closed his eye, yet was making himself go on and do work all the same. He said to Pelly the day before his last, affectionately pressing his hand, “I am passing away, and am glad of it.”Col. Jacob died of “brain fever,” midnight, 5–6 Dec. 1858, refusing medical attention, while doing a tour of inspection in Jacobabad, NW India, which had been named in recognition of his services. All that day he said his face was superhumanly beautiful. What a long time it is since you were in London!He had been in London, late 1855, returning to Scotland at the end of Jan. 1856; see Davidson, Memories 299–301. JWC had seen him in Edinburgh in Aug. 1857; see 33:42JWC to TC, [20 Aug. 1857], and 52–53JWC to TC, [26 Aug. 1857]. Are you not ashamed of yourself for being able to sit still in this restless age? I have been very anxious these many weeks about my dear old Miss Donaldson.Jean Donaldson. Davidson regretted that JWC was “singularly reticent on the subject of religion,” although pleased that “some of her dearest friends” were “decidedly serious people”; among her friends were the Donaldson sisters, Thomas Erskine, and “the faithful and godly Betty Braid.” In his last letter to JWC, he reports that he wrote that he was “often filled with anxious thought as to what assurance I should have, if she were taken before me, that we should meet again in the happy land” (Davidson, Memories 317). She has been living or rather holding on to life, beyond all expectation of those about her. Her mind is as clear and her heart as warm as ever, but her physical life is going out slowly slowly, amidst nervous suffering sad to think of in one so old, and so patient. I have not had a cold since November, and can drive out in good days, a great improvement on last year. Kind regards to your wife.– Affectionately yours,

p.name: Jane Carlyle.
p.note: Davidson recorded after this letter that he had “preserved no more of Mrs. Carlyle’s letters”; he then wrote of his own memory of JWC: “In fact, it is the Jeanie Welsh of the first half of my long life, when my memory dwelt, like hers, tenderly and lovingly on the past; and I cling to it still, rather than her appearance in later years. I see her now, her raven locks and dark liquid eyes contrasting with her fair complexion; and features which, if not quite regular, yet flashed with bright intelligence, softened in tender sympathy, or sparkled with the choicest fun” (Davidson, Memories 316).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GE [GEL], 20 Feb. MS: Yale. Pbd: The George Eliot Letters, ed. Gordon S. Haight (New Haven, 1954) 3:17–19; Gordon S. Haight, George Eliot: A Biography (Oxford, 1968) 274–75 inc; Fielding and Sorensen 238–40 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO GEORGE ELIOT

docBody.p: I must again offer you my heartiest thanks. Since I received your Scenes of Clerical LifeScenes had been sent to JWC, Jan. 1858; see 33:164JWC to GEL, 21 Jan. 1858. nothing has fallen from the skies to me so welcome as Adam Bede, all to myself,Coterie speech; see 34:233JWC to MR, [30 Oct. 1858]. “from the Author.”

My Husband had just read an advertisement of it aloud to me,JWC had been sent Adam Bede about 7 Feb.; see JWC to DD, 14 Feb.; advert. not traced. adding; “Scenes of Clerical Life? That was your Book wasn’t it?” (The ‘your’ being in the sense not of possession but of prediliction) “Yes,” I had said, “and I am so glad that he has written another! Will he send me this one, I wonder?“—thereby bringing on myself an utterly disregarded admonition about “the tendency of the Female Mind to run into unreasonable expectations” when up rattled the Parcel Delivery cart, and, a startling double-rap having transacted itself, a Book-parcel was brought me. “There it is!” I said, with a little air of injured innocence triumphant!—“There is what, my Dear?“—“Why, Adam Bede to be sure”!—“How do you know?” (I had not yet opened the parcel) “By divination.“—“Oh!—Well!—I hope you also divine that Adam Bede will justify your enthusiasm now you have got it”!—“As to that” (snappishly) “I needn’t have recourse to divination, only to natural logic!“—— Now; if it had turned out not Adam Bede after all; where was my “diminished head”See Milton, Paradise Lost 4.35. going to have hidden itself?— But Fortune favours the Brave!See Terence, Phormio 1.203. I had foretold aright, on both points! The Book was actually Adam Bede, and Adam Bede “justified my enthusiasm”; to say the least!

Oh yes! It was as good as going into the country for one’s health, the reading of that Book was!— Like a visit to Scotland minus the fatigues of the long journey and the grief of seeing friends grown old, and Places that knew me knowing me no more! I could fancy, in reading it, to be seeing and hearing once again a crystal-clear, musical, scotch stream, such as I long to lie down beside and— cry at (!) for gladness and sadness; after long stifling Sojourn in the South; where there no water but what is stagnant or muddy!—

In truth, it is a beautiful most human Book! Every Dog in it, not to say every man woman and child in it, is brought home to one’s ‘business and bosom,’Cf. Francis Bacon, The Essayes or Counsels, Civill and Morall, of Francis Lo. Verulam, Viscount St. Alban (1625), dedication. an individual fellow-creature! I found myself in charity with the whole human race when I laid it down—the canine race I had always appreciated—“not wisely but too well!”See Othello 5.2.—the human, however,— Ach!—that has troubled me—as badly at times as “twenty gallons of milk on one’s mind”!See Adam Bede chap. 32. For the rest; why you are so good to me is still a mystery, with every appearance of remaining so! Yet have I lavished more childish conjecture on it than on anything since I was a child, and got mistified about—a door (!) in our dining-room. What did that door open into? Why had I never seen it opened? Standing before it, “as in presence of The Infinite,”Coterie speech; see 33:74JWC to TC, [6 Sept. 1857]. I pictured to myself glorious possibilities on the other side, and also horrible ones! I spun long romances about it in my little absurd head! I never told how that door had taken hold of me, for I “thought shame”;Coterie speech; see 30:220JWC’s Journal, 21 Nov. 1855. it was a curiosity too sacred for speech! But I lay in wait to catch it open some day; and then I somehow—forgot all about it!—till long after (a year or so) that the recollection of my door-worship occurred to me “quite promiscuously,”Coterie speech; source unknown; for an early use, see 10:72TCJWC to JCA, 1 May 1838. and in the same instant, the whole fact as to the door smote me, like a slap on the face! It was a door into—nothing! Make-believe! There for uniformity! Behind it was bare lath and plaster; behind that the Drawing-room with its familiar tables and chairs! Dispelled illusion no. 1! and epitome “of much!” (as Mr Carlyle might say)

Perhaps could I penetrate my little mystery of the present date; I should arrive at the same sort of lath-and-plaster results! And so— I give it up; just “taking,” gratefully and gladly, “the good the Gods (under the name of George Elliot) have provided me.”Cf. Dryden, “Alexander’s Feast” 106; see also 27:179JWC to TC, [23–24 July 1852].

Now, Heaven knows if such a long letter to read be not illustrating for you also “the tendency of the female mind to run into unreasonable expectations”! But just consider! Is it possible that, with my opportunities, I should not know perfectly well, what a “distinguish-Author” does with letters of compliment that bore him; either by their length or their stupidity? He, lights his pipe with them, or he makes them into spills; or he crushes them into a ball, and pitches them in the fire or waste-paper basket; does anything
with them except read them! So I needn’t take fright about having bored you; Since, long before it came to that, I should have, or shall have been slit up into spills, or done good service in lighting your pipe!Eliot wrote to John Blackwood, 24 Feb., enclosing JWC’s letter: “I want the philosopher himself to read it because the pre-philosophic period … lay among the furrowed fields and pious peasantry. If he could be urged to read a novel! I should like, if possible, to give him the same sort of pleasure he has given me in the early chapters of Sartor, where he describes little Diogenes eating his porridge on the wall in sight of the sunset, and gaining deep wisdom from the contemplation of the pigs and other ‘higher animals’ of Entepfuhl.” However, she had found the first two vols. of Frederick “a painful book … in many respects.” Eliot asked Blackwood to reply to JWC: “Will you tell her that the sort of effect she declares herself to have felt from ‘Adam Bede’ is just what I desire to produce—gentle thoughts and happy remembrances; and I thank her heartily for telling me so warmly and generously what she has felt” (The George Eliot Letters 3:23–24). Anne Thackeray wrote in her journal, 21 March: “[Mrs. Carlyle] has written some of her enthusiasm off to George Eliot and had grateful messages in reply. Mr. Carlyle quite declines reading the book” (Letters of Anne Thackeray Ritchie, ed. Hester Ritchie [1924] 110). It is lawful for Clergymen to smoke, I hope,—for their own sakes? The newspaper critics have decided you are a Clergyman, but I don’t believe it the least in the world.By early July, an anon. writer was impatient with the mystery of the authorship (2 July, Athenaeum 20). By late July the identity of George Eliot was generally known, although clearly some people knew earlier; see TC to JF, 10 July. A notice in the Scotsman, 10 Aug., read: “The great ‘Adam Bede’ secret is at length thought to be discovered, and the author is … simply a Miss Mary Ann Evans, already known in this strong-minded generation as the translator of Strauss’s ‘Life of Jesus.’” You understand the duties and uses of a Clergyman too well, for being one! An old Lord, who did not know my Husband, came up to him once at a Public meeting where he had been summoned to give his “views” (not having any) on the “Distressed Needle Women,”“The Society for the Protection and Employment of the Distressed Needlewomen of London” was formed Jan. 1844. TC’s attendance at a public meeting is untraced, although he did attend a public meeting for the founding of the Society for the Improvemement of the Labouring Classes, 12 May 1844; see 18:42TC to MAC, 13 May 1844. For TC’s views on “distressed needlewomen,” see Works 20:27–28. and asked; “pray Sir, may I inquire, are you a Stock-Broker?“—“A Stock-Broker! certainly not!“—“Humph! Well I thought you must be a Stock-Broker; because, Sir, you go to the root of the matter.“— If that be the signal of a Stock-Broker I should say you must certainly be a Stock Broker, and must certainly not be a Clergyman!

closer.salute: Respectfully and affectionately yours, whatever you be

docBody.name: Jane W. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CB [CBU], 24 Feb. MS: EUL. Quot: Southern 265–66.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES BUTLER

docBody.p: You are Punctuality itself, and always reappear when the Almanack demands you! I received your Note of the 8th last, with the inclosed Cash,The interest on TC’s American investments; both payments in 1858 were £14; see 265TC to CBU, 9 June 1858, and 34:199TC to CBU, 23 Sept. 1858. which the Banker has now got hold of: that is all right; and I have only to return you many thanks as usual,—the poor but sole return in my power as matters stand.

On the other hand I perceive you have never got my last Letter,TC had written 23 Sept. 1858; see 34:198—99TC to CBU, 23 Sept. 1858. written 5 or 6 months ago (end of Septr, I should guess)? I posted it myself; and long ago, as no answer came to the inquiries there made, I began to fancy something had misgone; which, by your silence on the matter this time too, I perceive is the case. Two Books also you should have had a while ago, the end of my Collected WorksVols. 15 and 16. (I know not whether 1 vol or how many still wanting to you); and the Book on Friedrich (two big red volumes)The vols. of Frederick had not arrived by April; see TC to CBCBU, 8 April. Vol. 1 of the second printing (which included some corrections), inscribed “To Charles Butler, Esq etc etc, Wall Street, New York: With many kind regards: T. Carlyle. Chelsea, 6 Decr, 1858,” is in the Elmer Holmes Bobst Lib., New York Univ. whh I had just been publishing. I wrote instantly to my Bookseller here,Chapman & Hall. and have waited two days for the fruit of his investigation: No blame of his, it appears; only some loitering on the part of his agent;Unidentified.—for the rest he confidently computes the Books are now safe in yr hands. If so, we will forgive him. But please examine whether it is so;—and if in any respect it is not, let me know immediately.

The lost Letter treated of some money I meant for the American Funds under your guidance,—of whh there was long ago talk between us. £1,000 I had, and then another £1,000:—not hearing from you, I fancied you really might be at a loss to point out any absolutely good investment, or to risk an advice; I therefore proceeded to invest those two sums in English stock: “Brighton-Railway Debentures”TC had invested £4,000 in Brighton Debentures, 12 Nov. 1858 (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). they call one of them; some other similar thing the other: and there my peculiar [savings] lie, absolutely safe I am told,
but yielding only 4 per cent, tho’ perhaps I expected about 5.—— Well, if I missed any better American chance by that Post-Office accident, there still remains another £1,000, whh you may yet advise about if you like! Speak if there is anything deliberately eligible in your judgement; I will take yr Judgt as conclusive, if you be good to speak. Exorbitant interest is not at all what I seek or wish; but the absence of risk,—or necessity to think farther of the matter,— is very desirable.TC had written: “greedy of gain I am not; greedy of security and absence of bother I am”; see 34:199TC to CBU, 23 Sept. 1858. Perhaps you cd put it and the already existing thing together in some way,—so that a London BankerProbably Smith, Payne & Smiths, Lombard St.; the British Linen Co. Bank, TC’s bank in Dumfries, were agents for them. (or even a Scotch one in correspondence with Ln, whom I shd prefer) cd take possessn of the Papers, and manage the whole matter, witht ever speaking to me again abt it, except by the sending of his Half-Yearly receipts so long as they endured? That wd be the pleasant method. Do whatever your clear insight and friendly mind shall prompt on the matter.— I am still crushed down with the ugliest endless labour, in fact quite “killed” and broken hearted;—and so it must continue for many long months, if I can survive it all! No moment is my own. I, in great haste, say Farewell. Yours ever Truly,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF [EFO], [24 Feb.]. Addr: 46 Montague Square / W. PM: London, 25 Feb. 1859. MS: NLS 1797.15. Hitherto unpbd. Thurs. was the 24th.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.p: the Brougham will not be at my door “on Monday next.” We shall make a new appointment when you are quite well again but not sooner! Don’t I know the horror of living in terror, that when the day comes for aThus in MS. an appointment to take effect, I shall have to go thro with it however sleepless I may have been the night before however sick I may be at the moment!— That sort of dreads are enough to retard ones recovery.

You must have been doing “those things you ought not to have done,Cf. the General Confession, Book of Common Prayer. exhausting yourself on young sightseers &c &c, or you couldnt have gone and caught cold in this lovely weather.

I will call and ask for you one day next week—and will come another day to
Luncheon, when I have seen with my own eyes, (more understanding in such cases than a man’s never to say a Husbands!) that you are up to it

closer.salute: Yours in haste, and ink blots—but affectionately

docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: If Mr Forster would take a grain of care of himself!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [24? Feb.]. MS: NLS 552.187. Hitherto unpbd. Dated shortly before TC to JN, [25 Feb.], when TC has ordered the “Larkin kind” of paper.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Here is yr good Abstract of Kaiser Karl’s DeathKaiser Karl VI (1685–1740), father of the empress Maria Theresa and architect of the Pragmatic Sanction; see Works 14:388—89. sent back for bestimmung [definition] in one small point whh unluckily has become critical to me. In the Patch stuck to bottom of p. 3 you will find what the infinitely small point is: pray look, and make it indubitable for me.

Another little Patch (abt Truchsess [commandant] and fire in Spandau)Unexplained. will be useful, if you will put the date beyond question.— Needn’t copy anything; Larkin will do it so far as needful. I have Mill’s LibertyJohn Stuart Mill, On Liberty (1859); see TC to JAC, 4 May. Mill dedicated it to his wife, Harriet Mill, who had d. 4 Nov. 1858 in Avignon. He wrote that she was the inspiration and part author of “all that is best in my writings” and that her “exalted sense of truth and right” was his “strongest incitement” (J. M. Robson, ed., Collected Works of John Stuart Mill [Toronto, 1977] 18:216). Mill designed her tomb in Avignon and was buried there himself in 1873; for his epitaph to Harriet Mill, see opp.above ready for you; whh is a strange proof of what a Thinking Englishman amounts to at present!— [paper cut away]
J. S. Mill’s epitaph to Harriet Mill on the Mill tomb, Avignon
Courtesy of Sheila McIntosh
[Thi]s is the Larkin specimen of paper from [Parkins] & Gotto. It does very well; and I will [orde]r a ream ohne weiteres [without more ado].

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [25 Feb.]. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 25 Feb. 1859. MS: NLS 552.186. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Do not fail us on Sunday Evg: I expect Alan Ker (if you know him, Scott’s Nephew),A. J. Scott was m. to Ker’s aunt Ann. who will tell us something abt the West Indies,Alan Ker was chief justice of Dominica. if we like. Paper (Larkin’s kind preferred) is sent for.
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-T [THE], 25 Feb. Addr: Therapeutes, / Messrs. Sutherland and Knox, / Booksellers, Edinburgh. Pbd: British Medical Journal, 30 Nov. 1912, 1569–70; Wilson, Carlyle 5:334–35 inc. Therapeutes was the pen name of David Brodie, M.D.; Sutherland & Knox, publishers and booksellers, 60 S. Bridge, Edinburgh. According to the BMJ 2:1569, the letter was read by “Dr. Yeats … to the members of the annual meeting at Bristol in 1894 who were present at an excursion to Tintern Abbey”; this was on 4 Aug. 1894 during the 62d annual meeting of the British Medical Association.
div3.head: TC TO “THERAPEUTES”

docBody.p: Dear Sir—I have received your bookThe Healing Art, the Right Hand of the Church, or Practical Medicine an Essential Element in the Christian System (Edinburgh, 1859), pbd. by Sutherland & Knox. Brodie’s aim was to “ascertain what data are furnished by Scripture to warrant the recognition of scientific and practical Medicine as an essential element in the Christian system, an indispensable agency in the activity which the Church is called on to sustain in the world” (8). which you were kind enough to send me, and I beg to return you thanks for the same. It is a book (unlike many that come to me here) of a serious nature, the fruit of long study, meditation, inquiry, and evidently of perfect conviction on your part.

I believe, and have long believed, the essential idea it sets forth to be not only true, but of the very highest importance to mankind, namely, that the Physican must first of all be a priest (that is to say, a man of pious nobleness, devoted to the service of the Highest, and prepared to endure and endeavour for that same, taking no counsel of flesh, and blood, as the theory of Priests is),—first of all, a real priest, and thanPresumably a misprint for “then.” that the whole world should take supreme counsel of him, as it does of its real or imaginary Priests or Pontiffs this long while back, and follow said counsel as the actual will of God,—which it would be were the Physician what I say.

It is curious to remark that Heilig in our old Teutonic speech is both Holy and also Healthy; that the words Holy and Healthy, as our antique fathers understood them, are one and the same. A thousand times has that etymology risen sorrowfully upon me, in looking at the present distracted position of affairs, which is horrible to think of, if we look earnestly into it, and which cannot well be spoken of at all. We, sure enough, have completely contrived to divorce holiness (as we call it) from health, and have been reaping the fruits very plentifully during these fifteen hundred years.

The notion of bringing our present distracted anomaly of a Physician into union with our ditto ditto of a Priest, and making them identical, is, of course, extremely chimerical; nor can one easily say what ought to be the first step towards bringing each of them back from his anomalous imaginary condition and nearer to veracity, and the possibility of coalescing. But I am very glad to see the idea started, in any form, under any vesture, and heartily wish you success in bringing it home to men’s minds.
docBody.name: T. CARLYLE.

ps.p:
To Therapeutes,
Messrs. Sutherland and Knox,
Booksellers, Edinburgh.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 28 Feb. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 28 Feb. 1859. MS: NLS 552.188. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I am shoving rubbish aside. Here is a kind of Index to Fassn knocking about; I think you have Fassmann;David Fassmann (1683–1744), German historian. TC may be referring to either Des glorwürdigsten Fürsten und Herrn, Friedrich Augusti des Grossen, Leben und Helden-Thaten, so letzthin in historischer Ordnung beschrieben von D. F. Nunmehro erläutert durch J. G. H. (Frankfurt, 1734) or Leben und Thaten des Königs von Preussen, Friederici Wilhelmi (Hamburg, 1735); TC’s copies: HCC. please stick this in, with a crumb of wafer, it will at least be out of the way.

The other Patch is about Seyfart;Johann Friedrich Seyfart, Lebens- und Regierungs-Geschichte Friedrichs des andern Königs in Preussen (Leipzig, 1784–88). “A work of immense research; wd have been invaluable as a Dictionary; but in its present state, as a ‘Book,’ shot together into blind masses, witht even an Index, is very surprising!” (TC’s copy: HCC). was intended, I suppose, for Wm’s & NorgateWilliams & Norgate, booksellers, 14 Henrietta St., Covent Garden; see 32:138TC to JN, 1 May 1857. 3 months ago: but as they have made so little of AdelungJohann Christoph Adelung, Pragmatische Staatsgeschichte Europens von dem Ableben Kaiser Carls 6 an bis auf die gegenwärtigen Zeiten, 9 vols. (Gotha, 1762–67). TC had asked Neuberg to look into buying a copy in Oct. 1858; see 34:230TC to JN, 28 Oct. 1858. TC received vols. 1–8 in May; see TC to JN, 26 May; he wrote about it: “Perhaps the only copy in England, though not a rare book. I had a 9th vol., but it consisted only of Documents, State-papers &c., & was of no use. Herr Tauchnitz of Leipzig, who searched out for me that 9th vol., asserted confidently that no other had ever been published” (TC’s copy: HCC). See also 30:84TC to JN, 20 Oct. 1855. &c, it is
not worth sending thither now. I wish, however, you wd immediately, either there or somewhere better, take some punctual steps on the matter: it wd really be a great acquisition to me, that missing volume of Seyfart.TC needed vol. 1; see TC to W&NWAN, 6 June. Pray stir up somebody to try earnestly for that volume;—any other old ruinous Copy of Seyfart wd have a chance to contain it: beyond doubt, the thing might be got in the Antiquar shops by a diligt man!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady C [LCH], 1 March. MS: Shakespeare Birthplace Trust, Stratford-upon-Avon. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY CHATTERTON

docBody.p: You are very good; and it would give me great pleasure to come and pay my respects to you,Lady Chatterton lived at 5 Seamore Pl., Mayfair.—which I hope will one day be my fortune. But at present, and for the last two years,—owing to excess of occupation, weak health, and other causes,—I am totally cut off from such recreations; and for many months to come I have nothing to look for but grim seclusion, and an employment analogous to beating of hemp, with a whip swung over one!—

closer.salute: I crave your pity; and remain / Very sincerely yours

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-TW [TWO], 3 March. Pbd: Woolner 164; Wilson 5:336 inc.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p: I called yesterday, 4 to 5 p.m., at the Studio,Woolner’s studio was at Tudor Lodge, Albert St., Mornington Crescent, N. London. but found nobody—was proud I had found the House again, so that I might call another time.

I want you, in the meanwhile, to persuade the Secretary of the Hogarth
ClubFrederic George Stephens (1827–1907; ODNB), art critic and art historian for The Athenaeum (1861–1901), hon. sec. of the Hogarth Club, which had been founded in 1858 by Ford Madox Brown. Stephens’s birthdate is given as 1828 in earlier sources, including the DNB; 1827 is correct. (in some friendly way, for I would not hurt his feelings on any account) to cease altogether sending me the business letters &c. of that Institution,—to which I wish honestly well; hoping always I may look at your exhibited works, or the like, one day;The club was intended as an alternative to the Royal Academy and was an exhibiting forum where artists and patrons could meet informally. Thomas Woolner, William Morris (1834–96; ODNB), Dante Gabriel Rossetti (1828–82; ODNB), and Edward Burne-Jones (1833–98; ODNB) were among its 38 founding members. Carlyle and Tennyson were among the honorary members. but do not take hold farther, nor ever intend to do, least of all in present circumstances. Such letters are not only a waste of trouble and postage stamps to your society, but there is implied a kind of untruth in the affair: in short they are becoming, in their great frequency and miscellaneous complexion (of which I enclose you a specimen with appendix)Untraced. an afflictive phenomenon more or less; and I beg you, in a cunning silent way, stop them!
When anything that can interest a general member of the Community is afoot I shall be happy to hear tell of it.
. . . . . . . . . . .Ellipses in Woolner.
Excuse my headlong message (headlong form of ditto): I am in more haste, and with a heavier burden on my back, than is good for me just now.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-BB, [3 March?]. MS: NLS 606.521. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:206–10 inc. Quot: Hansons NE 477; Fielding and Sorensen 240–41. Conjecturally dated by the snowdrops sent from Auchtertool, which had probably flowered in Feb., and by the visits to the Rennies, which probably took place before the Rennies’ visit to Cheyne Row, Fri., 11 March; see TC to JAC, 14 March.
div3.head: JWC TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p: I shouldn’t wonder if you were wearying to hear from me! I know that I am wearying to hear from you, and there isn’t much hope of that till I have first put you in my debt.

The fact is I have a far wider correspondence on my hands than is either profitable or pleasant; and there are so few hours in the day that I can give to writing, being subject to continual interruptions in the forenoons, and in the afternoons too wearied for anything but lying on a sofa betwixt sleeping and waking. Ach! I remember “Tom Dodds” telling Mr Brown (you remember Mr Brown?)Thomas Dods, a schoolfriend of JWC; see 33:88JWC to WDO, [19 Sept. 1857]. James Brown (1786–1830), teacher of the public school at Haddington from 1812; see 1:3JBW to MWE, 19 Nov. 1812, and 24:166JWC’s MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849; see also A. Carlyle, NLM 207. that it was impossible to learn the whole of some task he had marked out to us—that he “hadn’t time for so much.” “Then” said Mr Brown, “make time, Sir! Miss Welsh can always make time for as much as I like to give her!” He wouldn’t compliment me on my talent for making time now, poor fellow! if he were alive to pay compliments and seeing how I go on! It isn’t that I am grown idle or lazy at heart; but I am grown physically incapable of exertion— It’s no good trying to “gar myself”Coterie speech; see 29:197TC to JCA, 10 Nov. 1854. do things now. If I overdo my strength one hour, I have to pay for it the next with utter impossibility to do anything! So it’s as well not to kick against the pricks,Cf. Acts 9:5. but to just creep along as I can! Indeed I should rather be thankful that I am got so far in the road to wellness, that I am now capable of resting and leaving the rest to shift for itself— In the beginning of my bad health, the feverish inclination to overfatigue myself, and the wide-awakeness day and night was the worst part of my disease. And besides this bodily languor and weariedness, I really have now little to complain of— I keep free of colds—have not coughed since November! and I get some reasonably good sleep—ever since I returned from ScotlandOn 29 Sept. 1858. and took to drinking—whisky toddy! Don’t be alarmed! I never increase my doze, and it is but one tablespoonful (of whisky that is) before going to bed.

For the rest; Mr Carlyle is hard at work as usual, and the house would be dull enough, if it were not for the plenty of people—often more than enough—who come to see me in the forenoons, and for Charlottes young, dancing spirits and face radiant with good humour and kindliness all day long! And the strange little Being has so much sense and reflection in her, that she is quite as good to talk with as most of the fine Ladies that come about me.— Sometimes I go out for a drive, and stay to Luncheon (which is my dinner) with some friend or other; to shake the cobwebs off my brain, which are apt to gather there when I sit too much at home! Last Tuesday I spent two or three hours at George Rennie’s! Oh you can’t fancy what an old worn-looking man he is grown. He has a grand house,George Rennie and his family lived at 32 York Ter., Regent’s Park. and his cousin Jane
whom he married (instead of me) seems to make him a devoted Wife;For JWC’s earlier opinions of Jane Rennie, see 7:253JWC to EA, [ca. Aug. 1834], and 30:248JWC’s Journal, 28 April 1856. but his life is not a happy one I think. Great ambition and small perseveranceRennie had been a reasonably successful sculptor, served as M.P. for Ipswich for six years, and was gov. of the Falkland Islands for eight years. have brought him a succession of disappointments and mortifications which have embittered a temper naturally none of the best! And his children (three sons)According to ODNB, George Rennie had two sons, William Hepburn Rennie (acting col. sec. to Falkland Islands, 1856–57, and lieut. gov. of St. Vincent, 1871–72 and Richard Temple Rennie (who became a barrister in Shanghai). must have disappointed him worst of all; for they are all a long, straggling, foolish sort of creatures; indeed the eldest, who had a stroke of the Sun in India, is become quite a helpless idiot!Possibly the third Rennie son, who has not been traced. In spite of all this, I am always glad to meet George, for the sake of dear old long ago; and if he is not glad to meet me, he is at least still very fond of me, I am sure. I saw at his house the other day, for the first time Marion Manderson (Margaret Rennie’s only daughter)Marion Manderson, b. Rennie, da. of George Rennie’s sister Margaret (b. 1796); m., 1828, John Rennie Manderson, capt. of the Bridgewater from 1824; see also 7:252JWC to EA, [ca. Aug. 1834]. She is the image of what Margaret was when she went with me to the Ballincrief Ball—my last Ball in East lothian!Ballencrieff, a mansion 1¾ mi. SE of Aberlady, E. Lothian, seat of Alexander Murray (1747–1820), 7th Lord Elibank, at the time of JWC’s last ball there (before Sept. 1819). I have been to Balls here—very grand ones too; but never with the same heart I carried to that one—before any shadow of death had fallen on my young Life!JWC’s father, John Welsh, d. 19 Sept. 1819; see 1:200–203JBW to EA, [26? Sept. 1819, and JBW to EWE, 5 Oct. 1819.

Who on earth do you think I have coming to two o’clock dinner with me? (Mr C dines at 7, which is too long for me to wait nowadays) That tall Sir George SinclairSir George Sinclair was probably staying with his brother, Archdeacon John Sinclair (1797–1875; ODNB), at Vicarage Pl., Kensington. that went to see George,George Braid, Betty’s invalid son. with some wonderful ointment or other! which of course did him no good! He is living in the vicinity of London at present. and wants us to spend a month with him at Thurso CastleThe Sinclair family home in Caithness, built 1660, modernized by Sir George, according to ODNB.—(in the very extreme north of Scotland)—when summer is come—If I could be conveyed there in my sleep I should make no objection for my share; but it would [be]Inserted in blue pencil (not TC’s) on MS. a terrible long journey to go, for the doubtful pleasure of finding Sir George Sinclair and Lady ClementinaJWC was mistaken; Sir George’s wife was Lady Catherine Camilla. at the end of it!

I had a letter from poor Miss Jess Donaldson today. No better accounts of
Miss Donaldson! She is wearing away; but so slowly, and painfully! It breaks my heart to think of her! And Miss Jess is as much to be pitied as the other—about to be left solitary at her age—and she a confirmed invalid since before I was born! I wish to Heaven I had health at this season to go to them and be of any use to them; since their silly niecesAs well as Eliza Donaldson, who did visit her aunts, the nieces were Jane Donaldson, Catherine Rawlins, Isabella Donaldson, Janet Skilbeck, and Helen Bayley. have no mind to go, and would only trouble them if they did! But it is only by taking the most tiresome cares of myself and self-denying myself at all turns, that I manage to keep from being laid up; and going to them, only to fall ill would be a sorry kindness. I write to them every week; it is sad to think that is the only way in which I can express my sympathy.

Surely this mild winter must have been good for George, as for me. If I only knew him improving tho’ ever so slowly I should think of you in your new homeUpper Stenhouse, Liberton, nr. Edinburgh; see 33:26833:biographical note. with pleasure. Have you any snowdrops or crocuses blown? My Cousin Walter sent me a dozen snowdrops from AuchtertoolRev. Walter Welsh; for snowdrops at Auchtertool Manse in 2006, see above. in a letter.
Snowdrops, Auchtertool Manse, 2006
Courtesy of Stewart Glasson

They arrived as flat as could be, but when I put them in water, I could
positively see them drinking and their little bellies rounding themselves out—till they looked as fresh as if they had been just brought in from the garden My kind regards to your Husband and George
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: John Welsh is still at Falmouth not worse he says. But the Doctors think his case perfectly hopeless.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LST], 10 March. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p:
Unfortunately,—or perhaps fortunately, who shall say?—my Wife had engaged DickensesCharles Dickens and his wife, Catherine, had separated in June 1858 (see 33:233TC to RWE, 2 June 1858); possibly he was bringing some of his children. (on some “business” Dickens says he has)Possibly concerning Dickens’s new journal, All the Year Round (1st issue, 30 April), which succeeded Household Words (last issue, 28 May; they overlapped by five weeks). Following the visit, Dickens wrote to TC, 24 March: “I cannot tell you how much I thank you for your friendly trouble, or how specially interesting and valuable any help is to me that comes from you. I do not doubt that the books received from the London Library, and suggested by you, will give me all I want. If I should come to a knot in my planning, I shall come back to you to get over it.” Dickens wrote to William Henry Wills (1810–80; ODNB), assistant ed. and part-proprietor of All the Year Round, 28 April, requesting that an invitation be addressed “to Ruffini, with a note to Mrs. Carlyle, asking her if she can direct the envelope” (DL 9:54–55).
