Giovanni Domenico Ruffini (1807–81), Italian writer and patriot exiled in 1839 and an ally of Mazzini, was a friend of JWC. There is no trace of him having written for All the Year Round. to come that same Tuesday Evg. But for this there wd have been a very great temptation; followed probably by a great repentance (and headache of six days), had any virtue given way!— I will, call one of these afternoons with Note of the Military Books:Unidentified, but presumably books on military strategy. I am very serious in wishing that you should be serious abt it. The Brith OfficerCf. 33:81TC to JSTR, 13 Sept. 1857. is a solecism among his fellow creatures in these ages! Yr Young manProbably Capt. John (” Johny”) Constantine Stanley, serving as aide-de-camp to Lord Canning (1812–62; ODNB), gov. gen. of India, after being invalided out of the Crimea in 1855, rather than his brother, Henry Edward John Stanley, who abruptly resigned his diplomatic post in Athens in Feb. and set out to travel through the Near East and Asia. His father later lamented that he had thrown away a good career in the diplomatic service: “Everything about his proceedings is objectless, purposeless and unintelligible” (Lord Stanley to Lady Stanley, 23 Jan. 1861; The Stanleys of Alderley, ed. Nancy Mitford [1939] 259). has plenty of talent; may rise to be Genl &c and, if he
really study his busss till he in the least understands what it is, and has by all rational mortals been recognized to be, he may prove importt to his country one day!—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-FC, 14 March. MS: NLS 8992.178. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO FREDERIC CHAPMAN

docBody.p: Dear Sir,— N°, this kind of paper, is to me much the pleasantest; but my experiments are not yet completed; and indeed I fled from some kinds (with a sort of terror) to my safe dim old straw-paper again!For TC’s previous coments on straw-paper, see 34:237TC to JN, 2 Nov. 1858. I will not fix on any at prest, lest I get bit when trying it on the great scan.

This sort I imagined wd do very well for Envelopes: but it seems unexpectedly transparent, whh is a fault in that kind of thing. Perhaps yr own Envelopes are made of a suitabler article? If you think so, and will get me a quantity made (wholesale, as you proposed) according to the inclosed samples of size &c, it will save me a quantity of small bother as well as small money, and be very welcome to me.——I sent off the order about the Frontispiece Prints:The first print, for vol. 3, was to be from the 1742 portrait of Frederick by Antoine Pesne, engraved in 1861 by Stanislaus Lukomsky (1835–67) under the direction of Eduard Mandel (see TC to JN, 11 Feb.), after Johann Georg Wille (1715–1808); see Works 15:frontispiece. The second print was to be from Heinrich Francke’s portrait of Frederick, Potsdam, ca. 1770 (see 33:209–10TC to WWV, 22 April 1858); it was engraved by Mandel himself, Berlin, 1860 (see Works 17:frontispiece); there were problems with it (see TC to EC, 11 Nov.; see vol. 36), which presumably led to its postponement to 5:frontispiece. The frontispiece of vol. 4 became a portrait of Frederick’s sister, Friederike Sophie Wilhelmine (1709–58; see 30:47TC to JAC, 28 Aug. 1855), margravine of Bayreuth, from a picture in Count von Usedom’s collection; see Works 16:frontispiece. “To be done in 8 months hence,” I covenant; tho’ alas there is small possibility of our being ready for them then! But it is better to be safe, and leave a margin. If both Prints cannot be done in 8 months, then they are to do one; and we will employ YoungPossibly Robert Young, engraver, 3 Furnival’s Inn, Holborn. upon the other.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Frk Chapman Esq

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 14 March. MS: NLS 525.48. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:235.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I write you a hurried word up aloft here,From his attic study; see 33:13TC to JWC, 7 Aug. 1857. after Tea, with plenty of business still waiting for me:—it will be better than no word at all. We go along here in the common way, or little below it; neither of us specially definable as ill, but suffering (possibly from the muddy tepid weather) under unusual fecklessness; and wishing we were a little stronger. Jane keeps afoot; takes her due drives, tries walking when the weather permits; and is surely a good deal better than she has been wont to be in the last two years. But her weakness is very great; her power of eating runs very low, poor soul, in these clammy days,—today she seems to be trying “total abstinence,” or something near it, by way of remedy to “a constant nausea” she complains of. We must do the best we can for a living, Boy!Coterie speech; see4:223TC to AC, 10 May 1827.— — As for me, the worst is a fatal inability to get forward with my work in this state of nerves and stomach. I am dark, inert and stupid to a painful degree, when progress depends almost altogether on vivacity of nerves! The remedy is— There is no remedy, but boring along mole-like or mule-like, and refusing to lie down altogether, tho’ one’s day’s work is hardly worth calling an hour’s now and then. Oh dear, Oh dear!— But I am fairly into my Second Book;TC is referring to the second stage of Frederick (vols. 3 and 4); TC also referred to the first two vols. as a single book; see TC to CBCBU, 24 Feb. progress is sometimes made in an inarticulate way: by a twelve month more of this kind of effort (if so much be granted me), we may see land, after all.— Poor Neuberg, translating in such a sublime way is almost as ill off as myself, and looks as if his 2d volume wd last him a ridiculous number of months yet.Neuberg was translating the 2d vol. of Frederick into German; see TC to JN, 19 Jan. He brot down, last night the inclosed bit of criticism by some grand Professor Leo (Berlin Jünker-Prophet),Untraced review of Frederick by Heinrich Leo (1799–1878), professor of history at Halle, 1828—68. Following the 1830 July Revolution, Leo renounced his radical Hegelian views in Die Hegelingen (Halle, 1838), befriended Wilhelm Friedrich IV (1795–1861) (king of Prussia from 1840), and advocated reactionary principles. whh I was tempted into looking at after Ng went: I found it not to reward my perusal; but I send it to you for another chance; the rather as I was ordered to “keep it safe“: please just put it into a cover for Neuberg, and write “with compts from J.A.C.,” if you have heart for no more.

RaePossibly a relative of either Benjamin Rae, previously schoolmaster at Ecclefechan (see 11:167TC to JAC, 15 Aug. 1839), or of Charles Rae (see 7:96TC to MAC, 11 Feb. 1834); not further identified. sent yr Card, and came by subsequent appointt Friday night last:
Rennies, TwisletonsGeorge and Jane Rennie and Edward and Ellen Twisleton. came too, but he preceded them by hours, and had talk enough: a good shrewd little fellow, tho’ of a very common type; wd grow wearisome at last, but is interesting while his Australian news last. A curious thing, to see such a man, one of many, with a fortune made in ten years!—Adieu, dear Brother; send word abt me to Jean. Yours ever
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[SL] [SLA], 14 March. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. Samuel Langley had apparently appealed to TC for help.
div3.head: TC TO [SAMUEL LANGLEY]

docBody.p: I am sorry to hear of your distresses, of your want of work especially. In help of that kind you propose I am already well supplied; and fear I shall have little or no use for yr services,—the rather as my present Task requires a ready knowledge of German to do much good in it, and French at least is entirely indispensable.

Enclosed is a small subvention“14 March (to Langley an Indigt Litr man) £2.00.0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). to assist in helping you over the bar. Enclosed too is a kind of problemPresumably a piece of research on “that affair of George Second’s Austrian-Succession War”; see TC to [SL][SLA], 5 May. TC described him as “14 Oxford Street / (the Museum man)” on 26 Dec. and as “half / charity,” “Half gift,” and “Charity,” 1860–61 (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). Langley either had a room or had his mail sent there, as 14 Oxford St. was the address of James Townsend, Coffee Rooms. somewhat in your line perhaps; which is of very remote importance to me, yet not absolutely of none at all. In case you have still nothing to do, but, observe, not otherwise, you may if you choose see what you can make of that, and send me the result you arrive at. No haste abt it;—nor can I well stand any farther questioning abt it; being constantly kept in such a whirl of hurries and theâtre-dancing confusions as are very difficult to keep command over.

closer.salute: Wishing you a better trade than that distracted one of “Literature” (whh only foolish Newspapers and such like Oracles can consider dignified, useful or wholesome for a wise man), I remain

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HG [HGR], 17 March. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd. Horace Grant (1801–59; see 8:74TC to JSM [13 March 1835]), civil servant in the Examiner’s Office, East India Co., 1826–1845, and a colleague of John Stuart Mill. He pbd. educational books, e.g., The Elements of Practical Geometry for Schools and Workmen (1852). Edwin Chadwick (1800–1890; ODNB) wrote in his biographical notice added to the new edn. of Grant’s Second Stage of Arithmetic (1861) that Grant’s principal object was that children should “exert their minds with pleasure” (xviii).
div3.head: TC TO HORACE GRANT

docBody.p: I am very glad to see your handwriting again; and was affected in heart as well as practically obliged by the kind Gift you sent me from your sickroom.Grant had suffered from poor health for several years; see 18:79TC to HGR, 23 June 1844; he d. in May. Such a messIn the sense of a large quantity. of Paper, all honestly made out of linen rags (as I perceive by this specimen), is a singular rarity in these days; and I mean to have my uses out of it by and by.

Nobody can compute the ridiculous but great and real sufferings I have had in regard to Paper, for the last 20 years! Ever since you ceased from my localities, I have been without pilot, in that bad matter, and have merely gone from sandbank to sandbank. If anybody, when I first entered London, had chopped 3 of my fingers off, and said, “Now I undertake that Paper, pens, ink, shall stand unimproved during your lifetime!” what a blessed bargain it had been in comparison!— About seven years ago, I was fairly drawn into iron pens; and go on in that fashion ever since,—cursing my stars rather less audibly than formerly; and I believe I must continue in the iron way (with dirty straw-paper &c), not to change too often. I still keep bad goose-quills (as you may notice); and no “pen” can replace to me some that I have had of your cutting, the last fairly good that were appointed me.

It is very sad all this that you have to report of yourself in the bodily way: such sufferings, I have often thought, are the most unmanageable that are laid upon clear-minded human creatures in this world. “Healthy,” in old German, is the selfsame word as “Holy”;TC’s etymology is correct; see also TC to T [DB]THE, 25 Feb.—and so in Nature I find the fact really to be; widely as we have wandered from it in our ways in this world!——One thing I perceive to be as good as certain: the fine weather, whh must be now at the threshold, will be greatly in favour of your kind of complaint; I promise myself all kinds of results out of this in the course of a month or two.

My Wife is usually one of the weakest of creatures (want of sleep, want of &c &c); but this warm winter she is decidedly better than in either of the last two. She sends you many kind and cordial regards.— I am myself busy as a
ginhorse;Horse used to drive machinery. driven on the whip (nothing else in this business), and in fact nearly flogged off my feet. My blessings with you, dear Grant!— T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 20 March. MS: NLS 516.66. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I might sometimes seize a five minutes (as now), and write you a small word, merely to keep your imagination quiet: but the truth is, the opportunity does but seldom occur; and when it does, I am not so prompt with it as I could once have been.

There is nothing new to tell you, nothing that you do not know, thro’ Jack or otherwise: I hang desperately at this bad job; and make most unsatisfactory progress; grudging the time spent in comparison with the paper covered (paper covered and not burnt);—whh in fact I sometimes admit to be a grudge merely that I am grown old, and have not the strength or speed that I once had. By no means a singular case among mankind!— My health is below the average rather; but nothing very bad: I expect as the weather mends, and the HorseFritz. is thoroughly himself again with his new coat on his back (he has been clipped, occasionally coughing, and never fairly right, all winter), I shall get a small accession of liveliness, and progress better. On the whole “ye maun excuse us the day”Coterie speech; see 7:199TC to MAC, 30 May 1834. (as a poor Mail Guard once said in wet weather); be patient till I do get done;—I design to go idle all the remainder of my life; and attend to what friends I have left.— Jane still holds up: sleeps every night,—thanks to a spoonful of whisky she makes into punch just before going to bed: she misses, when the whisky is omitted for any cause.

Your James Junr does not come much about us, for whh I give him credit, knowing the modest reason; but we do sometimes see him; a welldoing douce intelligt young man: he is to be over, with his flute this time, we expect, before long. It was truly a bit a great luck, that feat of the Dr’s in placing him there.James Aitken had begun work in a London mercantile house late Sept. 1858; see 34:216TC to JCA, 13 Oct. 1858, and 26934:biographical note.

I suppose the Dr often writes to you, tells you any vestige of tidings he gets. Ballantyne’s Newspaper having sunk,The last issue of Thomas Ballantyne’s newspaper The Statesman (see 33:102TC to HL, 18 Oct. 1857) came out 23 April. I always thot of getting some other;To send to the Aitkens in Dumfries. and will surely do it, tho’ all of them are considerably disgusting to me. And I
hear about the “news,” generally more than I want, from my fellow creatures.— Ballantyne will probably not come up again, tho’ he promised to do it: he is a foolish little being, tho’ a thoroughly goodnatured,—and has a vanity that will save him from pain on the most trying occasions.

There is here a letter from the Scotch-German LadyCountess Olympia von Usedom had a Scottish mother, was brought up in Scotland, and now lived with her husband in Germany; see 34:119TC to JWC, 11 Aug. 1858. to whose House I went last autumn.The von Usedoms lived on the Isle of Rügen; TC stayed with them 27 Aug.–4 Sept. 1858; see 34:159TC to JWC, 27 Aug. 1858. I know not if it is worth reading (some of it is German and unreadable): but you may try; and then forward it to John for return hither some time.—“Horse!” as usual— God bless you dear Sister. T. CarlyleTC sent £25 to his sister Mary Austin, 19 March, for her third da. Jessie’s m. to George Gilfillan, 8 March; he noted in error in his checkbook: “(on marriage of ‘Jane’)” (MS: NLS 20753).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [25 March?]. MS: NLS 606.514. Hitherto unpbd. Conjecturally dated by the expected visit of TC’s nephew James Aitken (see TC to JCA, 20 March) and Mary May Welsh’s marriage, 25 March. Fri. was 25 March.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row Chelsea Friday night[25 March? 1859]
docBody.p:
You could not conceive, without having been beside me, the hindrances I have found to answering your letter ever since it came to hand; for Nature prompted me to answer at once— You were sad—and a letter from me might cheer you a bit—the bare chance was quite sufficient to set me on writing without loss of a single post—if only ‘the Devil and his Grandmother’Cf. Jakob Grimm and Wilhelm Grimm, “Der Teufel und seine Grossmutter,” Kinder und Hausmärchen (Göttingen, 1843) 1:217. would have permitted. But, on the principle that “it never rains but it pours,” this house has been “like a cried fair”A fair that has been publicly proclaimed. for the last three days; or rather like the Siege of Sebastopale!The siege of Sebastopol during the Crimean War lasted 387 days, 1854–55. This is the third day that I have had company (improvised,—of their “own sweet will”)Cf. Wordsworth, “Composed upon Westminster Bridge” line 12. to my early dinner, making ‘pigs and whistles’I.e., bits and pieces, wrack and ruin; cf. 19:144JWC to TC, [13–14 Aug. 1845]. of the whole heart of my day, and again equally uninvited men tumbling in to tea, and stealing away my evening— I have literally not had an hour to myself, beyond what was needed for recruiting exhausted nature, at
full length, on a sofa, with shut eyes, and a mind as nearly in a state of vacancy as I could make it.

To night our last visitor (the anything but interesting sonJames Aitken. of my Sister-in-law at Dumfries) has left early, having mercifully a great distance to travel) and I snatched up my pen, before the street-door had closed on him, and surely I will now get a letter written; to be despatched tomorrow. Nobody else can well interrupt me tonight, as the clocks are this instant striking ten.

My Dear I am so much obliged to you for liking to write to me when you are sad. It is a proof of affection, that, which can be depended on. Fancy my writing to Mrs PringleJanet Pringle. when I felt sad—the thing would be impossible!—tho she wrote me, I must own, I nice long letter the other day with no flumery in it “to speak of”! Just a few phrases about Mary Welsh’s marriageJWC’s cousin Mary May Welsh married at Janet Pringle’s home, Lann Hall, nr. Thornhill, 25 March.—“poor Marys life had had so little of happiness in it of late years; that one must make her wedding as glad and bright as possible for her.“— Must one? and if one must; is lending her the use of one’s big rooms and silver-plate, and getting up the steam within a hairs-breadth of burting the boiler, so sure a way of making her wedding “glad and bright?” I should have thought the more quietly and modestly one took that BaboonRobert Craven; see 34:46JWC to TC, [15 July 1858], and 210JWC to MR, [1 Oct. 1858]. “for better and for worse” the better! I did not think Mary Welsh by any means a wise woman, when I saw her for the first time last summer, but this going to Lann Hall to be married proves her very much of a fool. It is quite of a piece with the bonnet she had bought herself in London, (lilac satin all bedizened with white paste beads—and worn along with a rusty black gown!)— My Cousin JohnJohn Welsh the meteorologist. is quite scandalised at the slight to her Mother’s houseMary Welsh lived at 250 St. George’s Rd., Glasgow.— He is quite another sort of a Cousin poor fellow—worth all my cousins tied up in one bundle! and him I must make up my mind to lose! He talks of being ‘stationary’— But his DoctorHenry Bence Jones. has not a hope of him—nor could any one hope, who had looked in his face and heard his voice—and his cough— But it is the line both he and his Mother have taken; never to admit that he gets worse. My poor old Miss Donaldson is still lingering on, her mind as clear, her heart as warm as ever!—but no rallying nor chance of rallying (they write)—and suffering much from sleeplessness, and nervous distress. She sends me the fondest assurances of her “affection, that will abide to the last“—bids her poor sister write and tell me this and that, and Miss Jess writes—with what a sorrowful heart you can
figure! I open every letter from Haddington with a shudder. One day, lately Charlotte brought me four letters, altogether, on a plate, and every on[e] (I could see so soon as she came into the room) with a broad black border! The sight made me sick, but it was a false alarm—there was no bad news, with all that influx of black. It is strange how the most absurd things will recur to ones mind along with the most solemn.

I am reminded this moment of a thing Old Sir George Sinclair (Sir Gorg Synkler as dear old BettyBetty Braid. spells him) told me the other day as an authentic fact. We were talking about the hardship of living with a bad wife! (Lady ClementinaLady Catherine Camilla. is said to have thrown much light for him on that subject) Sir George said an old acquaintance of his own being at the point of death, a mutual friend (KinairdUnidentified. I think was the name) went to take leave of him, and found him wonderfully cheerful. “I am glad” he said “to see you meeting death so bravely! Have you then no fear of the King of Terrors?“—“Oh no!” said the dying man, I have lived for five and forty years beside the Queen of Terrors; I need fear nothing after that!”

My little Charlotte continues to be a great temporal blessing to me. Proof against ‘Spoiling.’ But I have my own ideas about “spoiling servants,” and seen no cause yet to modify or change them. The “spoiling” I give Charlotte for example is no such easy matter as you may think—for I have common sense enough to know that a mistress must keep up her authority over her servants or it will be the worse for her!— and if the character of the servant be of a sort that cannot be acted upon by moral means, or if the Mistress is incapable or will not take the trouble to use moral means; why then there should be recourse to mechanical ones. I mean if one cannot or will not take the trouble to keep up a respect in the servant, why then, one must what they call keep up one’s dignityCoterie speech; see 8:193JWC to JCA, [mid Aug. 1835]. with her. Now, how often it is just to ones servants and to them only that one shows all ones faults—because it would be too much constraint to be always showing a fair outside to them, and because they dont seem worth the bother of putting constraint on oneself— If one is to treat a servant indulgently humanly, fellow-creaturely, one must show her at the same time the best of oneself—not the worst, and substitute the real respect one inspires for the conventional respect one does not exact. Thus one must be content to wear in her presence the same moral straight-waistcoat one doesn’t mind wearing in the presence of a lover, or valued friend. Moreover one must first of all satisfy oneself of the servants capacity
for respect— With a fool or a creature without sensibility better stick to the keeping-up-one’s-dignity system—

But Charlotte is full of intellect and imagination and feeling. The best piece of stuff I ever got, to “make a spoon or spoil a horn”Proverbial. with— And I assure you I never took more trouble to gain the esteem and affection of man or woman than I have taken to gain hers— In return I have the behaviour of an obedient, dutiful affectionate Adopted Child from her How long it may last so, I do not pretend to foretell—as I cannot forsee what other influences may be brought to bear on her—or how long my infallibility may hold out for her—
There! if that isn’t moralyzing enough for one time!

Mr C sent a bookPossibly David Brodie (” Therapeutes”), The Healing Art, the Right Hand of the Church (1859); see TC to T [DB]THE, 25 Feb. to Dr Russell today— He had read it and thought it might interest him.

closer.salute: Give him my kindest regards please—and write soon—and believe in my constant love

docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 26 [25] March. Addr: 2. St John’s Villas / Highbury Vale. PM: London, 25 March 1859. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. TC apparently misdated the letter.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: I now want a Saddle: probably you can help me in that too!Larkin had helped TC find an “apparatus” (i.e., a truss) for sea bathing in 1858; see 33:241TC to HL, 13 June 1858, 34:11TC to JWC, 5 July 1858, and 15TC to HL, 8 July 1858. Think what the resources known to you are, and call tomorrow.

There is plenty of confused writing ready again; no hurry abt it.— I begin to feel as if the Plan of BreslauTC did not use a map of Breslau. wd hardly be admissible after all. It wd involve us in various similar enterprizes (Plan of PragSee Works 17:opp. 223. is much more requisite, if any Town is to be given; &c): so pray dont be the least particular abt this Breslau; but just let me see what it is like,—before going farther.

A fraction of sponge to stick in the head of an inkbottle: perhaps you know where that can be had? I cannot think of clipping into one of my big bathing-sponges; and there is no other resource patent in this high elevation!—
Tomorrow (Saty)Sat. was 26 March. I count on seeing you for a minute.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC [W&N?] [UCWAN], 2 April. MS: Waverly Auctions, Bethesda, Maryland; catalogue entry for auction, 30 May 1987, two pp. signed autograph note, “Concerning an earlier book order,” 2 April 1859; it was possibly in relation to German books ordered through Williams & Norgate; see TC to JN, 28 Feb.
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT [WILLIAMS & NORGATE?]

docBody.p: [Concerning an earlier book order.]Frederick J. Foxton (ca. 1807–70), lapsed Church of Wales clergyman, who had traveled with TC in Germany Aug.—Sept. 1858, wrote a long letter of admiration to TC, 1 April: “I have the most agreeable memory of our German excursion—every yard of the way—every thing, person, & place—every cold cup of Coffee—‘staggering Bob’ & still more staggering steed—every bed (of torture) every bug … are now laid up in Lavender, in my imagination—purified & sanctified, as the chemise of the Virgin Mary to the devout Catholics of Aix-la-Chappelle. The whole picture of our four weeks travel is bathed in sunshine.” TC was not as enthusiastic about Foxton; see, e.g., 34:156TC to JWC, 24 Aug. 1858; 174TC to JAC, 5 Sept. 1858; 180TC to JWC, 10–11 Sept. 1858; and 197TC to JWC, 23 Sept. 1858.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 5 April. MS: NLS 525.49. Quot: Southern 266.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I have been wearying for a Letter of late, and expecting one from morning to morning; but none comes. The reason, when I reflect, is plainly twofold: most probably I myself am in arithmetical arrear; and in the second place there is probably nothing at Edinr that presses to be said.— I have come up stairs, however, to write to you this night; whh is the next best thing.

You asked me once about poor John Welsh; and I doubt I made no answer. The truth is, we know little of him, except in general the sad fact, that he is wearing weaker; that Bence Jones has no hope of him, and considers that, since autumn last, all efforts are intrinsically useless or worse. He (B. Jones) wrote twice to Jane, to that effect in very delicate tones, not long after you left, and probably in consequence of your visit to him. John Welsh too wrote to the like practical purport, and seemed almost provoked that the matter should be stirred farther. Jane has had at most two other Letters from him; very distinct, quiet, brave; giving graphic descriptions of the Fox peopleAnna Maria and Caroline Fox and their Quaker family in Falmouth. and their ways, who are very kind to him; and saying little, in the way of complaint nothing, about his own situation: the winter temperature very favourable to him; nothing sensibly worse; daily or almost daily walks, sometimes near an hour; cough troublesome &c. From his Mother’s Letters whh are more frequent
there can nothing be gathered, except incidentally; poor woman she tries to speak always in the language of cheerfulness, tho’ one can see that there is no hope in her. Most of the Fox people are off lately towards Rome; but one, an old Naturalist,Probably Robert Were Fox, Anna and Caroline’s father. very good and honest, is still left. Poor John & his Mother propose to return to Richmond soon;—and it was by the Mother’s anxiety about the first part of this journey (40 miles not in railway) that we drew our saddest inferences last time she wrote. Alas, alas!—

But I must tell you about Butler’sCharles Butler. Letter, whh is here inclosed. He is my American who did the last Yankee BondFor the Illinois bond, see 29:21TC to CBU, 17 Jan. 1854, and 34:261TC to CBU, 19 Aug. 1856. in the way you know: an excellt old gentn, to judge by physiognomy, and by other tests that have come in my way: had I got this Letter at the time I expected one and got none,Possibly in early 1858; see 34:265–66TC to CBU, 9 June 1858. I had probably sent all my cash for him to invest. As it is, I will now make no change in the Debentures and Preference Shares (4 per cent each);See TC to CBCBU, 24 Feb. but I mean to send Butler another £1,000 whh I still have: except that the interest is so extremely good,Butler had written, 4 Aug. 1856, that he could buy bonds with a return of “about 10%” (MS: NLS 1767.134). I have not the least reason to question his judgement. He works in that business as his trade, is thoroughly well affected to me, and I found him a prudent considerate kind of character & much the gentleman in appearance, manners & conduct. So the £1,000, I suppose, must go, tho’ at £70 annually. You perceive he has still room for 2 other Thousands: but I confess I am almost rather glad the others (of mine) are quietly settled, on different bottoms; so that it will take three thunderbolts to sink them all.— For the rest, I design to try if AdamsonRobert Adamson, TC’s Dumfries banker. cannot manage both to send the money for me, and to gather up from Butler all the legal threads (both of this sum and of the former one), so as to hold good vouchers in case of any accident to me or to Br,—and on the whole to trouble me no farther with the thing at all, except by receiving the half-yearly dividends.Butler sent interest every Feb. and Aug.; see 34:261–65TC to CBU, 19 Aug. 1856. For the rest, I will do nothing, not even write to Adamson, till I hear from fromWord repeated at turn of page. you. Pray read Butler then; and return him to me; so soon as you have come to clear understanding about it.

Alan Ker was here; had been 3 or 4 months in this Country, with wife & child,Alan Ker was chief justice of Dominica; his wife and child were Mary and Walter. but at Manchester mostly; did not appear here till within a fortnight
of his departure (3 weeks ago or so), and all I saw of him was, one night, an hour or two over tea. He is hardly changed, or if at all rather for the better; a shade less croaky and uneasy in his skin;—translating German &c (I strongly advised him to write upon the Niggers) as he has nothing to do.Ker had written a pamphlet, Remarks on the Present Representative System (1847); no other work by him has been traced. DominicaIn the W. Indies, between the then French-controlled islands of Guadeloupe to the N and Martinique to the S, Dominica was fought over by the British and French for nearly 200 years; British control was finally established by the 1783 Treaty of Versailles. For Ker’s appointment to Dominica, see 31:192TC to JWC, 25 Aug. 1856. [was] a glorious present to get from her Majesty, if [one] were 40 years younger! Size of the Isle of Wight or bigger;Isle of Wight is in Hampshire, off the S coast of England, area 147 sq. mi.; the area of Dominica is 290 sq. mi. rising grand with Mahogany woods tropical üppigkeit [luxuriance], and a grand extinct-volcanoPotentially active volcanoes form Dominica’s central spine; TC is possibly referring to Morne au Diable in the N of the island, thought to be extinct at the time. (whh g[rows] fine coffee and is wholesome as Tempe)Tempe was a luxuriant valley in Greece between Mounts Olympos and Ossa, celebrated by ancient Greek poets. in the cen[tre] of it:populatn 100 whites, 28,000 blacks, and perhaps 3,000 yellows;According to the 1859 American Almanac, the population of Dominica was 22,469, of which the white population was a small minority. Although slavery was not abolished in Dominica until 1834, the Brown Privilege Bill, 1832, had abolished all discrimination on grounds of color for all free people, and by 1838 Dominica had become the first and only British Caribbean colony where white Europeans did not control the legislature, mounting the first successful challenge to white rule in the Caribbean. In his letter to TC, 10 May 1856, Ker wrote that Dominica was “the most villainous community in the entire British Dominions” and that “the Mulattoes” wanted “to drive the whites out of the island and get everything into their own hands” (MS: NLS 1767.109). Parlt of13 members;Dominica was a British colony, administered as part of the Leeward Islands since 1833 with a lieut. gov. appointed by the crown; its Legislative Council of seven members was appointed by the governor on behalf of the crown, and its House of Assembly of 19 representatives elected by the people (Colonial Office Papers; National Archives at Kew: CO 380/44). 1 mu[l]atto tinsmith the DerbyLord Derby, the British prime minister. TC is possibly referring to Benoit Bellot, Speaker of the House of Assembly and its dominant voice. It is not clear why TC refers to him as a tinsmith; he was a planter. In 1853, the Colonist newspaper, which supported the white minority, reported that the elected members were on the whole “men who are entirely ignorant of the first principles of government. … They are uneducated, ignorant and revengeful. … The majority of these would-be-legislators, is made up of Journey-men Printers and Tailors, Bankrupt Shopkeepers, a Blacksmith and a few fourth rate Planters” (quoted in Joseph A. Boromé, “How Crown Colony Government Came to Dominica by 1898,” Caribbean Studies 9.3 [Oct. 1969]: 27). of the institn, the Henry
Dr[um]mond jet black,Henry Drummond, M.P. for W. Surrey, 1847–60, and an apostle of the Catholic Apostolic Church. TC is possibly referring to Charles Gordon Falconer (1819–72), a shrewd and charismatic leader of the Mulatto Ascendancy (an unofficial political party), members of which formed the majority in the House of Assembly in 1859. Falconer established and edited the Dominican in opposition to the Colonist; a vociferous and evangelical Methodist, he opposed Roman Catholicism and state funding of religion. In his letter to TC, 10 May 1856, Alan Ker described him as a “mulatto incendiary” whose “power is omnipotent over his own class” (NLS: MS 1767.109). and one hon. member a whit[e] specimen.Unidentified. It is not worth a farthing to her Majesty as at present managedSince it became a British colony a succession of lieut. govs. had found the island notoriously difficult to manage. The often conflicting influences of French and British colonizers and Dominica’s history of slavery created complex social relations, of which skin color, religion (Protestant and Roman Catholic), and language (French and English) were an integral part (see Patrick L. Baker, Centring the Periphery [Montreal and Kingston, 1994] 128). The two main groups within Dominica’s political and social elite were the white administrators, officials, and estate owners, and the mainly French mulatto families, many of whom owned estates and slaves but who, until 1831, had been banned from participating in government (see Lennox Honychurch, The Dominica Story [1995] 127–29). With the entry of nonwhites into the Assembly the atmosphere became combative. In 1850 only a fifth of Dominica’s population was literate (see Boromé 28); the need for legislation to improve public welfare (particularly that of ex-slaves) became caught up in the power struggle between the elite groups and the interests of the British govt. The Antigua Weekly Register reported in 1858 that the “political disputes, engendering social discord and strife” of Dominica were now so common that they had “cease[d] to attract even an ordinary degree of attention” (quoted in Honychurch 27). Many of the white minority saw the solution to the problem as single-chamber govt., which was successfully opposed by the Mulatto Ascendancy until the 1860s. Dominica’s economy was also poor. Revenue for 1858 was £13,500, £7,000 of which was owed to the British govt. in repayment of the capital and interest on an 1845 hurricane relief loan. In June 1857, the House of Assembly had asked the lt. gov., Maj. Henry St. George Ord (1819–85), to petition Parliament to cancel the debt; in exchange the legislature would spend that amount on public works. At the same Assembly meeting, the Education Commissioners reported that in the first year of the Education Act (1857) only £440 had been spent on education (two-thirds of the sum that should have been spent), due to shortage of funds. Money was also needed to finance repairs to roads (Colonial Office Papers; National Archives at Kew: CO 74/31). Ord reported, 4 Jan. 1859, that he had strongly supported the proposal to cancel the hurricane loan debt but the British govt. insisted that repayment was “from the first … a positive condition of the loan” (CO 74/31). An arrangement was eventually made whereby the loan was paid back over a period of 20 years. (they have to send f[or]The MS was taped together at some point and the removal of the tape has taken off the ink of the words and letters noted above in brackets. Frenchmen even to quench riots,—and a boat’s crew with cutlasses cd take it at any time.British defenses in the colony were acknowledged to be inadequate; in Jan. 1859, on the instructions of the British govt., Ord had raised the question of the establishment of a militia or volunteer force for the defense of the colony. He complained that govt. buildings were so badly defended that “constant plundering means that there is nothing of a portable nature left” (Colonial Office Papers; National Archives at Kew: CO 74/31). Dominica’s closest neighbors, the islands of Guadeloupe and Martinique, would probably have had greater resources to use against insurgents because historically the French had established stronger defenses to protect their colonies (see Patrick L. Baker, Centring the Periphery [Montreal and Kingston, (1994)] 77).

James CurrieJames Corrie, Sandy Corrie’s son; see 22:108TC to AC, 2 Oct. 1847; as he was living in Mauritius by 1875 (see Marrs 784–85), he was possibly already there. has sent me three specimens of Tobacco: just opened this
night (or rather only one of them yet opened, so busy am I); there had been some correspondence with Irving & CoPossibly Reid, Irving & Co. (merchants), 2 Gresham Pl., King William St. abt getting it out of the Customhouse (5 or 6 lb of it in all), and Shakspeare the MilkmanOtherwise unidentified; see also 33:221JWC to CSO, [8 May 1858]. has opened the Mauritius sample (Bourbon is the 2d, 3d I forget what, neither of whh are yet opened): I find it eminently good,—and send you a pinch or two; try it in a clean pipe, and you will find it excel Havannah almost. Very kind of James Currie; tell me what his Address is:—I have laid the thing all by again in a dry place; suppose we wait till you come before opening it!—

I am getting on slower & slower; woe’s me! For the rest Jane keeps on foot; never was finer weather: I rode by Streatham and ClaphamLondon boroughs S of the Thames, approximately 5 mi. and 3 mi. respectively from Chelsea. today, thro’ all manner of silent lanes and green spaces,—beautiful extremely, had not one’s poor heart been so shut & sad.

I heard from Jean the other day; & sent her the Fraser just come out,—where you will see a Paper by Mill (on “Reform” forsooth),John Stuart Mill, “Recent Writers on Reform,” Fraser’s Magazine 59 (April 1859): 489–508, a review of books by John Austin, James Lorimer, and Thomas Hare, in which Mill observed: “the present demand for Parliamentary Reform, being in an unusual degree the product of calm reason, leaves room to hope that any appeal to reason may be listened to, and encourages the superior intellects to bring forward any thoughts they possess which seem to them to have a useful bearing upon the questions at issue” (489). quite enthusiastic about nothing at all.— What “the ministers did” yesternight,The govt. had been defeated in the debate on the Reform Bill, 31 March; Derby’s ministry decided, 4 April, to proceed with the dissolution of Parliament, which took place 23 April. and who or what now is ministry I have not the least notion (having spoken to nobody all day), nor any desire peceptibleThus in MS. to get one.

closer.salute: Adieu, dear Brother; I have still “Notes” to write: adieu

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CB [CBU], 8 April. MS: EUL. Quot: Southern 267.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES BUTLER

docBody.p: I am much obliged by your last kind message (Nw Yk 19 March); all parts of which, the sad part too,Unexplained. I have read with appropriate interest!—Today, in great hurry (as my wont is in these times), I restrict myself to the specially practical.

By your account of the Books, I perceive that you have got safely the 16 voll. (stereotype “Collected Works”) whh were successively sent, and which complete that set;—but farther (what was rather mortifying to me, and has produced dunning and remonstrance here in the proper quarter), that Two big new volumes called Life of Frederick were still lingering on their tedious route, at the time you wrote. My Publisher (Chapman 193. Piccadilly) asseverates that you are now sure to have got them (“delays at the Customhouse” &c notwithstanding); and adds that if you still have them not, a message addressed “Dr Cogswell, Astor Library,Joseph Green Cogswell (1786–1871), a friend of John Jacob Astor (1763–1848), helped found the Astor Library in 1854. Lafayette Place, N. Yk” will at once bring them. Pray assure me that they are come to hand;Butler acknowledged the arrival of the first two vols. of Frederick, 3 May, “with your own autograph sign manual on the fly leaf which book I am now reading to my daughters with interest & gratification” (Kimball 287).—and be so good as put the enclosed Note into the Post-Office, whh directs Mr Emerson when to apply (if needful) on the same sorry errand.See TC to RWE, 9 April. That, I hope, is now finished.

With regard to the Money-Investment whh you are so kind as undertake for me,—we must submit to the accident of 2 Thousands being already planted (not to be torn up again, in my present sad hurry); and as to the 3d, I have this day given orders to my Banker at Dumfries (British Linen Company,The British Linen Co., founded in 1746, acted as a bank from 1765, formally chartered as a banking corporation 1849; headquarters at 38–40 St. Andrew Sq., Edinburgh. The correct name was the British Linen Company Bank, rather than the British Linen Bank (which it became in 1906), despite previous references to Adamson as the manager of the British Linen Bank at Dumfries (see, e.g., 10:23TC to JA, 14 Feb. 1838). Branch-Bank there) to send off straight way, to your Address, £1,000 on my behalf,—and to arrange with you for receiving the dividends of this and of the other sum, and for having the vouchers (Law etceteras whatever they are) put into his hand; so that all may be tightly set in order, agt any event, and there may be no more care required abt it from my inexperienced head. I hope there will be no difficulty, or not much, on your side either. The Dumfries
Banker is a solid expert man of business; his address, “Robert Adamson Esq., Brith Ln Cy Bank, Dumfries N.B.”; and he has all my bits of factorage &c in hand: his Bank (headquarters of whh is in Edinh) is of old standing & respectability, and I believe has direct communicatn with New York. Were the matter once in Adamson’s hand, I shd consider myself as having done with it; and the next £1,000 that falls to me I could, by his channel, send the same road, &c &c. In short I shd prefer it that way, if equally manageable.—— If not, then I have also a Banker (or Bank for the people are mere ciphers to me) who keeps a little money for me; and the dividends &c &c cd be made payable to “The Londn Joint Stock Bank, Western Branch, 69. Pall Mall” (that is the Title in full),—tho’ I shd like the other way (and still runs my imagination wd) considerably better!—In the course of a week after this, the money from Adamson will follow.—I beg many pardons for my haste, inexpertness, & the trouble I give; but your goodness is great. Yours ever truly
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-WMT, 9 April. MS: NLS 7197.68. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM MAKEPEACE THACKERAY

docBody.p: Dear Thackeray,—Thanks for your merry little Note and the two Pens.TC’s letter is in reply to Thackeray’s note: “What do you think, most hard-to-please of men, / Of William Mitchell’s patent broad-nibbed pen? / I’ve bought a box—three shilling for the gross— / At Mitchell’s Stationer’s in Charing Cross. / Try these: and if you like the pens, I’ll trouble you / To write to 36. O. Square. S. W. / Where Somebody is found, who’ll gladly spend / Three Bob to be of sarvice to a friend” (Ray 4:147, dated [3? Aug.], and the correspondent mis-identified as William Brookfield). Thackeray lived at 36 Onslow Sq. It is like a little pearl of human cheerfulness and friendliness, turning up for one in the dreary wash of commonplace and botheration, whh is one’s common lot!—

I have been true as Mitchell’sWilliam Otho Mitchell, 39 Charing Cross. own steel to his Pens and him these many years; not even the Pair you sent me to ScotlandIn 1856; see 31:155TC to JWC, 7 Aug. 1856, and 157TC to LA, 7 Aug. 1856. could seduce my faithful hand, for above a day or two. “Letter J” I find to be the right article: “R” I use for addressing Packets. Try these two “J’s,” both in slantindicular and perpen-do, they perform well.Thackeray wrote in a postscript: “I think they seem to suit better for the upright, than the slantingdicular writing.” Ray noted: “This sentence is written in Thackeray’s slanting hand, the rest of the letter is in his upright hand” (Ray 4:147).

And observe farther, here is a kind of Paper, whh I find the best of many for suiting Mitchell. Try that too: it is made partly of straw;—smooth enough;
and bites at the ink with an appetite one likes. “Parkins & Gotto” Stationers;—and I will send you a ream of it whenever you hold up your finger.

Oh that I cd see a gentleman with a sweet smile on his face walking past my table, equipped in the corresponding way!Thackeray wrote in a second postscript: “A gentleman has just passed my table with a sweet smile on his face, and in his hand the last number of THE V.RG.N..NS [Virginians]” (Ray 4:147). W. M. Thackeray, The Virginians, 2 vols. (1858–59), was pbd. in monthly installments in London by Bradbury & Evans, Nov. 1857–Oct. 1859, and in New York in Harper’s New Monthly Magazine, Nov. 1857–Oct. 1859. Thackeray presumably means the most recent issue, while TC means he would like to see a gentleman carrying the last vol. of Frederick. But I often think this villainous bottomless confusion (worthless to gods and men) will kill me first.

closer.salute: Adieu dear Thackeray; good luck to you always.

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 9 April. Addr: Concord / Massachusetts. MS: RWEMA. Pbd: Norton, CE 2:301–2; Slater, CEC 526.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p: Dear Emerson,—Long months ago there was sent off for you a Copy of Friedrich of Prussia, Two big red VolumesEmerson wrote, 1 May, that he was “heartily glad to get the Crimson Book itself”; he had looked for it sooner, and when it did not arrive he presumed himself punished for his “sluggish contumacy.” He had read the American reprint and had referred to it in his lecture “Art and Criticism,” 13 April, Music Hall, Boston. When the book arrived with “its irresistible inscription” he was “all tenderness and all but tears” (Slater, CEC 527). Emerson had referred to his “long contumacy to-you-ward” in his letter, 27 May 1858 (Slater, CEC 520). (for whh Chapman the Publisher had found some “safe swift” vehichle); and now I have reason to fear they are still loitering somewhere, or at least have long loitered; sorrow on them! This is to say: If you have not yet got them, address a line to “Saml F. FlowerIn error for Haven; Samuel Foster Haven (1806–61), librarian; see Slater, CEC 527. Esq, Librarian of Antiquarian Society Worcester Mass.” (forty miles from you, they say); and that will at once bring them. In the Devil’s name!—

I never in my life was so near choked; swimming in this mother of Dead Dogs,Coterie speech; cf. Pope, Dunciad 2:271–72. TC used the phrase “mother of dead dogs” in his letters from Jan. 1832 (see 6:87TC to JAC, 10 Jan. 1832), as well as in “Boswell’s Life of Johnson,” written early 1832 (pbd. May 1832; see Works 28:110); it was a time when he was trying to negotiate the publication of Sartor Resartus and was being commissioned to write journal articles; he used it to mean London, Fleet St., and Grub St. journalism (see 6:87TC to JAC, 10 Jan. 1832, 17:179JWC to SS, [14 Nov. 1844], and 22:3TC to UC, July 1847). and a long spell of it still ahead! I profoundly pity myselfEmerson responded: “Every child of mine knows from afar that handwriting, & brings it breathless home. I read without alarm your pathetical hints of your sad plight in the German labyrinth. … I await peacefully your issue from your pretended afflictions” (Slater, CEC 527–28). (if no one
else does). You shall hear of me again if I survive;—but really that is getting beyond a joke with me; and I ought to hold my peace (even to you) and swim what I can.

Your little Touch of Human Speech on BurnsEmerson’s lecture, delivered at the Burns centenary celebration, Boston, 25 Jan., in which he celebrated the poet’s unique language. was charming; had got into the Papers hereDumfries and Galloway Courier, 15 Feb. (and been clipt out by me) before yr Copy came;—and has gone far & wide since: Neuberg was to give it me in German from the Allgemeine Zeitung;A trans. of part of Emerson’s speech appeared in Allgemeine Zeitung, 19 Feb.; see Slater, CEC 526. but lost the leaf.—— Adieu, my Friend; very dear to me, tho’ dumb.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle (in such haste as seldom was)—

div3.sourceNote: TC-CGD, 13 April. MS: NLI. Pbd: Duffy 202–5. Charles Gavan Duffy (1816–1903; ODNB; see TC to MAC, 28 April 1845), Irish politician who emigrated to Australia, 1855; see TC to MACA, 7 Dec. 1856.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES GAVAN DUFFY

docBody.p: I confess I have been remiss in writing to you; shamefully so, if you did not know the circumstances, or believe in them without knowing! To want of remembering you I will by no means plead guilty; and I have had two letters, or one and a half (with excellent continuation by Mrs Callan)Margaret Callan, b. Hughes (d. ca. 1865; see 24:60TC to CGD, 29 May 1849), Duffy’s cousin and sister-in-law; she had emigrated in 1856; see 32:46–47TC to MACA, 7 Dec. 1856. which were heartily welcomed,—welcomer than hundreds that did get answer of some kind! The truth is I have [been]Word omitted by TC. swimming in bottomless Abysses, whipt and whirled about as man never was, for long years past; and there are still many months of it ahead:—it was after all this should have once rolled itself away, that I always meant to write to you; a free man once more (no Prussian or other rubbish crushing the life out of me); till whh fine consummation, tho’ my conscience did a little bark upon me now and then, it barked to no purpose as you have seen! This is the true history of that phenomenon; & I leave it with you.

As I said, there are months and twelvemont[h]sLetter omitted. still of that sad Prussian Operation pressing on me; and one knows not how long the foolish speechlessness might have lasted,—had it not been for a message that arrived this morning, the Letter here inclosed; which cannot brook being neglected by me. I shove Friedrich aside therefore (more luck to him); and hasten, with a bad or good grace, to do the needful.

Please read carefully that inclosed Letter from MacreadyWilliam Macready to TC, 13 April, asking for help in getting his son Edward work in Australia. to me: it will bring the whole case accurately before you; and if you can do anything in it, I will earnestly request you, for my sake withal, to do it with your best might. I know not if you are aware, as I am, that the private worth and merits of Mr Macready senior are of the highest order; a man of scrupulous veracity, correctness, integrity,—a kind of GrandisonianThe model gentlemanly hero of Samuel Richardson’s novel The History of Sir Charles Grandison (1753–54). style of magnanimity, both in substance and manner, visible in all his conduct;—I have often said, Looking at his ways as a public person: “Here is Playhouse Manager, dependent on the populace for everything; and there is no Bishop of Souls in England who dare appeal to the truth, and defy the Devil & his Angels, except this very singular “Bishop” whose diocese is Drury-Lane!”Theater district of London. In fact I greatly esteem the man; and his domestic losses and distresses (loss of an excellent noble little wife; loss of Child after Child, so soon as they grew up; loss of &c &c) have filled me and others with sympathy for him in these years.His wife, Catherine, five of their children, and his sister Letitia d. between 1850 and 1858. I add only that he is an Irishman (that his wife was Irish,—a pretty little being, whom I think he found an Actress, and whom he left a high and real gentlewoman in her sphere):They had first met in Glasgow when she was nine and already acting; between their betrothal, 1823, and their marriage, 1824, Letitia Macready took her in hand; see 11:70JWC to GW, 7 April 1839.—so that you see the whole case is Irish: and if Macready junr,Edward Macready had wanted to become a professional actor, but, encouraged by his father, he joined the East India Co. as an officer; getting into debt, he was obliged to resign his commission. Duffy described him as “a gentlemanly prepossessing young fellow, with considerable intelligence and observation” (Duffy 207). He offered him a job in the Civil Service, but Edward decided to become an actor. He continued to get into debt and cause his family concern, apparently remaining in Australia for the rest of his life (Duffy, 205–10). whom I do not know, but whose Father’s account of him I credit to the last particular, can be launched on an honest career, and made useful among his fellow creatures, it will be, on every side, in the line of your vocation.——This I think is about the substance of all I had to say; you will take it all for truth, my exactest notion of the truth: and there I must leave it with you. The young
man will appear in person, and you can take survey of him: what is fairly feasible I have no doubt you will do; and I need not repeat that it wd be pleasant to me among its other results. So enough.

The “Township of Carlyle” (more power to it!) amused us very much, and there was in it a kind of interest, pathetic and other, whh was higher than amusement. “Stuart Mill Street,” “Sterling Street” (especially Jane Street):Carlyle Township, Murray District, Victoria; see 34:54–55JWC to TC, [19 July 1858], and 67JWC to TC, [22 July 1858]. I cd almost have wept a little (had any tears now remained me) at those strange handwritings on the wall: stern and sad, the meaning of them to me, as well as laughable. In short it is a very pretty device;—and if in the chief square or place they one day put the Statue of C.G.D. himself, when he has become head of the ColonyDuffy became premier of Victoria, 1871, and was knighted, 1873. and led it into the good way (whh is far off just now!) I shall by no means be sorry.— For the rest, the Plans &c of Carlyle are firmly bound, and secured, along with a learned volume of Scottish Antiquarian Topography,David Macpherson, Geographical Illustrations of Scottish History (1796). The top edge of the first map, “Country Lots Parish of Carlyle Murray District,” is glued at the back of Macpherson; it is folded in three places with the left-hand edge of the map turned in along the bottom; on its reverse TC wrote: “This has nothing to do with the Book. Neglect this.” The second map, signed by Duffy as minister of land and works (1858–59), is “Plan of the Township of Carlyle in the Parish of Carlyle Murray District” ([May 1858]); see 72. The book and bound-in maps are in Carlyle’s House although not listed in the catalogue. and there wait till they become antique if possible. I send the most cordial regards to Mrs Callan, amiable much-suffering Lady. I am, as of old Yours truly T. Carlyle
Plan of the Township of Carlyle ([May 1858])
Courtesy of The National Trust

div3.sourceNote: TC-GEJ, 13 April. Pbd: The Diary of Alfred Domett, 1872–1885, ed. E. A. Horsman (1953) 240.
div3.head: TC TO GERALDINE E. JEWSBURY

docBody.p:
Dear Geraldine,—Thanks for the sight of Mr. Domett’s letter,Alfred Domett (1811–87; ODNB), writer, administrator, and politician; civil sec. for New Zealand, 1851; commissioner of crown lands, 1854; premier of New Zealand, 1862–63. Mantell, knowing of Domett’s admiration for TC’s writings, had sent him a photograph of Woolner’s medallion portrait of Carlyle, of which Domett wrote in 1881: “a stern, determined, yet eager and thoughtful, Roman-Emperor kind of head. … The picture which Froude has given us of the dyspeptic oversensitive, irritable, selftormenting, evermoaning and miserable, bitterly sarcastic yet actively generous and kindhearted pessimist, was entirely unconceived by me” (Domett 239). TC had signed the photograph. Mantell gave Domett’s letter (which acknowledged receipt of the photograph and praised TC) to Jewsbury, who showed it to TC. which was a pleasant little treat,—not unwholesome, we will hope, to so veteran a stomach!— Mr. Dtt gives me the image of a fine sunburnt silent considerate
Pastoral Existence, like that of the Patriarchs and Antique Populations, on modern conditions, existence tragically unattainable to us in these climates. Pity your friend and hisWalter Mantell. did not gradually gather him a £50 worth (or a £20 worth) of really genial and wise Old English Books for his reading and meditating out yonder: they might be useful to him, & be seed of one knows not how much on the other side of the world.

I never had an acquaintance of the name of Lalor or Lawlor:Lawlor was identified by Domett as a New Zealand settler who had told him he had been TC’s pupil (Domett 240); not further identified. Lr, I perceive, means a ‘T. Carlyle’Thomas Carlyle (1803–55; see 6:132TC to MAC, 18 Feb. 1832, and 29:67TC to JAC, 17 April 1854), the ninth of the apostles of the Catholic Apostolic Church; he had practiced as a lawyer in Edinburgh. (often confused with me by mistake and otherwise) who died a year or two ago, as Irvingite ‘Angel,’ or some such title, out at AlburyHe had d. at Heath House, Albury, 28 Jan. 1855. in Mr Drummond’s precircincts:Thus in MS, according to Domett, which has “[sic]” inserted. he had aspired towards various things,—a hardheaded, ambitious fanatical mortal; who used to call me Antichrist, or at least one of the Antichrists, and perhaps rather liked me notwithstanding.
docBody.name: R.
docBody.note: Thus in Domett; mistranscription, presumably by Horsman: “(Capitals, abbreviations, punctuation, &c., in the above note strictly as in the original.)” (Domett 240).
docBody.name: Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 13 April. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 13 April 1859. MS: NLS 553.192. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
West-Wickham is a pleasant very ancient and yet still modern village, 2 miles off Croydon to eastward, and about 12 southward from London;Neuberg wrote, 12 April: “I have a batch of M.S. ready to be sent off to the Berlin printer, in which one ‘Translator’s Note’ requires filling up yet: ‘The Westwickham-set,’ section of the Opposition-party, in George II’s time, to which … if you have two minutes leisure to give me two words of Etymology of that (some body’s house, or what?) my parcel could go, and Decker begin to print endlich [at last].” George II (1683–1760), king of Great Britain and Ireland, 1727–60. in whh stood, and I believe still stands (well secluded by its Park-walls and shady beeches), the Mansion of Gilbert WestGilbert West (1703–56), poet and theologian, mentioned in Frederick but without a note; see Works 15:500. Esqr an amiable ästhetisch-fromaner [aesthetic good] Herr in easy circumstances (and given to write
upon St Paul &c: “Conversion of Saint Paul;” item “Observatns on the History of the Resurrection of Jesus Christ” London (1747; also verses I think;As well as writing poetry and translating Greek poetry, West wrote Observations on the History and Evidences of the Resurrection of Jesus Christ (1747) and A Letter to G.W., and to the Author of the “Observations on St. Paul’s Conversion“ [Lord Lyttleton] (1748). but you can hide these details);—whh Gilbert, to whom I suppose they went out on Saturday &c &c, was the central figure (at least in men’s idle hands) to this group of persons. I know West Wickham well; and know whh mansion I guess to have been Gilbert’s,Untraced. tho there is nobody now about, who cd tell you with more certainty than a horse cd;—a beautiful bit of God’s Earth, all torn to pieces (inwardly, even when not outwardly as here, for the railways go all on the other side of Croydon as yet)The railway to W. Wickham opened in 1882. by sordid sooty gnomes looking after scrip and nuggets,—sorrow on them! Except for deficiency, or even total want, of swift clear brooks and streams, this is to my experience the finest part of England, or indeed of the Planet Earth for really human purposes and objects.— There are many Wickhams in England; spelt Wiccombe (High Wiccombe still a considerable Town,High Wycombe is about 40 mi. NW of London. in Buckingmshire), Wykeham “(Wm of Wykeham” founder of Winchester School, Builder of Windsor, ArchitectWilliam of Wykeham (ca. 1324–1404), bishop of Winchester and clerk of works for royal houses. He founded Winchester School and New Coll., Oxford. spiritual too, and a still memorable man after 4 centuries);—all pronounced Wick am. Name means that the place was a Roman Vicus [village] before it became a Saxon heim [hamlet].—— You need only 3 words, indeed cannot stand more;—and must pick them out of this barrowful.

I am sorry about Adelung’s Pragmatische: I fear that of Göttingen will be far too romantic;Neuberg wrote: “I have heard from Prof. Dahlmann in answer to our enquiry after Adelung. Neither he nor any acquaintance of his, nor the Bonn Library possess the Book. But he ‘does not doubt a moment’ that, if you were to apply to the Bibliothekariat in Göttingen, that learned Body would think it an honour to be helpful to a man of so ‘allgemeine auerkaunten Verdiensten’ [universal outstanding merit].” Friedrich Christoph Dahlmann (1785–1860); for Adelung, see TC to JN, 28 Feb. and indeed I see no daylight thro’ the business, except that one will have to do without,—as in many other cases.

My worst news is, a very bad fit of cold whh has come upon my poor Wife again. She caught it (as I did a dose too) in that sudden burst of heat we had, inducing one to strip too suddenly. A very bad fit indeed; the worst I have known for long years, if ever; nor can I say with the least confidence that the worst of it is yet over. Come down on Sunday Evg (unless I write to the contrary), and see for yourself.

I have heard nothing of Prints from Magnus or any one;Neuberg had written that Eduard Magnus “fares but badly in his search after Portraits; there being so few. Has sent 2 or 3 with a Catalogue of others, (addressed to you direct, I suppose?).” pray tell him not to bother;—this too I must do without. The stupidity of mankind, in the past times and also the present, as to what things they “collect” and what things they don’t, is very considerable;—nor is this the only way they shew that sad quality in these Fields not Elysian where I now am, and I believe, in others.—God Above deliver me once out of this, alive; and see if all the universe cd persuade me in again!

One small thing practicable is, A Box of Mitchell’s Steel Pens “J”;See TC to WMT, 9 April. pray remember that for Sunday Evg. Item to bring back the Preuss, the Helden-leben the &c,Possibly Johann David Erdmann Preuss, Die Lebensgeschichte des grossen Königs Friedrich von Preussen, 2 vols. (Berlin, 1837); see 33:115TC to EC, 13 Nov. 1857; TC’s copy: HCC; also Helden-, Staats-, und Lebens-Geschichte des allerdurchlauchtigsten und grossmächtigsten Fürsten und Herrns, Friedrichs des Andern, 11 vols. (Frankfurt, 1758–64); see 33:22TC to KAVE, 12 Aug. 1857; TC’s copy: HCC. if you have done with them for the prest (not otherwise): I never know when I shall not be sent hunting rearward into some of them. Pretty much my one wish is, I could say to them: “Adieu forevermore my Dears: dwell peaceable in Chaos thro’ all Eternity for me!”
No more at present. Yours always truly T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CB [CBU], 13 and 14 April. MS: EUL. Pbd: Southern 267–68 inc. Quot: F. H. Stoddard, The Life and Letters of Charles Butler (New York, 1903) 328–29.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES BUTLER

docBody.p:
On reading your letter again before sending off the Adamson message I spoke of, other lights began to glimmer out on me from the bottom of the business, other care that perhaps was going to be needed from you:—and I decided not to send off that message to Adamson, but simply to bid him forward me the £1,000, and be ready if you shd have anything to say to him.Butler replied, 3 May: “The sober second and proper business thought of your letter of the 13th quite relieved me as I am sure you would have found the machinery proposed in your letter of 8th cumbrous & possibly expensive. The methods of remittance between the two countries are now so simple and the facilities of intercourse so constant and rapid that you may consider New York but at the other end of a steam ferry” (Kimball 287); for TC’s earlier proposal, see TC to CBCBU, 8 April. He sent the money yesterday; yesterday I left it with my London BankerSmith, Payne & Smiths, Lombard St. to
pay thro’ the Union BankUnion Bank of London, Lombard St. in the way you direct (whh I made him copy); and today there is to come the “Certificate” or Receipt presentable by you to the “Messrs Duncan Sherman and Co New York,”Bankers, Wall St., New York.—whh I will inclose in this Note and instantly dispatch: I shall then have done with the matter. Please signify to me by some sign that the Money has come safe: I shall then feel no more concern abt it, but leave you to do wholly what your wisdom and kindness suggest in regard to the thing. You see well how totally inexperienced, and averse, I am in such finances: if you can make Adamson do for me, well; but if not, or not without too much trouble, then manage your own way,—whh I shall well believe to be the best that was devisable for me in the matter.

I am in these months particularly held down, and indeed more laden than you can conceive with that intolerable load of Prussian rubbish (whh has many times seemed as if it would really choke the life out of me before I got done with it): let this be my excuse for all short comings; if I do live to get honestly out of this sad whirling Abyss of Brandenburg dust and ashes, I promise to be an idler and a better boy for the remaining days appointed me.
When the Certificate arrives, I will mark the fact, before enclosing and sealing. I remain, Dear Sir,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p:
Charles Butler Esq. N. Yk
(t.o.)

Wedny morning, 14 April. Not till now did the Document come; but here it now is, all in proper form I think,—and truly a very simple straight operation it has been, in contradiction to my recluse fancyings! I enclose it, with my blessings; and wish you a happy deliverance,—flying back to my Prussian rubbish.— T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 14 April. MS: NLS 516.67. Quot: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:212; Southern 268.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I have despatched the Butler £1,000,See TC to CBCBU, 13 April. in the way you recommended, or at least have it all sealed and ready for despatching; the “trouble” at last amounted to nothing, for the Bankers here did it all for me & sent the final
Document by Post:—yet you have no conception what a hole in my own poor feckless peculiar operation such a slight business made. Alas the fabric of my efforts is of weak description at present; and needs only little to make a big hole in it!— More power to me!

The Ziethen Print is no doubt a fellow copy, with German title, of the one you saw here with a French: it was cheap enough in all conscience; and, tho’ not reckoned a good Chodowiecki,For Chodowiecki’s Ziethen print, see TC to JN, 11 Feb. will deserve framing. On the rear or elsewhere there is, or shd be, a key to the figures; that is the chief use of mine to me (especially since I brot the key round to the front, and see everybody handily labelled):—if your key is lost any way, it may be worth your while to copy this of mine when you get near it again.

I cannot manage to find an Adelung, however I dun for it in Germy thro’ Neuberg and otherwise:See TC to JN, 28 Feb. I shall have to do witht that help too; I find many helps in that case for me:—make the utmost of what helps one has; there is no other refuge. I cannot describe to you how I long to be delivered from this sad task; or how small, amid the given conditions, my visible progress is! On the whole, however, I am in secret perhaps making progress: a mountain of dust ashes and cinders has all to be smelted by heat and fuel of one’s own (for in every item it is chaotic incoherent); and the little bit of metal is a dreadful business to extract, in the circumstances I am in.

Poor Jane, I grieve to say, as the worst item of all, has broken down at last: in that outburst of almost july heat last week but one, she stripped too suddenly, gradually got into a bad cold (accumulated peccancies, I have perceived, were there at any rate); and for the last four days, sleepless, foodless, coughing, tormented somehow in the region of the heart, she has been as ill as I ever saw her. Not till this morning pretty late, cd I flatter myself with the least sign of improvet; but now I do strive to believe we are round the corner again. She has eaten a particle of white-fish (her one demand), and is lying quiet, with here and there a moment of sleep, whh is better than none.— I myself got a whiff of cold, on the same occasion; but it has not grown worse; a good ride yesterday (poor horse in galloping humour, over in Surrey) did it good.

I meant to ask you if Cressfield House Furnished was still to let;Cressfield House in Ecclefechan, built by TC’s father, for rent in July 1858; see 34:77TC to JWC, 28 July 1858.—or if there were any such attainable for summer coming. I find I could, for a certain part of my work, pack the necessary Books in something like compendious shape; and write in the country. At all events to gather a little strength there wd be very furthersome both for self and partner. You know what we want; at least you & Jamie could make it all out, if you were together. “Horse-
exercise (for both), abundt milk” &c.— Poor Jane cd not front much bother with servants; but this little LassCharlotte Southam. here wd accompany, & be excellt in her inside place. Alas, we are both of us less fit for bother; and a little stronger only on the money side! No more at prest. Turn that over & write abt it. Is Isabella better?Isabella Carlyle, TC’s sister-in-law, d. 1 June. Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CWW, 15 April. MS: NLS 23167.132. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLOTTE WILLIAMS WYNN

docBody.p: I am sorry to tell you, by order of my poor Wife, that she is quite too ill for writing;—indeed confined close to bed these two or three days, and suffering a great deal, tho’ now better slightly than at one time. This is too true aThus in MS. tale! The business was cold (caught in that outburst of july heat the other week), of which I too got my share: but nothing at all to hers,—indeed for two days (till yesterday morning) she was worse than I ever remember to have seen her.

There has an eloquent volume come to me this day, by a certain Peter Bayne:Peter Bayne (1830–96; ODNB), ed. of The Witness, 1856–62, and misc. writer; in the preface to the 1st edn. of The Christian Life, Social and Individual (Edinburgh, 1855), Bayne had been very critical of TC’s religious views. He had sent TC the book, and TC had “answered in a kind manner,” then forwarded Bayne’s letter and the book to Jean Aitken; see 29:339TC to JCA, 25 June 1855. Bayne had added a new preface to the 2d edn. (now being sent to Charlotte Williams Wynn), “Genius and Influence of Carlyle.” He proposed setting “in clearer contrast than formerly what I regard as good and serviceable, and what I deem evil and pernicious”; he then listed: “first, certain qualities of his genius which render his rejection of Christianity to some extent accountable, but void of even a show of authority; next, what contributions may be safely accepted from him to intellectual, and even moral progress; and, thirdly, how potent the error of preferring, at the crisis of his moral and intellectual history, the vague sublimity of the pantheist to the divine simplicity of Christ, has been to injure and derange the action of his intellect” (vii). He emphasized the importance of Carlyle’s contributions to Christian teaching: “Never sceptic saw so far into the meaning of Christianity as Mr Carlyle; never sceptic set so generously the Christian hero at the top of greatness. … From such a man we need not turn away when he earnestly enforces truths of natural religion” (xxviii). whh I judge will suit you much better than me. Pray accept it from me at any rate.— Yours ever truly
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Bayne Eloquence goes by the same post

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 15 April. MS: Univ. of Toronto. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO AN UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: I am grieved to think how far ahead of us that kind Proposal of yours lies at present! I have not, for years past, been out to any dinner; and in late days there has a severe fit of Cold fallen on the two principal parties here (especially on the weaker of them) which much aggravates the obstructed circumstances.

ps.p: You do not say whether you got that Appointment?Unidentified. I shd have been glad of an affirmation on that side.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 19 April. MS: NLS 1796.97. Pbd: Sanders, “Carlyle’s Letters to Ruskin” 215; Cate 81.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: We are in great misery here: my poor Wife, after escaping all winter, has fallen into the worst Cold I have ever seen her have; and suffers very much; weak too as an infant,—tho’, I strive to flatter myself, not growing worse, but contrariwise. I caught a Cold on the same occasion (late paroxysm of july-december weather),—or rather renewed a cold I have always obscurely had since a “bathe in the Baltic” last autumn:During TC’s stay on the Isle of Rügen with the von Usedoms, Aug. 1858; see 34:170TC to JWC, 5 Sept. 1858. but I try to keep it at the staff’s end, and do not hitherto allow it to interfere with business. Absolute silence being the rule here just now.— I will come riding out to Denmark Hill,SE London, where Ruskin lived. on Thursday (day after tomorrow): and call you over the coalsTo scold, or take to task for one’s shortcomings. for half an hour, if you will be at home. Near 5 p.m;—no, let us say “4.20 or so,” and be away before 5 again. Don’t write, unless you have something to object.

That hovering about, and circling among the eddies, is not a pleasant process; but you will (to your astonishment perhaps) have various bouts of that kind in your wide voyage; and they are not unsalutary, still less can be dispensed with, tho’ so disagreeable to the natural manPossibly a response to Ruskin’s undated letter to TC and JWC: “When may I come & see you? / Friday—Saturday. Monday. A Tuesday-evening? / —— / I’ve been in Yorkshire—In, also, lands of figurative Rock and moor—hard work—& peat bog puzzle— / —— / No end visible. / —— / Not getting on with German. / —— / Frederick yet unread. / —— / Nothing done. / —— / All sorts of things gone worse undone—stitches Run down. Entirely dim notions about what Ought to be done.— Except—that I ought to come & tell you all about it” ([late March / early April?]). Ruskin had been in Yorkshire until 17 March.

If the Natural Man is totally at a loss for a career, let him read with attention this American Letter whh came this morning;—surely that opens a career talem qualem [of whatever kind]! As the Letter is & not to be answered, you can burn it for the poor young Lady’sUnidentified. sake.

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: Woolner records a meeting with Ruskin at Cheyne Row, probably in May, before the Carlyles had decided on going to Scotland for the summer: “I went and spent a long evening with Carlyle on Monday last: he was not in good spirits; in fact he has not been at all well since that laborious continental journey last year, the details of which he told me, and I do not wonder at his discomfiture. I tried hard to persuade him to cut work altogether for a few months, on the plea that it would be all the better for his book, and he confessed that he had not done so much in three months as he was accustomed to do in so many weeks when in a higher tone of health. … Mrs. Carlyle absolutely needs country air, for she has been unwell for a long time, and I did not see her on that evening. … Ruskin came in while I was there and commenced a buzz of inflated rapture upon a piece of charlatanry called ‘Victory,’ by Marochetti, now being shown at Apsley House. … Ruskin’s inflation was met in a manner that I think one so utterly good and kind as you [Emily Tennyson] could not with your utmost efforts imagine; but we certainly gave that conceited creature something to reflect upon. When he was gone we both agreed that a man who took Marochetti as his ideal sculptor, Louis Napoleon as his favourite king and politician, and Spurgeon for his best beloved theologian, was certainly an unsafe guide for women and the youths of England; for besides these, his trusting admirers are few” (Woolner 183). Carlo Marochetti (1805–67; ODNB), Italian sculptor, moved permanently to England, 1848; “Victory” (part of a planned monument for Arthur Wellesley [1769–1852], duke of Wellington, which was not commissioned) was installed in the garden of Apsley House, late April. Charles Haddon Spurgeon (18321834–92; ODNB), Baptist preacher and religious writer. TC disliked Napoleon III intensely; see TC to JN, 21 July.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Earl of R [EOR], 20 April. MS: offered for sale by John Wilson, Witney, England, summer 1982. TC and Ripon (previously Lord Goderich) rode regularly in Hyde Park; see TC to EC, 13 Nov. 1857.
div3.head: TC TO THE EARL OF RIPON

docBody.p: [Expressing TC’s regret that he has unluckily engaged himself for tomorrow and fears that his “Horse will be too much tired by that operation for a smart ride on Friday,” and proposing therefore—though he should go if Friday is “your only day“—alternative times “Saturday 3½ p.m.; Sunday 2 p.m. (note 2); Monday 3½. &c … ,” which “are all open, in the usual course.“]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 20 April. MS: NLS 516.68. Quot: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:212.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN
