docBody.p: Don’t make me those beneficent Flannel-shirts: I have at present not the least need of them, having already a stock for winter, and a do for summer, all quite fit for their function; besides you could not (without the linen or cotton model, whh poor Jane has locked by) have any possibility of fitting me with that uncertain material;—and, alas, my poor Missus is far indeed from being able to help you in it just now!

She is close in her bed, with a Doctor watching over her,—rather sensible kind of man, who comes daily, and gives little or no medicine, but prescribes food (or attempts at food), and above all things, absolute silence and the steady endeavour to give a chance for rest.Dr. Alfred Brooke Barnes. For JWC’s illness, see also JWC to MR, [12 May]. He does not seem alarmed about her general state; but says that of all the patients he has had she is the most excitable, and is so weak in bodily respects that she amazes him. As weak as an infant, poor little soul; and loaded daily (not in these days only) with such a burden of suffering; whh she bears without quarrelling with it more!—Yesterday I did not see her except once, so strict was her order for seclusion.Jewsbury had heard that JWC was ill and wrote to Mantell, 20 April: “I went yesterday and found the knocker nailed down, the doctor in attendance & the sullenest of answers from the little maid of all works & minister of domestic affairs. … [A]t night I went round to Carlyle to ask him how things had come to such a pass. I was in very depressed spirits & never expected him to do anything to raise them.” But TC was kindly and made Jewsbury drink tea with him; she was touched by his “two or three little words of sympathy” and went away “quite cheered up.” Mantell sent the note on to Domett; see The Diary of Alfred Domett, [1872—[1885, ed. E. A. Horsman [1853] 240–41. She sleeps very little, but not absolutely none; it is the same with her eating.—I flatter myself, and the medical man flatters me, with the hope of seeing her fairly on the mending hand (as indeed, we hope she already intrinsically is) in the course of a few days more.

I myself have a good deal of cold; but I bathe, go riding &c: and, tho’ with more pain than usual, do not feel more feckless or overclouded. Could I but get on with my Affair, whh is my one excuse for continuing in the world (as I often feel in my grim moods)! But of course one has not a very fair field, as you see:—the clearer one’s duty to make the best use of what field there is!—Let me to work therefore!

Cressfield House is already occupied.See TC to JAC, 14 April. The thing we might want in that kind would be a good tight lodging place (no great size requisite), among wholesome green quietudes; near friends, near shops, and capable without
much bother of furnishing milk &c in abundance, and keep (and especially groomage) for a Horse. Both of us depend on the Horse, either saddled or else yoked. Near Dumfries, I shd say,—some of those woody Hillsides behind Cargen,Cargenholm was a house, approx. 3 mi. S of Dumfries, and Cargen a stream; see 25:296TC to JCA, 30 Nov. 1850. or the like? Sea is as nothing to the above indispensabilities. Alas, we can stand no bother; we are not now called to be anxious abt money, but in all other respects we are fallen lower than before.— Enough, if you do hear of anything suitable, look into it a little. That is all we can do. Adieu, dear Sister Ever your Affecte T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 25 April. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 25 April 1859. MS: NLS 553.193. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Here is the Portrait-CatalogueSent by Eduard Magnus; see TC to JN, 13 April. (goes by this same Post) in a final conditn: I did not get it fairly re-examined till last night: A distinct cross (X) stands agt all the articles I now want out of it; the ”?” marks, where negative, are (unless by omission) crossed out:—and for more distinctness, I enclose you the list as marked in pencil while I went on.— Several of those others I shd have liked to have: but they are extremely difficult to dispose of when got;—Borck, for example, my beautiful Borck, I am looking out for somebody to take it off my hand gratis: to me it is rather a minus quantity, tho’ so superior otherwise. Whisper nothing abt that, or the like, to the good Magnus!— I find there are just 2 Portraits (unless Ziethen’s be excellt, and form a 3d) in the list now sent that are essential: Belling (the Anti-Swedish Genl), and Brühl of the many tailors;Wilhelm Sebastian von Belling (1719–79), Prussian gen. during the Seven Years’ War; see Works 18:431. Count Heinrich von Brühl (1700–1763), chief adviser and later prime minister to August Friedrich (1696–1763), king of Poland and elector of Saxony; see Works 16:76. the latter especially, of whom I cd never see any Print whatever.——And now we will leave the chase of Frh-Soldier Prints:There are no portraits of Frederick’s generals or of Brühl in Frederick. es geht nicht [it’s impossible]; clearly enough there are none attainable to us; on this side, as on so many others, the answer is, “You must do without”!— “Blessed are they who can do without; for their talent will not be kept sleeping.”Cf. Matt. 5:3–11.

We are a little better here; my Wife very considerably, tho’ still in bed and
as weak as water,—in fact I do not remember to have seen her in such a fit of overwhelming pain and weakness as had come over her on this occasion. I have gone about on my usual rounds, tho’ more as a shadow than a substance: seldom was there a more ineffectual heavy-laden week appointed me than last. I think my Cough is going, however; and I feel determined to have another bit of duel with my Evil Genius (namely my Prussian Problem, and be hanged to it!)—file, file steadily with the poorest implement upon your accursed slave-chain, you will get thro’ it at last, and out of the nasty degrading Galley where you have sat among the pots, and rowed, and been whipt, so long. Oh Heaven, Oh Heaven!

Come next sunday Evg if you hear nothing to the contrary.— Some day in the week, you might call at Wms & Norgate’s (to whom I have sent a new message, with new “Yes, surely Yes!” for ansr), and try to ascertain what chance there is for the exquisite Adelung & his 10 quartos?For Adelung, see TC to JN, 28 Feb.; there were nine vols., divided into 10 quartos.— Yours always truly T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [26 April]. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 27 April 1859. MS: NLS 553.194. Hitherto unpbd. Tues. was 26 April. TC’s letter is written on the back of Williams & Norgate to TC, 26 April.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I have ordered the people to send me this incomplete CopyWilliams & Norgate had found a copy in Germany of vols. 1–8 of Adelung’s Staats-Geschichte Europens (see TC to JN, 28 Feb.) and asked him to confirm that he wanted the 8 vols. even though vol. 9 was missing. as soon as possible. You need not call, therefore,—unless it be quite handy;—but in case you do, ask when it is likely to come; and try if you can discover (in the Bibliographies whh Wms & Norgate have) what years the missing volume relates to? If to 1760 or the like, I shall care little about the want of it.— And report on Sunday Evg.

We continue to keep improving tho’ slowly;—and I am near the end of Book II; getting on a little better for the moment! I entreat the Fates you were free again to bear a helping hand. But we must wait.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Tuesday Evg

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 4 May. MS: NLS 516.69. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:196.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—You need not give yourself much or any farther bother abt Dunlop’sWilliam Dunlop’s half-brother (see note 5); otherwise unidentified. Possibly one of the Dunlops who had suggested a house for rent near Lythe, Yorkshire, in June 1858; see 33:244TC to JAC, 18 June 1858. affair, except to shake him and it handsomely loose again. The Glaisters-Blackmark TerritoryThe area between Glaisters, approx. 4 mi. S, and Blackmark, approx. 2 mi. W of Craigenputtoch. in question is scarcely worth any money at all; and to my (ignorant) fancy it wd almost be a question whether if a gift were made of it, the prize wd be worth fencing with dry-dike, on such terms as mine wd be!—— It were of course rather good that the two Properties were bounded by the Highway,The main road, presumably resurfaced to make it a “Highway” as not a new road, from Dumfries to Castle Douglas in Kirkcudbrightshire was ½ mi. away. now that there is one; and a few pounds wd not be grudged by me for that object;TC had recently heard from Adamson about Craigenputtoch business that would raise rather than cost money. Samuel Adamson (b. 1832), Robert Adamson’s nephewson, had advertised in the Dumfries and Galloway Courier, 8 and 15 March: “About 2000 Cut trees, principally LARCH, some of them suitable for Railway Sleepers with some OLD SCOTCH and SPRUCE FIRS, at CRAIGENPUTTOCH. … Mr. John Common, the Tenant, will point out the Wood.” Robert Adamson wrote, 24 March, listing the offers from £80 to £210 for the trees: “I would recommend the last offer to be accepted and that their Bill should be taken for the £210 payable six months after date. // I consider the price offered very high and the remaining Wood will improve by the want of those cut. The expence of cutting &c will be somewhere from £20 to £25 I think, so that I hope you will consider the Transaction a renumerative one”; see also 34:117TC to JWC, [10 Aug. 1858]. TC made a calculation on Adamson’s envelope: “Crh Woods March 1859 / £210–25 = £185” (MS: NLS 20752). JWC had inherited Craigenputtoch from her father, but TC, as her husband, was the owner. He noted in his checkbook, 27 March, that JWC was to get £50 for “Putth Woods” (MS: NLS 20752); he wrote a check, 27 March, which was not cashed, on the reverse of which he noted four separate payments that were made to JWC: 5 Oct., £10; 29 Nov., £20; 29 Sept. 1860, £10; 8 April 1861, £10 (MS: NLS 20753). but I think they wd require to be very few, as that is the waste of wastes according to all recollection I have of it! Act on that view,—suppressing the emphasis used here; whh indeed even abstinence from farther action will sufftly do, if otherwise advisable. Unbeschreiblich ruhig [inexpressibly quiet] we may remain under this offer of increased dominions in the Planet Earth!—

On comparing notes, I find this Dunlop will be the Half-Brother of the once famous and always rather likeable “Teeger Wull”“Tiger” is inserted above the line in the MS. JWC’s cousin William Dunlop (1792–1848; see 5:70JWC to EA, 5 Feb. 1830, and 30:163–64JWC’s Notebook, 13 April 1845). William’s parents were Alexander Dunlop (1766–1840) and Janet Graham (1769–95); an Alexander Dunlop m. Margaret Colhoun of Renfrew, 24 Sept. 1796, in Greenock; this might be this Dunlop’s mother. (who died, a rough
Eremite, in Canada, some years ago);—who always esteemed this relative at a very low figure (“Canting, hardhearted, hypocritical sneak,” said the plain-spoken Tiger, and wd have no trade with him more or less);—whether justly or not we need not trouble ourselves inquiring: he can rest on the above basis, his Proposal & he.
Jane continues slowly improving, in spite of the weather; has been out a little in the Drawing room these two days,—always on the sofa, close wrapt; and able to read light matter at intervals.

Did not I send you Mill’s Essay on Liberty? I meant it; and do not now find the Book here.TC had apparently lent it to Neuberg; see TC to JN, [24? Feb.]. In my life I have never read a serious ingenious clear logical EssayMill argued that “the sole end for which mankind are warranted, individually or collectively, in interfering with the liberty of action of any of their number, is self-protection. … His own good, either physical or moral, is not a sufficient warrant” (J. M. Robson, ed., Collected Works of John Stuart Mill [Toronto, 1977] 18:223). In an implied criticism of TC, he denounced “the sort of ‘hero-worship’ which applauds the strong man of genius for forcibly seizing on the government of the world and making it do his bidding in spite of itself” (18:269). with more perfect and profound dissent from the basis it rests upon, and most of the conclusions it arrives at. Very strange to me indeed; a curious monition to me what a world we are in! As if it were a sin to control, or coerce into better methods, human swine in any way;—as if the greater and the more universal the “liberty” of human creatures of the Swine genus, the more fatal all-destructive and intolerable were not the “Slavery” the few human creatures of the man genus are thereby thrown into, and kept groaning powerless under.Larkin reported visiting TC when he had a copy of On Liberty in front of him: “he rose angrily from the table with the book in his hand, and gave vent to such a torrent of anathema (glancing at Christianity itself, as if Christianity had been the inspiration of it), as filled me with pain and amazement. He addressed himself directly to me, almost as if I had written the book, or had sent it to him, or was in some way mixed up with it in his mind. I felt terribly hurt; but what could I say in protest against such a wide-rushing torrent of invective?” (Larkin, BQR 73). Ach Gott im Himmel!

Tomorrow, if I have time to wrap it, you shall have Buckle’s Io-Paean [high praise] upon Mill,Henry Thomas Buckle (1821–62; ODNB), historian, admired by Mill as a popularizer of important ideas. Buckle wrote that Mill’s defense of liberty was “drawn from the most exalted region of thought” but is “applicable to the common transactions of daily life” (H. Buckle, “Mill on Liberty,” Fraser’s Magazine 59 [May 1859]: 516).—not read by me but guessed to be the loudest30-ass power utterance yet heard on the subject.— Adieu, in haste. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[SL] [SLA], 5 May. MS: Manuscript Section, Lund University Library, Sweden. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee identified by note in TC’s checkbook: “5 May 1859, Langley (Muse/um quarrying) / £3..0..0” (MS: NLS 20753).
div3.head: TC TO [SAMUEL LANGLEY]

docBody.p: I find you have quarried honestly in that affair of George Second’s Austrian-Succession War;The War of Austrian Succession, 1740–48, was about the right of Maria Theresa, archduchess of Austria, to succeed to the Hapsburg dominions; see 30:13TC to JN, 28 July 1855. George II commanded the British, Hanoverian, and other troops that defeated the French at the battle of Dettingen, 1743; see also TC to [SL][SLA], 11 May. and brought up a variety of curious things,—whh might be more valuable to many a one than they are to me, tho’ to me also they are not all without value.

I send you £3 whh you hint will be of value at present;TC had previously sent Langley a check for £2; see TC to [SL][SLA], 14 March. I wish you to expend that new amount by labour on the thing,—continuing to Peace of Aix-la-Chapelle the end of it:Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle, signed 18 Oct. 1748, ended the War of Austrian Succession.—that amount and no more. Being in extremity of haste, I can only note the following points for guidance of you:
1. First in any future Extracts to be so good as write only on one side of the Paper.

2. In regard to Dettingen & Fontenoy, to consult the Duke of Cumberland’s LifeHistorical Memoirs of His Late Royal Highness William-Augustus, Duke of Cumberland (1767), attrib. to Richard Rolt, was one of the sources TC used for the battles of Dettingen and Fontenoy; see 30:13TC to JN, 28 July 1855, and Works 15:425–34 and 16:92–104. TC’s copy of the book (signed “T. Carlyle / Chelsea, 1859—”; NLS F.5.f.20) contains extensive marginal notes, and fragments of paper with additional notes glued in the front, showing both exasperation and humor in correcting the book’s inaccuracies, and giving cross-references to other works; for an example, see opp.above (mentioned to you before), and to understand that everything there is already mine.
Example of TC’s marginalia on Historical Memoirs of His Late Royal Highness William-Augustus, Duke of Cumberland (1767)
Historical Memoirs of His Late Royal Highness William-Augustus, Duke of Cumberland

3. Not to forget the Rendezvous at Finchley (March to Fi[nchley)]MS torn. or whatever they call it, subject of Hogarth’s Print,“The March to Finchley, December 1750”; see Hogarth, The Complete Engravings, text and engravings by Joseph Burke and Colin Caldwell (1968) plate 223. George II is said to have refused the original dedication by William Hogarth (1697–1764), who satirized the plan to introduce stricter discipline in the army on the Prussian model. Hogarth dedicated the third and subsequent engravings to Frederick the Great.—1745 if I rember).Thus in MS.

4. Any details about the Return of the Troops from the Netherlands (a
horrid puddle of misery and mismanagement, as I understand) might be perhaps of use to me.For TC’s comments on the British army after the battle of Fontenoy, see Works 16:103–4.
And so I leave you to your own fidelity and good sense.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-FMB, 5 May. MS: Hilles. Pbd: Ford Madox Brown 163.
div3.head:
TC
TO FORD MADOX BROWN

docBody.p:
I think it pity you had not put (or should not still put) some other man than me into your Great Picture:Ford Madox Brown’s Work, painted 1852–65. Brown had been a great admirer of TC’s writings for many years. TC’s philosophy of work, as both social duty and source of personal fulfillment, as well as his criticisms of modern industrial society, capitalism, and utilitarianism, formed the intellectual basis of Brown’s painting. it is certain you could hardly have found among the Sons of Adam, at present, any individual who is less in a condition to help you forward with it, or take interest in it active or passive. I was never in my days so overwhelmed, and l[ost] MS torn. miles deep in the belly of an ugly Enterprise, too heavy in sad truth for the strength I have left, as even now:—Jonah in the Whale’s BellyJonah 1:17. but a type of me, in those sad months and years!—
Ford Madox Brown, Work
Courtesy of Manchester Art Gallery
I very well remember your amiable request; and the promise I made you, to “sit for some photograph.” That promise I will keep;—and to that we must restrict ourselves, law of Necessity compelling.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 5 May. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / N. B. PM: London, 5 May 1859. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 36:267–68, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am very sorry to hear that Isabella is so poorly,Isabella Carlyle had been seriously ill for several weeks and d. 1 June; see 35:95TC to JC, 20 May 1859.—that you are in distress at Scotsbrig as we are here. John’sJames Carlyle’s second son, John. Letter, the other day, was but conformable to what the DoctorJohn A. Carlyle. has been frequently telling us; his last account, yesterday, is, that there does not seem to be yet any considerable improvement: but he seems to expect all things from the weather coming round to its summer pitch;—and indeed one cannot doubt but that would do us all a great deal of good, and be particularly beneficial to poor weak creatures who are suffering from too thin a skin in this world.— It has been such a winter for sluggish heat, and such an April (& May hitherto) for venomous cold, as I hardly remember to have seen before. Today and yesterday the wind has fallen, & the sun come out; but all is still easterly winterly; and I doubt we have not yet done with the affair; tho’ after a few more clashes it surely must go.

I suppose you heard how poor Jane was knocked down, by the April paroxysms of weather,JWC had caught a cold during a “sudden burst of heat” in April; see 35:74TC to JN, 13 April 1859.—or rather perhaps it was only in these, for the causes had been accumulating long before. I never saw her as ill;—in wild misery for the first days, and then so weak, weak as an infant. She is now fairly a good deal recovered, and steadily growing better; yet obliged mainly to keep her bed, and as weak as need be, tho’ gathering strength too. A DrDr. Alfred Brooke Barnes. of the neighbourhood, whom she had seen prescribe before, was called in; and he has really proved a helpful kind of man.

I had a nasty cold, myself, too, at first; but that is mainly gone, ten days ago,
tho’ there is still something coughy about me,—which indeed I got in Germany last autumn:TC had caught a cold while visiting Baron and Baroness von Usedom at Carsitz during his German tour of 1858; see 34:173TC to JWC, 5 Sept. 1858. a terrible smashing and trashing that German affair was to me altogether! I pull along at this sad job of mine; but it is in a spavined manner, and with mud to the axle-tree: my progress very bad indeed. If only 3 miles aday, it is better than nothing. If I ever get to the end of it (whh is conceivable sometimes), I design to lie idle for the rest of my natural life!— I do hope always for Two months of Scotsbrig under Isabella’s care,—some time or other:—but you see how far that is from us, on both heads, at present!

The Craigenputtoch woodsTC had sold some wood from the Craigenputtoch estate; see 35:84TC to JAC, 4 May 1859. did very well: honestly cut (I am informed), charge abt £30; sticks sold (by private bargain, Adamson managing all) for £200. Curious, one man offered £85 for the lot; another £115; two others (Dumfries people) each £200: these were the 4 offers.Robert Adamson, TC’s Dumfries banker, had listed the offers, 24 March 1859: “J. Donaldson, Dalry £80 / John Martin, Castle Douglas £112 / Samuel Willet, Dumfries £210 / James & John Sloan Do [ditto] £210”; he recommended the last offer “be accepted and that their Bill should be taken for the £210 payable six months after date” (MS: NLS 20752). Your Journey and mine, that day,TC had visited Craigenputtoch, in his capacity as owner, with James, 5 Aug. 1858; see 34:99–101TC to JWC, 6 Aug. 1858. was not useless you useless, you see.Thus in MS; at the turn of the page. It is possible there may be another needed by & by; many are they you have made for me! Adieu dear Brother. Let us hope all will be better with us in a short time! I send my affectionate regards to old & young. Yours T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-FMB, 10 May. MS: Robert G. Heyneman. Pbd: Ford Madox Brown 163–64.
div3.head:
TC
TO FORD MADOX BROWN

docBody.p:
I propose coming up to Mr Thomson’s Photographic Establishment on Thursday (day after tomorrow), as the first part of my afternoon’s walk,—if you will meet me there, and have the job in readiness for my appearance
there. I set forth at 3½ p.m.; if we give half an hour for the journey, we may appoint 4 p.m. as the hour for beginning business.For the photograph, see opp above. It includes the frame used to steady the subject during the long exposure necessary indoors. If the day is actually rainy,—that is to say, rain without interval,—I shall understand that it will not do; but that I must return on the morrow.
Thomas Carlyle, by Charles Thompson, 12 May 1859
Courtesy of Birmingham Museums and Art Gallery

You will have to tell me, however, where the place specially is:—I vaguely understand it to be at or in what they call “the Brompton Boilers”;Land had been purchased in Brompton, 1855, for the S. Kensington Museum; its first building of corrugated iron and steel was opened 27 June 1857 and soon nicknamed Brompton Boilers because its buildings resembled steam boilers lying on the ground; see above. The museum was less than a mi. from Cheyne Row. but I never was within the circuit of that Establisht; & shd like to know, What door &c, and whether simply asking for “Mr Thompson Photographer”Charles Thompson had been superintendent of photography since 1856 at the Department of Science and Art, which had become the S. Kensington Museum. will suffice.—— Please, a word upon this, in the course of tomorrow (Wedy); and for the rest, consider it settled as above on my part, the hour 4, the &c &c.

figure.p: The Iron Museum at South Kensington Watercolor by J. C. Lanchenick, ca. 1863

p.hi: The Iron Museum at South Kensington

div3.sourceNote: TC-[SL] [SLA], 11 May. MS: Pierpont Morgan Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee conjecturally identified as Samuel Langley, who was helping TC with research on George II and the “Austrian-Succession War.“
div3.head: TC TO [SAMUEL LANGLEY]

docBody.p: In the year 1741 (year before all those adventures you are putting on record for me) George II had an Army rallied in Germany, Danes, Hessians, Hanoverians, and intended to join them with a Body of English; that so he might strike in with effect, that year, between the King of Prussia & the Austrian Sovereign.George II, elector of Hanover as well as king of Great Britain, enthusiastically supported Maria Theresa’s claim to the Hapsburg dominions; see also TC to [SL][SLA], 5 May. He raised money to help her (Works 15:93); he also raised an army in Hanover (Works 15:202) and in England (Works 15:201–2) to aid her in her fight against Frederick II and his French allies. The French checkmated him (29 Septr, 1741),While George II’s army in Hanover was being threatened by the Prussian forces encamped at Götten, a French army arrived from the S, forcing George to agree to a truce in order not to lose Hanover; see Works 15:262–63. and he could not, that year,—not till gradually at late season next year (1742), as you have seen This Army of 1741 is, to me, rather more important than the other of 1742,In 1742 George II tried a second time to get an army into the field in support of Maria Theresa (Works 15:372). This also failed to achieve anything. On his third attempt in 1743, he won a victory against the French at the battle of Dettingen, about which TC commented: “After which he feels better” (Works 15:200). just at present; and there is if possible still less light attainable upon it out of any English Book I can consult.

In various German Books I read, that, in “April 1741,” he had a “Camp,” of Danes &c and Hanoverians, Camp at “Hameln” (a little south of Hanover Town),Hameln was about 10 mi. S of Hanover; see Works 15:202. then vaguely at some other place (name forgotten) in the same Territory;—and furthermore that he had (same April 1741) made “a Camp” somewhere on the “Coast of Kent,” and was reviewing and rendezvousing English Forces there, with whom he intended to sail over, and join his Dane-Hanoverian people. It is this last point, the “Camp on the Coast of Kent”The camp was not on the coast of Kent but was at Lexden Heath, nr. Colchester, Essex; see Works 15:201–2. April (or so) 1741, that I wish to be informed about. The other facts (Camp of Danes &c in Hanover Territory, at “Hameln” or elsewhere) are indubitable to me, and clear enough for my purpose: but for this of the Kent Camp I shd like to have some precise English evidence, and any notable feature of it (if notable any be) pointed out to me.

Will you, therefore, as the first thing after the Museum opens, look out a little in that direction,—a
little, not much, for in fact it is but a side matter to me,—and ascertain date & place of this English camp: “Coast of Kent” is the vague name given;—“April” 1741The camp was at Lexden Heath, May–Oct. 1741. may not be the exact month either; but it will probably be near it. If you find anything about the simultaneous German Camp (“Hameln” or wherever it was, for I think it shifted, and was often split into pieces, and perhaps reunited &c) I shall be willing to hear of it too. Not many Extracts (none, unless you find them worthy); skeleton of the fact (English fact, especially) is what I want.
You need not write in answer to this: merely send me what you succeed in gathering about this part of the business. This part first.—— In great haste (as is too usual)
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [12 May]. Addr: Thornhill / Dumfries / N. B. PM: London, 12 May 1859. MS: NLS 606.522. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 210–13. Quot: Blunt, CR 147–48; Hansons, NE 477.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Had I been ever so well, I shouldn’t have written till you wrote—just to bring it home to your business and bosom,Cf. Francis Bacon; see JWC to GEGEL, 20 Feb. how much easier it is to keep out of a long silence than to get out of it! (For you couldn’t but know very well, my Dear, that you were owing me a long letter; in spite of your cool doubts as to whose turn it was!) Indeed I was very cross with you, till I heard that you had been ill with your stomach—and then I regretted that I had stood on my rights of womanJWC usually wrote “rights of women” (cf. 13:196JWC to JF, [24 July 1841], 19:180JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1845], and 24:157JWC to MML, 1 Aug. 1849), generally in an ironic fashion.—when I could so easily have written on the voluntary principle.Coterie speech; see 26:158JWC to TC, [7 Sept. 1851]. Especially as to answer your letter at once on receiving it was among things forbidden to me— My Dear for weeks I had been forbidden to write, or read, or talk, or think!! above all I was “on no account to think”! I “might knit” in my bed if I liked—but nothing else—besides swallowing tonics, wine, and “nourishing food” from morning till night and I might add from night till morning! And as I never had succeeded in learning to knit and my DoctorTC wrote on the envelope: “(12 May, 1859) / Barnes first”; Dr. Barnes was first mentioned in TC to JCA, 20 April. “couldn’t teach me” (which he excessively regretted) I had just to resign myself to be an Idiot!—— So!— I have had a ‘Dr’ after all! Dr Russell will say, he had been
right then in telling me, I “had never been very ill or I would have sent for a Dr”! But let me tell him first, why I sent for a Dr on the present occasion— In the first place my head was getting light which threatened to disable me from giving directions about myself—in the second place, there was need of somebody with authority who knew, to explain to Mr C that if care were not taken, I should die of sheer weakness! a thing which makes no show to inexperienced eyes—especially to eyes blinded with incessant contemplation of Frederick the Great!— So I sent for the nearest General PractionerThus in MS. Dr. Barnes lived at 182 King’s Rd., Chelsea; he was listed as a surgeon. (whom I knew to bow to—and had often been struck with the human, practical look of)—and he came and more than realized my most sanguine expectations—not only making the danger of my situation understood—so that I was delivered from petty worries, and noises, and all that, but helping me up with strength—in medecines, and especially by giving me to understand that if I did not make myself eat I would certainly die.— The violent illness which had preceded this state of weakness, I had treated he said “quite right” but “my audacity was not a thing he would recommend me to repeat”! During the three weeks that I saw him every day, and was allowed to see no one else, I indeed took quite a serious attachment to him! And as he finds me the very oddest patient he ever had he now sits with me half-an-hour instead of the official three minutes! Another thing—he is not unlike Dr Russell—certainly far liker him than any other medical man in London! But I am writing too long— I am in the drawing room now (after three weeks confinement to bed)—most part of the day at least—and may see one person daily—and I am improving in strength slowly but steadily— So soon as I am up to moving and the weather is warm I must go my Dr says to the seaside— God bless you
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 14 May. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 14 May. MS: NLS 553.195. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: There is nothing new here; or nothing new that is good (a death sad to us has happened at Falmouth; a cousin of my wife’s;John Welsh d. 12 May. a very fine young soul, tragically cut off);—and we are weltering about, with little progress, in this inclement element;—nothing new at all that is not rather bad! But you had better come and glance at the old again, tomorrow evg, and let us compare Notes.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LS], 17 May. MS: NLS 19.3.52. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: Contrary to what I said, the other day, in answer to your benevolent question about madeira, I now privately discover that the “exquisite” sort in use for a certain Weak Creature’s Zambiano,For “zabaglione” (French “sabayon”); Italian dessert made from egg yolks, sugar, and a sweet fortified wine, usually Marsala; for TC’s recipe, see TC to [JC], 20 May. is actually running low! I therefore permit your Ladyship the luxury (such you esteem it) there contemplated:—to the extent of Two Bottles, not more!—
We are still rather low here; and weak against the weather; as, we fear, your case too is. But the wind is now evidently coming round to west; and that will be a great benefit to all the Thinskinned.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JC], 20 May. MS: NLS 516.70. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee identified as James Carlyle in JWC to JC, [ca. 24 May], when she refers to “the thing Carlyle told you of made of Eggs and wine,” i.e., the recipe for “Zambaio” [zabaglione] that TC gives below.
div3.head: TC TO [JAMES CARLYLE]

docBody.p: Thanks for your brief Notes; welcome tho’ brief. I hope you have got back to Scotsbrig safe the second time,—“for good” now, as I suppose;—and that wereThus in MS; for “there.” will some favourable account of poor Isabella come tomorrow. We have had a dreadful May of it, all of us! Jane, from her bed, often talks to me of Isabella; and we “wonder how she is” &c; very sorry to think of the bad she has had, and still has.Isabella Carlyle had been seriously ill for eight or nine weeks and d. 1 June. The shifting to upstairs was evidently a good movement; she cannot but be better for so much better a lodgement,—in that venerable old room, so memorable, so strange to me when I but think of it!Probably the room in which TC’s mother died in 1853.—The curtains of the bed I found misarranged; letting in the light upon one’s face: but of course that is easily mended, if found inconvenient.

Our DrDr. Alfred Brooke Barnes. here, a sensible kind of man, does a great deal by “improved diet,“—by continually enforcing and enjoining that, as the means of getting strength, which is the thing wanted. I have no doubt you are wide awake to
that too, and that Isabella’s case is one greatly depending upon weakness too. There has come up here,—not by our Doctor’s invention, but greatly praised by him, and producing good effects,—an Italian article, called “Zambaio” by some, by others “Zambiano”; which perhaps you know already: in case you do not, let me describe it to you, on chance. Two new eggs of the best quality (Scotsbrig not to be equalled in that respect); beat them well up, with a great deal of pounded sugar (quantity I cannot give, but the thing is extremely sweet); add then one glass of the very best madeira or sherry; stir in small saucepan; set on the fire and still diligently stir: in a minute or two it is a beautiful yellow batter;—one of the nicest articles for taste; and nutritive, I shd think, beyond any other.— That is my poor contribution of a recipe, if it shd happen to be of the least use or applicability! The fine weather, whh is now at hand (deluges of straight-down rain are pouring overhead) will itself be half the battle, I hope. Good news will be very welcome here!

Poor John Welsh is gone, as doubtless you have heard: he had 4 days of actual confinement to bed (Friday Evg to Wedy evg); but his sufferings, from sore throat &c, were latterly heavier & heavier. His death is a sternly tragical thing in one’s solitude here.— Jane comes into the drawing room, thro’ the day; means to go out under the first sunshine with wind to west. Weak very, and sleeps ill. Yours ever
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CWW, 23 May. MS: Robert Mooney. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLOTTE WILLIAMS WYNN

docBody.p: My Wife is still weak, and forbidden all noise or disturbance; but I think she sees one or two people almost every day, who are gentle with her and do not stay long: you, I should say, had only to come early enough any day (12 or 1 o’clock, before she has had her allowance of Company), in order to be gladly admitted and welcomed.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JC, [ca. 24 May]. MS: NLS Acc. 7988. Hitherto unpbd. Dated a few days after TC to JC, 20 May, when TC sent the recipe for zabaglione; see also below.
div3.head: JWC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: When I hear of poor Isabella being so dreadfully weak, I feel as if nothing but my own weakness were preventing me from flying off to Scotsbrig, to try and strengthen her up with the same means which has brought me thus far in the way of recovery, from a state of weakness as extreme.

When I sent for a Doctor,—(not so much in expectation that he could do me any good; as that he might make Mr C and Charlotte understand how ill I was, so as to insure myself deliverance from noise &c) I was utterly spent—feeling as I lay on my bed, as tho’ I were sinking-sinking in clouds of black smoke; bathed day and night in cold perspiration; and my heart fluttering at the slightest disturbance like a nest of young birds! I hated every sort of food offered me, and hardly touched it. For I did not believe that food taken against one’s appetite could do one any good.

The first thing Mr Barnes did was to tell me plainly that if I did not insist on making myself eat, I should die. and not a little eating would do— I was to eat every two hours—and only the most nourishing things. But what he showed his skill in, was in suggesting a hundred palatable things and describing them temptingly—so that at every visit he left me with a notion of at least one thing of which I thought; “well I might find that possible to swallow!” He gave me of course, at the same time, strengthening medicine—as no doubt Isabellas DoctorsProbably William Bell (1791–1864) and William Young (1809–74). are giving her— For about six weeks now, I have taken twice a day a mixture in which there is a great deal of steel in camphor julepJulep is a liquid sweetened with sugar or syrup to which a variety of medications could be added. Camphor supposedly had a calming effect and was also used in the treatment of colds and chills.—with other things—I have also had every day at least two glasses of wine.

Now if I were there what I would do would be to sit beside Isabella, and talk to her about eating till she could not help thinking about it, and describe to her the things I first took to. Some of them more handy to her than to me. for instance the fresh eggs and the cream— I have been sending all the way to the StrandTo Robert Barham, dairyman, 272 Strand. for little pots of ‘Devonshire cream’ at the rate of fifteen pence a pot! and a pot serves me only two days! She could get so easily the “half pint of good fresh cream“(!) which Mr Barnes ordered for me as an accompaniment
(merely) to my tea in the morning! or I might take a tumbler of new milk with a table spoonful of rum in it the first thing in the morning.

But what has done me most good of all is the thing Carlyle told you of (he says) made of Eggs and wine. Dr Carlyle writes that Isabella would not take that on account of the sugar— Well then, make it without sugar—it would not be so palatable to most people but the strengthening part of it, the wine and egg would be there. Now do let dear little JennyJames and Isabella’s da. Janet. make this for her Mother and persuade her to try it.

Separate two yolks of quite new eggs from the whites and drop them into a small saucepan—then put to them a full glassful of wine and keep whipping up the egg yolks and wine over a slow fire, till it is all in a froth. Pour it in a teacup—and take it up with it a bit of nicely toasted bread. Another way of doing egg that perhaps would suit best with the condition of no sugar is to whip up a yolk in a tea cup, then mix a glass of wine with it and fill up the cup with boiling water, pouring slowly and stirring as Dr Carlyle does with his tea. I have had quantities of calve’s foot Jelly sent me—but I don’t find much strengthening in it and I only take it during the night, when I lie awake—as a sort of melancholy distraction! Mr Barnes has no faith in jelly—Thinks essence of beef much better—

One thing that I have been much the better for Isabella could get famously from Annan and that is Salmon! People fancy it unwholesome—but it was after my first dinner of Salmon that I felt the first assurance I should live! and that I had my first natural sleep. I have had it often since and it has always agreed with me. Such beautiful salmon trout you have at Annan! How I should like to try her with a bit!

I am still very weak and you would not think to look at me I had much to brag of—but if you had seen what I was!— Oh my dear Jamie I pray God you may soon be out of this anxiety give her my kindest love I would have written to herself but that I fear she could not be troubled with all this
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JC], 24 May. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 36:268–69, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO [JAMES CARLYLE]

docBody.p: We were sadly shocked and astonished yesterday; never till that phrase in yr Letter abt “hope” had we understood that there was any immediate apprehension of fail:—merely the old business, we always thought, aggravated by the terrible weather &c &c! Alas, alas. It was not till this morning that I perceived by your detail of that continual motion demanded,Isabella Carlyle was suffering from continuous diarrhea; see 35:101JWC to MW, 28 May, 1859.—how the strength must have continual demands made on it, and till that stop or abate must be getting lower and lower. God help us; we can only wish and hope!—

Yesternight Jane wrote, about diet &c;JWC wrote to James suggesting he tempt Isabella to eat by describing a variety of delicacies, and also advocating the “strengthening” mixture of eggs and wine that she had been taking; her letter can now be dated 23 May; see 35:97–98JWC to JC, 24 May. and did not see till today, how wide it wd mostly be of the mark.

Yesternight I wrote off to LeithHutchison & Co., Leith wine merchants; TC noted: “May 29 1859 / £3..0..0 (Hutchinn Leith, / ’for wine’,—ah me!)” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). for some Bottles of “the best sherry” to be sent: I was aware her house contained sherry; but I thot possibly this “best” kind might be of better quality. An egg-yolk among sherry, Oh how I should like to hear of her swallowing it. In fine, dear Brother, forgive us,—continue your exertions, of course you do and will;—and do not think it “painful” to write “no news” to us. A short bulletin will be much prized here.
Adieu, the horse is at the door / Yours ever affecte / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [25 May]. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 25 May 1859. MS: NLS 553.196. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Dear Neuberg,—Wms & Norgate sent the Herzog [Duke] Ferdinand Book, “vol 2,” yesternight: tell them I will keep it, but that it is worth nothing to me
till I get vol 1 to begin upon!Ernst Julius Georg von dem Knesebeck, Ferdinand Herzog zu Braunschweig und Lüne-burg während des siebenjährigen Krieges, 2 vols. (Hanover, 1857–58); TC’s copy: HCC.— I also (and much more pressingly) wish you cd urge upon them some despatch abt Adelung:See TC to JN, 28 Feb. “Coming, coming”; and it does not come, not even in an imperfect state;—and I am daily obliged to some contrivance for doing without it; and you can fancy how lovely it will be, arriving like ten (or 9?)There were nine vols. in 10 quartos. cartloads of beastly mustard after the dinner is done! Pray call some day, and urge!

A fine Letter from Emerson,See TC to RWE, 9 April. whh you shall see. Sunday Evg come, and all the PreussesProbably referring to both Friedrich der Grosse mit seinen Verwandten und Freunden (Berlin, 1838) and Die Lebensgeschichte des grossen Königs Friedrich von Preussen, 2 vols. (Berlin, 1837); TC’s copies: HCC. &c with you that you have done with.— Yrs ever truly T. C.

ps.p: (Chelsea, Wedy)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 26 May. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 26 May 1859. MS: NLS 553.197. TC’s letter is written on the back of Williams & Norgate to TC, 25 May. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I have heard nothing of the Prints:See TC to JN, 25 April. pray call, get hands on them, and let us end that bit of business.

By the inverse side of this (whh arrives along with your Note) you will see immediate prospect of Adelung;—perhaps also of Seyfart (the Friedh II); concerning whh later a small message marked.Williams & Norgate wrote: “Adelung Staatsgesch. 8 vols will be here next week.” TC added: “Swift, then!” “Vol. I of the Lebens und Regier. Gesch Friedrichs II [Seyfart] has also been ordered, but they have not yet found the Namen-Verzeichniss [name index].” TC added: “Does this mean that ‘vol I’ has actually been got hold of? If so, let it be sent for instantly! The Namen-Verzeichniss (of whh I already have a borrowed copy) can wait to any length of leisure. ‘vol I’ at once!” See 100above. It is not clear what the “Namen-Verzeichniss” refers to as, according to TC’s notes (HCC and Works 14:1267), Seyfart’s book had no index. For Adelung and Seyfart, see TC to JN, 28 Feb.
Williams & Norgate to Thomas Carlyle, 25 May 1859
Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

GyulaiCount Franz Gyulai (1798–1868), Austrian gen. When the Austrians discovered in 1858 that Napoleon III and Cavour had met to discuss the unification of Italy, Gyulai was sent to invade Piedmont. The Piedmontese, supported by the French, forced the Austrians to retire after the battle of Magenta, 4 June 1859. I will now know,—to be at least by hand.— Much illness in our
circle still (a poor sister-in-law dangerously situatedIsabella Carlyle d. 1 June; her death certificate noted that she had suffered from diarrhea for ten weeks; TC told Alexander Carlyle that “her complaint was of the liver and bowels”; see TC to AC, 7 Oct. in Annandale); my Wife herself beginning to get out, tho’ still very weakly.
In haste (to try for a little work,—alas!)
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 28 [27] May. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. MS: 553.198. Hitherto unpbd. TC probably misdates 28 rather than mistaking the day; Fri. was 27 May.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Will you be so beneficent as take this German gentlemanGerman gentleman unidentified. in hand, and try to do for him what the sacred duties command.

He seems to want a couple of Notes from HumboldtFriedrich Heinrich Alexander, Baron von Humboldt (1769–1859), Prussian naturalist, explorer, and diplomat. translated into English,—“a most vital service,” he seems to intimate. But as he cannot speak one word of English, as asThus in MS. I have not half a moment of time, I can make nothing of him, and must roll him over upon you.
To me he brought no kind of introduction (merely got tumbled in); but he seems to be a very innocent little creature.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Friday 3.20 p.m,—in endless haste

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MW, [28 May?]. Pbd: Huxley, LJWC 638. Dated after John Welsh’s death, 12 May, and with reference to JWC’s slow recovery from her illness; see TC to JN, 26 May. Huxley dates “(June 1859).“
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET WELSH

docBody.p:
Just two lines from myself, dear Margaret, to urge on you, that you should come here and recover from the fatigues of the journey,Presumably from Falmouth, where she had been with her son, John. before proceeding to Richmond—since my present state makes it too impossible for me to go to
Richmond to receive you; as I should otherwise have certainly done. Your home-coming will be too dreadful, poor dear soul! without the petty aggravation of bodily weariness. I will say nothing more— My God what is there to be said!— But you know how I feel for you without needing to be told. The merest stranger would feel for you; and I am his cousin—and know all that he was.
God comfort you—no mortal need try.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IEB, [early June]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Froude, LM 2:394–95. Quot: Blunt, CR 148. Dated at the beginning of JWC’s friendship with Isabella Barnes, after she had recovered from her illness; Dr. Barnes had attended JWC since April; see TC to JCA, 20 April. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 3 June 1859.]
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA EMILY BARNES

docBody.p: Your FatherDr. Alfred Brooke Barnes. left a message for me this morning, the answer to which I expected him to “come and take,” when he had done with our next-door neighbour.Possibly Anne Gilchrist, who lived at no. 6. But—Blessed are they who expect nothing;Cf. Matt. 5:3–11. they shall not be disappointed! Pray come to tea with me tomorrow evening—at seven—if my Husbands particular Friends “The Destinies” alias “The Upper Powers” alias “The Immortal Gods” (your Father says you read Mr C so you will understand me) dont interfere to keep you away.

I will drop this at your doorThe Barnes family lived at 182 King’s Rd., Chelsea. in passing for my drive—and along with it a piece of old, old German crockery which had the honour, to catch your Fathers eye and has set its heart on belonging to him! So dont let it get broken—till he have seen it at least!

All you know of me as yet is, that I seem to be in the very lowest state as to penmanship! But I assure you I can write much more tidily than this—made with the back of the very worst pen in the created world! And if you will bring with you tomorrow evening whatever stock you may have of “hope, faith, and charity”1 Cor. 13:13. I have no doubt but we shall become good friends.
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JC], 3 June. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 36:269, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO [JAMES CARLYLE]

docBody.p: My thoughts are full of you this sad day;Isabella had d. 1 June and was buried 5 June. and I have no word that it is of use to say. I feel my own loss to be great in this matter;—what then is yours! She is at rest, she suffers no more. She was a faithful Helpmate to you; with superior worth, and much simple nobleness of mind, which none of us can forget while we live: God has taken her from you; it is an irreparable loss; and you are not forbidden to sorrow over it as the heart of man must. Jane says (or has often said), it must be a blessed thought to you now, how kind and defensive and protective you always were to Her that is gone; of whh she often spoke to Jane (as I now hear) with a lively gratitude

My Dear Brother, may God’s blessing be on you, and on what is now left to your sole charge!James and Isabella Carlyle’s three children, James, John, and Janet (known as Jenny). That is all I can write today. Indeed I am very sorry; very dark and sorry.
In a day or two I hope to write farther. Bid the Dr send me another line if he is still with you.John A. Carlyle sent an account of the funeral, 6 June; see 35:106TC to JAC, 7 June.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 5 June. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Quot: “New Letters By Carlyle,” Times, 29 June 1914. Charles Augustus Ward (1828–1914), vintner, poet, and antiquarian.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES A. WARD

docBody.p: There is a great deal of fire and talent in this little Book;England Subsists by Miracle (1859), written under Ward’s pseudonym of Feltham Burghley, denounced the hypocrisy and corruption in English society in Carlylean tones: “The terrific disclosures of immorality that daily come before the public; the legal facilities that are now offered for obtaining divorce, furnishing encouragement to adulterous alliances; the scandalous frauds that disgrace the trading community, and make commerce like a wild beast, with stains as frequent as the leopard’s skin … the religious hypocrisy that begets reputation; the false education that makes the poor knowing and insolent, instead of humble and industrious; on the other hand, the scepticism which boldly blasphemes the great All-Giver of its treasonous reason; the ill-disposed demagogue who shouts loud for reform, making sharp the wedge of revolution the while; the Papist carrying on covertly his insidious game … the list of canting villainies would be painfully too long to recount, if even it could be recounted here” (105–6). much manly insight and emphatic declaration, which the vulgar of mankind are still strangers to: I vote that this is considerably more like the road for an earnest Literary man than any of the former courses I have seen you on;Ward had sent TC a manuscript to assess in the summer of 1854; see 29:123–25TC to CAW, 6 July 1854. and that you try this farther, and with all the faculty and active and passive virtue you have, to see what it will yield, to you and to your neighbours of mankind!—You manifest the elements of a very considerable gift for writing as a man should write in the England that now is; but give me leave to say they are in good part only elemental as yet; and will require a long tough struggle, on your side, to bring them into the perfection they are worthy of. It is mainly a question of morality, as you will find by and by. If you can endure and endeavour, in a manful, modest and honest manner, victory does lie ahead, in my opinion!

You have recognized with noble indigna[tion] the brutal leprosy poor England has fallen into, and you do not, like the vulgar, reckon it florid health and increase of weight: this is excellent to start with; but in going on, you will find you have not yet got near the bottom of that horrible phenomenon (unless I mistake it); and that there are strange questions to settle, and sad and strenuous things to do, very many, before you can with your right strength grapple it, and deal with it. Your contempt of the Penny Newspapers is transcendant,Ward condemned the popular press for its slavish allegiance to the principles of free trade and universal suffrage: “The penny papers are wildly, insanely edited, and become the frantic exponents and exaggerators of the already flagrant follies of agitator Bright; who is nothing else but a rude, and ignorant democrat of considerable natural powers, but lawless, and uncultivated, and an infidel to the constitution of England. … No penny paper—we speak from personal knowledge—no cheap provincial paper can sell now, if it be not warm in the advocacy of manhood suffrage and electoral districts. It is no matter how English it may be—how thorough going in the exposure of abuses—it must advocate the above trash, or it is doomed; and the editors soon find this out, and against their better judgment supply the requisite fustian to the fustian jackets” (54–55). TC had met and argued with the radical politician John Bright (1811–89; ODNB) in 1847; see 22:58TC to JWC, 9 Sept. 1847, and 22:68TC to JWC, 13 [14] Sept. 1847. as it ought to be: but I think you have not perhaps enough
meditated, and above all practiced, what I call “the Silences” (about whh too I am profoundly serious);—and that, one day, perhaps, you will be astonished to find how much the Penny Newspapers (and their Penny Philosophies, indubitable to all the world just now) have still hold of you. Verb. Sap. [verbum sapienti satis est; a word to the wise is enough.]

It is not for want of business of my own that I interfere so far in yours, and write these things;—as, I doubt not, you perceive without my telling you. In very great haste (a too habitual state with me of late times)
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JJGW, 6 June. Pbd: Clement J. Wilkinson, James John Garth Wilkinson: A Memoir (1911) 37. James John Garth Wilkinson (1812–99; ODNB), Swedenborgian writer and homeopathic doctor; known to TC since 1838 (see TC to JJGW, 2 Aug. 1838), they had probably met by 1843 (see TC to JJGW, [early May? 1843]); see also TC to JAC, 26 March 1858.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES JOHN GARTH WILKINSON

docBody.p: My dear Sir,—I am sorry to be cut off from attending you on this pleasant occasion.The marriage of Wilkinson’s eldest da., Emma Marsh Wilkinson, 16 Aug., to Hermann Karl Pertz (1833–81), lieut. in the Royal Prussian Engineers, son of Georg Heinrich Jakob Pertz (1795–1876), historian. We are too weak here (especially the poor wife), and too busy (especially the other party, who is like to be swallowed and extinguished altogether with a job too heavy for him, and too hideous)—too weak and busy for going out at all, for many months past, even under the handiest circumstances.
I pray you offer my respects and congratulations to all the parties, old and young, concerned in this glad business, and believe me, yours sincerely,

div3.sourceNote: TC-W&N [WAN], 6 June. MS: NLS 7197.70. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAMS & NORGATE

docBody.p: To Messrs Williams & Norgate

The Adelung will do extremely well:—I only wish it had come 3 months ago; it wd have saved me a great deal of trouble so.—— There are now 3 other points to be attended to (with all the speed you can oblige me with!)

1o. To get, and forward with the utmost despatch, the “Seyfart (Friedh der Andern) vol I,“—or whole Book, or any Book-Copy that has vol I, if you cannot get vol I by itself.For Adelung and Seyfart, see TC to JN, 28 Feb. TC wrote “der” for “des” in “Friedh der Andern.” Only soon, for I am in great want of it!

2o. The first vol of Knesebeck’s Herzog Ferdinand & 7 years-War, of whh you have sent me vol II. Vol II cannot be used, or begun upon at all, till Vol I is got:Williams & Norgate had sent vol. 2 of Knesebeck’s Ferdinand Herzog zu Braunschweig und Lüneburg in May; see TC to JN, [25 May]. About this too I am in haste; meaning to take it to the country with me in about 2 weeks.

3o. Be so good as send for Hormayr’s Anemonen. (Hormayr is Author of the Oesterreichische Plutarch,Baron Joseph von Hormayr-Hortenburg (1781–1848), Austrian historian, archivist, and statesman; Anemonen, aus dem Tagebuche eines alten Pilgersmannes, 3 vols. (Jena, 1845–47) and Oesterreichischer Plutarch, oder Leben und Bildnisse aller Regenten und der berühmtesten Feldherren, Staatsmänner, Gelehrten und Künstler des österreichischen Kaiserstaates, 20 vols. (Vienna, 1807–14). a man of real talent; the Anemonen (“Anemonies”) also treat of Austrian History, but in a bitter style, whence their name: I think it is in four voll. or so, a Book not scarce at all:—this too I want soon; but it is not so pressing as the others.
You will oblige me much by expediting these things.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Chelsea, 6 june 1859—

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JAC], [7? June]. MS: NLS 518.79 inc. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee identified as John A. Carlyle because of the references to his stepsons. Presumably a reply to John’s letter to TC, [6 June], and dated shortly after Isabella Carlyle’s funeral, 5 June; TC has written on the back of John’s letter: “Isabella’s Funeral / ah me! / (on Saturday 5 june / 1859).” The first part of this letter is missing and probably contains TC’s response to John’s account, [6 June], of Isabella’s death, 1 June, and her funeral, 5 June. John wrote: “The funeral yesterday was got thro’ in a very quiet & orderly manner, though there was an unusually great attendance of people. Young James, John, & James Aitken walked behind the hearse, & immediately after them were Jamie & I in the gig. … Mary & Jean were both at Scotsbrig. Robert Calvert [Isabella’s brother; see 26:biographical note] too was there from Manchester. / Now that one looks back to the illness which Isabella had for so many years, one cannot regret for her sake that she is now at peace. And for all that remain behind her it is a comfort to think that her end was so peaceful, & that every thing possible was done for her up to the very last moment.” Women generally did not go to the graveside.
div3.head: TC TO [JOHN A. CARLYLE]

docBody.p: in the Country. The first scheme was towards Bourne MouthBournemouth, Dorset, seaside town, 111 mi. SW of London. (a place you perhaps know), nor has that yet been quite condemned; nay I think of going to look and examine there, from “Friday to Monday” next, an extremely “cheap train” offering inducements.There was no train to Bournemouth until 1862; TC would have taken a train to Poole, 5 mi. E of Bournemouth, on the Southampton and Dorchester Railway. Jane says she will herself go, if I don’t!—We shall then say Yes or No to Bournth: & there will remain the Scotch eligibilities to be tested.

Jane does not like the idea of Nithsdale at all (so many half-acquaintances &c &c); and I must not rashly contradict her notions (even if I had difft ones) in the present state of matters. There was never any finis abt Bonshaw, abt Annandale generally?Bonshaw mansion, ca. 4 mi. SE of Ecclefechan; see 2:3TC to JCE, 12 Jan. 1822. For TC’s interest in renting a house in Annandale, see TC to JAC, 14 April.—In the meanwhile some Miss LiddelPresumably one of the Liddell family, who farmed at Kirkton and owned Auchtertool House; see also 31:163JWC to TC, [8 Aug. 1856]. or other set Jane thinking about a “Farm House with Lodgings,”Perhaps Humbie Farm, where the Carlyles stayed from 24 June until 5 Aug. where Lord SomebodyUnidentified. lived one summer,—close by the sea some 4 or 3 miles from Auchtertool;—whh looked, and still looks, rather seductive. MaggyMaggie Welsh, JWC’s cousin at Auchtertool Manse, Fife. has been giving acct of it,—of it, and of some Furnished MansionAuchtertool House. close by the Manse, “whh is not to let now, but can be had” (I do not well understand how),—in considerable disrepair, as to furniture, I guess. My notion about the whole
matter is very dim; and perhaps you, if you have a day of leisure, cd throw light on it to me,—going over to Auchtertool, looking pointedly into everything with your own eyes, and reporting upon it candidly. The Farm House and its capabilities seems to be the really promising matter: if the essentials there were satisfactory, little Charlotte (who is an excellt clever little creature, & looks well after Jane) cd cook, clean &c to the wholesomest perfection; and with my Horse there (whh I shd bring up in a steamer, and certain Books), and a little pony or ass for Jane (or a Bath-chair, if there be roads, and be a procurable man to draw it); with these and other attainable &c we shd probably get a great deal of good of the Forth Sea-water and fine sea-sands and pure air, in summer weather and on country diet. In case you should be able to go (whh I have no right to expect either) I will ask you to take an approximation to a foot-rule with you (stick notched to the length of a yard, for instance), and to tell approximately what the dimensions of the several rooms are,—height, length, breadth,—what kind of furniture, what &c &c; above all what kind of people. Whether they wd take Care of one’s Horse; furnish unexceptionable farm-produce (butter, eggs, fowls, milk), and be reasonable to live with. I mean my Horse to fill his insatiable belly with grass (nothing can equal his appetite for it just now), and I wd give him 2 feeds of Corn per day,—to keep him in heart (better than he has been for years past, till quite lately) is a most essential matter to me. If in luck, I am to start printingPresumably of the 3d printing of Frederick, vols. 1 and 2, which included further corrections; Chapman & Hall began to advertise it (as the 3d edn.) in the Athenaeum, 12 Nov. See also Tarr 173–74. on my return hither; and ought to be in a far other state of health than has been constant with me since I last left The Gill!— Jane wd need to negociate too about some Pony, Bath-Chair, Ass, or means of moving, as above-said; having almost no strength at all to walk. But that of course cd not be difficult to settle in any such place.— The delicacies of sleeping, question of cocks &c &c, all these and other such points you are alive to, without hint needed. In short, exercise your judgement and your eyes; and say what result they yield. I have been interrupted; “dinner ready,” then ” ’oss ready”; and have missed the afternoon’s post. It is now night 10 p. m.— Jane, at dinner, read to me a new Letter of her Cousin Maggie’s which gives a much more precise account of matters. So that, if it should be inconvenient to you, do not mind this Commission at all: most likely I shall have to come down myself, and take my luck of the thing, in case we reject Bne Mouth,—as is likely enough: “too hot,” people tell us. Ah me, ah me. Henry WattHenry Watt, one of John’s stepsons, was presumably on leave from his ship. has just been here: brisk and well. I am glad you got good news from Woolwich.Henry Watt’s brother William, the youngest stepson, was enrolled at the Woolwich Royal Military Academy; John wrote, [6 June], that he had got back to Edinburgh “last night at eight, & have quite favourable reports of poor little Willie. He seems convalescent; so I shall probably be allowed to stay here & rest myself.” John was staying at 67 Hanover St., Edinburgh.— Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JC], 8 June. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 36:270–71, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO [JAMES CARLYLE]

docBody.p: In regard to what you write by Jamie this morning, I answer without delay, Yes. It is a duty, and will be a pious pleasure to me, to repair and set right in all ways the solemn City of RefugeCf. Num. 35:11. where those forever dear to us now rest;The graveyard at Ecclefechan; for the family gravestone, see 35:229TC to AC, 7 Oct.—and I can only bid you proceed in the business when and in what way you judge to be fittest. I forward Jamie’s Note to the Doctor tonight, in case he should have anything to say about it: but that need occasion no dubiety, for I am ready to pay the whole expense myself, if none object to it;TC paid for renovations to the family plot, and John A. Carlyle paid for the refurbishment of the railings around the plot; see TC to JC, 23 May 1860. Isabella’s name was added to the gravestone of their son Thomas; see 35:228TC to AC, 7 Oct. and you have only to get the business done properly, and let me know when it is to be settled about between us. I hope you have already paid LatimerPossibly John Lattimer (ca. 1796–1866), mason, Forgebraehead, Canonbie, Dumfriesshire. for that change in the Lettering; and that you keep the sum marked against me, that I may not forget it when we meet. These things are a kind of solacement to one’s sad heart to attend to; and I would not keep you waiting in regard to this.

I am sorry Jamie did not say anything about John’sJames’s son John. cold, caught in the way I heard of. Let him take great care in case of such accidents. I understood last summerTC was in Annandale from 24 June to 20 Aug. 1858. he was reckoned rather liable in that direction; which is a dangerous one at his time of life, but can be much guarded against by care taken, & I believe much diminishes in danger as one grows older. I hope he is now well again,—and that in health you are all well. Poor little Jenny,—poor all of you, all of us I may say; for we have all had a loss that cannot be forgotten! But I must not speak of these things. Time softens all sorrows, tho’ at a certain age it cannot abolish them: let us walk steadfastly and humbly, and try to do our poor wisest in the ever-altering Pilgrimage appointed us. We are going whither those before us have gone; only a short space separates us, altogether short the longest it can be!

Perhaps I shall see you in Scotsbrig before long. There is a necessity or clear propriety for both of us to get into the Country for two or three summer months: a sad untowardly job to me; but, I think, an unavoidable this year. We
are decidedly looking towards Scotland,TC and JWC spent July, Aug., and Sept. 1859 in Scotland, at first together in Fife; TC then visited his family in Annandale while JWC went to visit her aunts in Edinburgh and then to stay with the Donaldson sisters in Haddington. I perceive, if there wd anything inviting turn up. I believe I shall have to go and look with my own eyes. My blessing with you all, dear Brother. / T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 10 June. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Enclosed is a List of Localities belonging to the Battle of Sohr. If you cd (by tracing or some easy method) make me a slight map with all these in it, that wd be one of the things, first likely to be useful now.Frederick defeated the Austrians at the battle of Sohr, 30 Sept. 1745; see Works 16:152–57; for map, see Works 16:opp. 156.
docBody.name: T. C.

ps.p: Hy Larkin Esq

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 10 June. MS: NLS 553.199. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:344.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: What with east winds, organ-grinders, what with bad nerves, stupidities, we are getting on very ill here;—talking about being off to the sea-side (to Scotland most likely) in a few days. Come on Sunday evg, you shall hear more.

In RaumerSee TC to JN, 7 Jan. (p. 104) is a notable passage, ‘Austrian Hofrath [councillors] falling all back in their chairs like dead men’ when they first undeniably heard that France was going to war with them.For French participation in the first Silesian War, see Works 15:248–52. Stupid Raumer does not date itRaumer gives only the date of Frederick’s secret treaty with France, 5 June 1741. (and has otherwise blotched it), nor does Coxe,William Coxe, Memoirs of Sir Robert Walpole, 3 vols. (1798); see 33:105TC to RH, 25 Oct. 1857. nor does anybody: from RobinsonSee TC to JN, 7 Jan. it can be dated (doubtless, in State Pr Office), and I want the date much.

Also abt Maria Tha’s Kronung [coronation] at Presburg; you seem to have got from Mailath that it was ‘20 May’;—it is in reality 25 june;Maria Theresa was crowned queen of Hungary at Pressburg, 38 mi. E of Vienna, 25 June 1741; see Works 15:222. For Mailéth, see TC to JN, 7 Jan. and I cd wish to know (Robinson agn the probable source) when she returned to Wien out of that, and when out of Wien (in terror of French and Bavarians) back into
that, and fabulous Moriamur pro rege nostro [Let us die for our King].See Works 15:259–62. (Not of much consequence this to me; only the wiping up of a slobber out of History;—not much trouble due to this. The Raumer point is the importt one).
You will get a Copy of Raumer in the London Library: p. 104 is the place; but I doubt you will not be able to settle the thing so early as tomorrow.

Adelung is a capital fellow; fair Index to him, too! Will be worth ten times his money to me.TC had received his copy of Adelung’s Pragmatische Staatsgeschichte Europens via Williams & Norgate; see TC to JN, 26 May. Frh der Andern (complete at last) is gone to the Binder.Seyfart’s Lebens- und Regierungs-Geschichte Friedrichs des andern Königs in Preussen had been ordered by 25 May; see TC to JN, 26 May. TC wrote “der” for “des.” The binder was possibly T. Morrison, bookbinder, whom TC had paid for previous work, 6 Nov. 1858 (MS: NLS 20753). If I were only a little fresher of nerve (by sea-bathing, milk-diet &c), and you free from that Translation Enchantt,Neuberg’s trans. of vol. 2 of Frederick.—we might cut our way after all. ‘End of Septr,’ I have appointed, the Printing is to start;The 3d printing of Frederick. and the Printer CerberusCharles Robson was the printer. Cerberus is the mythical dog guarding the gates to the Underworld. to chace us thro’ that “Rotten Sea,”Cf. Samuel Taylor Coleridge, “The Ancient Mariner” lines 236–43. or boundless, featureless, putrid quagmire, whh is neither sea nor land, and where human nature cannot live!—

The ugliest of Emperors, and most mendacious, has got the Open part of Lombardy,Emperor Napoleon III, in alliance with Victor Emmanuel, king of Sardinia, had defeated the Austrians, 4 June; they entered Milan, where “their reception was magnificent and full of enthusiasm,” and the “part of Upper Lombardy which has been freed from the Austrians has hastened to proclaim Victor Emmanuel as King” (Times, 9 June). it wd appear; but I suppose they will expect him at Pizzighitone,Imitating the exploits of his uncle, Napoleon I, who had captured Pizzighettone, a fortress in Lombardy on the Adda River, in 1796 and staged a “triumphal entry” into Milan five days later. & watch how he comes on at eating granite. The “Galgen-Aas [gallows-carrion],” if there ever was one, still digesting victual!—

Dizzy versus PammyNicknames for Benjamin Disraeli and Lord Palmerston. Disraeli was chancellor in the Derby govt., which resigned 10 June. Palmerston formed the new govt. 30 June. is to be settled tonight they say; I care not a whit how it go.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 11 June. MS: NLS 516.71. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Many thanks for your prompt attention, and for the lucid account you have managed to send.Presumably information about accommodation during their proposed visit to Scotland, asked for in TC to JAC, [7? June]. This is a real help to me at present; and, in the dismal, importunate and thrice-hateful chaos from without (beside all the chaos from within) whh this busss of flitting has caused me, I had need enough of help!—To Jane it rather emphatically appears, and to me too in a less emphatic manner, that probably the Paterson Establisht in the village of AberdourPossibly Richard and Janet Paterson of 4 High St., who took lodgers. Aberdour: coastal town in Fife, across the Firth of Forth from Edinburgh. will be the eligible thing. Most clearly a better lodging (the other indeed questionably dingy and stuffy in this respect): the only things that give me pause, are 1o grass for my horse (I want him to go at unlimited grass, for health’s sake, with 2 feeds of corn daily), and 2o the “unlimited command” (or quasi-unlimited, one’s fancy thinks) of Farm-sustenance, milk, eggs, chickens! Probably yr InkeeperTC puts a line over “n” to indicate the double letter. (if respectable and his wife respectable) will be able to furnish us completely in both these respects;—and if so, I am as emphatic as Jane.

So or not so, I cannot stand this wild jumble of dubieties any more; but will and do instruct you to end it for us, by closing with the Paterson offer. on Wedy next15 June. (whether you go over in person again or not, whether you hear again from me or not), pray signify to Mrs Paterson that we take her apartts: first of july (or it may be last days of june) to Augt for certain; we “intend” (you can say) to stay 3 months, perhaps more if it suited; but do not, witht experimenting, make further engaget: if, while our term runs, any ulterior lodger applies, we shall feel bound to give Mrs Pn a definite Yes or No on her then asking us. That, I think, is the reasonable footing; and on that let the whirlblast steady itself, and collapse, in Heaven’s name.

Wedy come a week (if the wind is to west, at least!) I think of starting, Horse & Charlotte and luggage with me, in the Edinr Steamer,See TC to JAC, 16 June.—Wedny 26thWed. was 22 June. 10 a. m., whh I think brings one to LeithEdinburgh’s port on the Firth of Forth. Friday forenoon:—there I shd see you most hoffentlich [hopefully]! Friday Evg we could manage to reach with Hab’ und Gut’ [belongings] the Paterson hospice: Charlotte, who is a
nimble orderly clever little creature, wd break bulk uponUnpack. the “linen & plate,” clothe a tea-table a bed or even two;—and so we shd be installed! Jane wd leave, Thursday 27th,Thurs. was 23 June. by Express Train; sleep at Morpeth,Town 11½ mi. N of Newcastle-upon-Tyne; JWC had stayed a night there in 1849; see 24:159—60JWC’s MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849. perhaps at HaddingtonWith Jess and Jean Donaldson at Tenterfield (Sunnybank). (or two nights with her Aunts in Edinburgh);With Ann, Elizabeth, and Grace Welsh at Craigen Villa, Morningside.—and there the achievement were!—
On those terms therefore, dear Brother!—— Yours ever T. Carlyle

ps.p: We have furious thunder-plumps (grand long deluge yesterday with big hail in it; on the whole very great quantities of rain; and a hot müde [heavy] atmosphere,—very hot today. Grass is growing here (in this garden for instance) as I never saw it.—— Busy, busy (to small purpose!), sacking up my confused mss &c). T. C.
first of the hail yesterday, & these windows dour to open or shut!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 13 June. MS: NLS 516.72. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I have got your Letter; and no doubt you have, by this hour of the day, got mine. TC to JAC, 11 June
. On reflecting farther, the “farm-produce question” (abt unlimited grass, milk, whey &c, a dietetic essentiality for horse and self) assumes additional importance; and I foresee you will have bother upon it in the Paterson case, and probably bother without complete success: we have also heard testimony just now, of an emphatic tenor (from poor Mrs George WelshMargaret Welsh. who has come in), abt the dreadfully “relaxing” nature of Aberdour Village: “a pit of a place, backed with heights and rocks; roasts you to nothing,” &c &c:—so that, on the whole, the final figure of the thing is this:

Give up Paterson’s altogether; answer “No” there, as you pass on Wedny; and go on to Humby, Humbie Farm, owned by James Thomson; for its position nr. Aberdour, see frontispiece [viewable in the CLO on the table of contents page of vol. 35]. The Carlyles were to have the “upper story”; see TC to AC, 7 Oct.
and engage that: £1 per week; week beginning 2 days after that “second Wedy by Steamer” already described (whh I now count tobe “Friday evg 24th,” not being well provided with Almanacks!),—term from
week to week;—and if we are well we shall be sorry when 6 Augt comes, but of course obliged to comply. Fix this bargain: “From evg of june 24th; that is the alone indispensable; the rest will be all capable of good arrangement with honest people such as you describe,—and if we can sleep (by their masking of cocks & cattle, in an obliging manner), there will be no other obstacle.— Jane will require a pony, cuddy or something to carry her about: but that doubtless can be managed well enough;—the grandson BoyProbably Henry Thomson. will be very useful;g—it is probable also the people have some kind of gig (or clatch), whh our Horse (a willing loyal creature) will comfortably go in, if Jane take a notion that way: and on the whole, the people will understand that we are well disposed to pay for all such extras, and not leave in debt for any goodnatured service, done us.—— In fine you might ask whether there is any “Linen & Plate” required there, and if so “Approximately what?” Or you need not, if you happen to forget!— Poor Jane lost her sleep last night “thinking abt the packing of these things,”—poor excitable little soul; weaker than anybody I ever saw, with so much courage left!—
